analyzed: yathā āha bhavatām āgamaḥ cakṣuṣā dṛśyamānam rūpam upādāya iti atas vināśya ātmā
translated: As your scriptures say, Based on form seen by the eye, thus the self is destroyed.

analyzed: tadā tu ayam cakṣuḥ vijñāna vijñeyaḥ
translated: Then this is cognizable by eye consciousness.

original: tadā na vaktavyaṃ na rūpaṃ nārūpamiti /
analyzed: tadā na vaktavyam na rūpam na arūpam iti
translated: Then it cannot be said to be neither form nor not form.

analyzed: evam śabda ādayaḥ api iti
translated: The same applies to sound and so forth.

analyzed: atha yadi ātmā ṣaṣ vijñāna vijñeyaḥ
translated: If the self is cognizable by the six consciousnesses,

original: tadā sūtrairvirucyate /🔽sūtre hyuktampañcendriyāṇi nānyopyasya viṣayān pratyanubhavanti /
analyzed: tadā sūtraiḥ virucyate  sūtre hi uktam pañca indriyāṇi viṣayān pratyanubhavanti
translated: then it contradicts the sutras.

analyzed: iti
translated: For it is said in the sutras, The five faculties do not experience the objects of each other.

analyzed: pratyadhva avasāyasya vaiṣamyāt
translated: Because of the inconsistency of the determination of the three times.

analyzed: yadi ātmā ṣaṣ vijñāna vijñeyaḥ syāt
translated: If the self were cognizable by the six consciousnesses,

analyzed: tadā ṣaḍ indriyāṇi anyonya vṛttīnī syuḥ
translated: then the six faculties would have each other's functions.

analyzed: kiñca bhavat uktam pūrva apara viruddham
translated: Moreover, what you say contradicts your earlier statements.

original: yat cakṣurvijñānavijñeyaṃ na tat rūpamiti bravīṣi /
analyzed: yat cakṣuḥ vijñāna vijñeyam na tat rūpam iti bravīṣi
translated: You say that what is cognized by eye consciousness is not form.

analyzed: bhavān āha na asti ātmā iti iyam mithyādṛṣṭiḥ iti
translated: You say that the view there is no self is a wrong view.

original: sūtre bhagavān svayaṃ bhikṣūnāmantryāhaasatyapyātmani saṃskārāṇāṃ santānamupādāya jananamaraṇamastīti vadāmi /
analyzed: sūtre bhagavān svayam bhikṣūn āmantrya āha asati api ātmani saṃskārāṇām santānam upādāya janana maraṇam asti iti vadāmi
translated: In the sutra, the Blessed One himself addressed the monks, saying: Even though there is no self, I say that birth and death exist based on the continuity of formations.

original: paśyāmi ca divyena cakṣuṣā sattvānutpadyamānān mriyamāṇāṃśca /
analyzed: paśyāmi ca divyena cakṣuṣā sattvān utpadyamānān mriyamāṇān ca
translated: And I see beings being born and dying with my divine eye.

analyzed: atha api na vadāmi asti ātmā iti
translated: Yet I still do not say there is a self.

analyzed: kiñca bhavatām śāsane asti doṣaḥ
translated: Moreover, there is a fault in your doctrine.

original: bhavatāṃ śāsane hyucyate ātmā na jāyata iti /
analyzed: bhavatām śāsane hi ucyate ātmā na jāyate iti
translated: For in your doctrine it is said that the self is not born.

analyzed: yaḥ jātaḥ sa mātā pitṛbhyām vihīnaḥ
translated: One who is unborn is devoid of mother and father.

analyzed: mātā pitṛbhyām vihīnasya na asti ānantaryam
translated: One devoid of mother and father has no immediate retribution.

original: anyānyapi pāpakarmāṇi na santi ityato bhavatāṃ śāsanameva mithyādarśanam /
analyzed: anyāni api pāpa karmāṇi na santi iti atas bhavatām śāsanam eva mithyā darśanam
translated: And there are no other evil actions, so your doctrine itself is a wrong view.

analyzed: bhavān āha bhavasya pūrvasmāt utpādaḥ iti
translated: You say that existence arises from a previous existence.

analyzed: pañca skandhān upādāya sudarśanaḥ nāma rājā
translated: Based on the five aggregates, there was a king named Sudarshana.

original: ta eva pañcaskandhāḥ santatyā buddho bhavati /
analyzed: te eva pañca skandhāḥ santatyā buddhaḥ bhavati
translated: Those very five aggregates, in continuity, become a Buddha.

analyzed: tasmāt āha aham eva sa rājā iti
translated: Therefore, he says, I myself was that king.

original: bhavatāṃ śāsane ātmana ekatvāt viśeṣo na syāt /
analyzed: bhavatām śāsane ātmanaḥ eka tvāt viśeṣaḥ na syāt
translated: In your doctrine, due to the oneness of the self, there would be no distinction.

analyzed: bhavān āha kṛta puṇyaḥ ubhayatra nandati iti
translated: You said, One who has done merit rejoices in both places.

original: sūtre bhagavān idaṃ vastu pratiṣidhyāhanāhaṃ vadāmi kaścidimān pañcaskandhān parityajya tān skandhānupādatta iti /
analyzed: sūtre bhagavān idam vastu pratiṣidhya āha na aham vadāmi kaścid imān pañca skandhān parityajya tān skandhān upādatte iti
translated: In the sutra, the Blessed One, having refuted this matter, said, I do not say that anyone abandons these five aggregates and takes up those aggregates.

analyzed: kintu tat pañca skandhānām santatyā bheda abhāvāt āha aubhayatna nandati iti
translated: But because there is no interruption in the continuity of those five aggregates, he said, One rejoices in both places.

analyzed: yat bhavān āha citta saṃkleśāt sattvāḥ saṃkliśyante iti
translated: As for what you said, Beings are defiled because of the defilement of mind,

analyzed: tatas na asti ātmā paramārthataḥ iti
translated: therefore there is no self in the ultimate sense.

analyzed: yadi asti ātmā
translated: If there were a self,

analyzed: citta abhinnaḥ syāt
translated: it would be undifferentiated from the mind.

analyzed: na ucyate sattva saṃkleśāt sattvāḥ saṃkliśyante iti
translated: It is not said, Beings are defiled because of the defilement of beings.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

original: na hi sambhavati tasya saṃkleśasamayaṃ sattva upādatta iti /
analyzed: na hi sambhavati tasya saṃkleśa samayam sattvaḥ upādatte iti
translated: For it is not possible that a being takes up defilement at the time of defilement.

original: kintu prajñaptyā hetupratyayānāṃ saṃkliṣṭatvāt āhasattvāḥ saṃkliśyanta iti /
analyzed: kintu prajñaptyā hetu pratyayānām saṃkliṣṭa tvāt āha sattvāḥ saṃkliśyante iti
translated: But rather, because the causes and conditions are defiled by designation, it is said, Beings are defiled.

analyzed: atas prajñaptyā asti ātmā
translated: Therefore, there is a self by designation,

analyzed: na paramārthataḥ
translated: not in the ultimate sense.

original: bhavatāṃ śāsane cocyate na pañcaskandhā evātmeti /
analyzed: bhavatām śāsane ca ucyate na pañca skandhāḥ eva ātmā iti
translated: And in your teaching, it is said that the five aggregates are not the self.

analyzed: tadā saḥ jātaḥ niruddhaḥ puṇya pāpaḥ iti evamādayaḥ doṣāḥ bhavanti
translated: Then there would be faults such as it being unborn, unceased, neither meritorious nor demeritorious, and so on.

original: vayantu vadāmaḥ pañcaskandhānāṃ kalāpaḥ prajñaptyā ātmeti /
analyzed: vayantu vadāmaḥ pañca skandhānām kalāpaḥ prajñaptyāḥ ātmā iti
translated: But we say that the collection of five aggregates is provisionally called the self.

original: imamātmānamupādāya asti janma asti nirodhaḥ puṇyapāpamityādi /
analyzed: imam ātmānam upādāya asti janma asti nirodhaḥ puṇya pāpam ityādi
translated: Relying on this self, there is birth, there is cessation, there is merit, there is demerit, and so on.

analyzed: na ca prajñapti sat na asti iti
translated: And a provisional existent is not nonexistent.

analyzed: vastu mātram na bhavati
translated: It is not merely a real entity.

analyzed: bhavatā pūrvam uktam tīrthikānām āśaya khaṇḍanāya bhagavān āha na asti ātmā iti
translated: You previously said that the Buddha spoke of no self in order to refute the intentions of the non-Buddhists.

original: abhūtasaṃjñayā bhavānevaṃ kalpayati na tathā bhagavadāśayaḥ /
analyzed: abhūta saṃjñayā bhavān evam kalpayati na tathā bhagavat āśayaḥ
translated: You imagine it to be so through a false conception, but the Buddha's intention is not like that.

original: vividhā ātmavādāḥ sarve duṣṭāḥ yathā bhavān bravītipañcaskandhān vihāya anyo'styātmeti tīrthikā manyanta iti /
analyzed: vividhāḥ ātma vādāḥ sarve duṣṭāḥ yathā bhavān bravīti pañca skandhān vihāya anyaḥ asti ātmā iti tīrthikāḥ manyante iti
translated: All the various self-theories are faulty, as you say. The non-Buddhists think that there is a self apart from the five aggregates.

analyzed: tathā bhavān api manyate
translated: You also think so.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: anityāḥ hi pañca skandhāḥ
translated: The five aggregates are impermanent.

analyzed: ātmā atu avaktavyaḥ yadi nityaḥ nityaḥ vā iti
translated: The self cannot be said to be either permanent or impermanent.

analyzed: saḥ uyam skandha vinirmuktaḥ eva
translated: It is apart from the aggregates.

analyzed: atha skandhasya santi trayaḥ bhedāḥ śīla samādhi prajñāḥ
translated: Now, there are three kinds of aggregates: morality, concentration, and wisdom.

analyzed: kuśala akuśala avyākṛtāḥ
translated: They are wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.

analyzed: kāmadhātu pratisaṃyukta rūpadhātu pratisaṃyukta ārūpyadhātu pratisaṃyuktāḥ iti evam vibhāgāḥ
translated: They are divided into those connected with the desire realm, those connected with the form realm, and those connected with the formless realm.

analyzed: ātmānaḥ tu tathā vibhaktāḥ na bhavanti
translated: But the self is not divided in this way.

analyzed: atas pañca skandhebhyaḥ nyaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is different from the five aggregates.

analyzed: ātmā ca pudgalaḥ
translated: And the self is the person.

analyzed: pañca skandhāḥ na pudgalaḥ
translated: The five aggregates are not the person.

analyzed: tadā tu ayam anyaḥ bhavati
translated: Then it would be different.

analyzed: skandhāḥ pañca
translated: There are five aggregates.

analyzed: ātmā atu ekaḥ
translated: The self is one.

analyzed: iti atas na ātmā skandhāḥ
translated: Therefore, the self is not the aggregates.

analyzed: asti ced ātmā
translated: If the self exists,

analyzed: saḥ ebhiḥ kāraṇaiḥ pañca skandhebhyaḥ nyaḥ syāt
translated: it would be different from the five aggregates for these reasons.

original: loke ca nāsti ko'pi dharma eka ityavaktavyaḥ /
analyzed: loke ca na asti kaḥ api dharmaḥ ekaḥ iti avaktavyaḥ
translated: And in the world, there is no single dharma that can be said to be inexpressible.

analyzed: atas na asti kaścid avaktavyaḥ dharmaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no inexpressible dharma at all.

original: pṛ yathā agnirindhanañca na vaktuṃ śakyata evaṃ vā nānā veti /
analyzed: yathā agniḥ indhanam ca na vaktum śakyate evam vā nānā vā iti
translated: Just as it cannot be said that fire and fuel are either the same or different,

analyzed: tathā ātmā api syāt
translated: so would the self be.

analyzed: u idam sandigdhasamam
translated: This is a doubtful parallel.

analyzed: kim agniḥ kim indhanam iti
translated: What is fire and what is fuel?

analyzed: yadi tejaḥ dhātuḥ agniḥ anye dhātavaḥ indhanam
translated: If the fire element is fire and the other elements are fuel,

analyzed: tadā agniḥ indhanāt pṛthak syāt
translated: then fire would be separate from fuel.

analyzed: yadi tejaḥ dhātuḥ eva indhanam
translated: If the fire element itself is fuel,

analyzed: katham ucyate na ekam iti
translated: how can it be said to be not one?

analyzed: yat indhanam saḥ eva tejaḥ dhātuḥ
translated: If fuel is that very fire element,

analyzed: tejaḥ dhātum vinā api dahet iti ubhayam ayuktam
translated: It is not reasonable that it would burn without the fire element.

analyzed: atas sandigdhasamam
translated: Therefore, it is doubtful and equal.

analyzed: yasya agniḥ indhanavān yathā ātmā rūpavān iti
translated: For one who says fire has fuel like the self has form,

analyzed: tasya satkāyadṛṣṭipātaḥ
translated: there is the fault of the view of the transitory collection.

analyzed: ātma bahu tvam ca syāt
translated: And there would be the plurality of selves.

analyzed: yathā kāṣṭha agniḥ anyaḥ gomaya agniḥ ca anyaḥ
translated: Just as the fire of wood is one, and the fire of cow dung is another,

analyzed: eva ātmā api
translated: so is the self.

analyzed: manuṣya skandheṣu anyaḥ ātmā
translated: The self is different in the aggregates of humans,

analyzed: deva skandheṣu anyaḥ ātmā iti idam ātma bahutvam
translated: and different in the aggregates of gods. This is the plurality of selves.

analyzed: yathā agniḥ indhanam ca triṣu adhvasu vartate
translated: Just as fire and fuel exist in the three times,

original: evamātmāpi pañcaskandhaiḥ saha triṣu adhvasu vartamānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: evam ātmā api pañca skandhaiḥ saha triṣu adhvasu vartamānam syāt
translated: in the same way, the self would exist in the three times along with the five aggregates.

analyzed: yathā ca agniḥ indhanan ca saṃskṛtam
translated: And just as fire and fuel are conditioned,

analyzed: ātmā api pañca skandhaiḥ saha saṃskṛtam syāt
translated: the self would also be conditioned along with the five aggregates.

original: yadyapi bhavānāhaagnirindhanena naiko na nānā iti /
analyzed: yadi api bhavān āha agniḥ indhanena na ekaḥ na nānā iti
translated: Even though you say fire is neither the same as nor different from fuel,

analyzed: tathā api cakṣuṣā paśyāmaḥ khalu nānā lakṣaṇe
translated: nevertheless, we see with our eyes that they have different characteristics.

analyzed: ātmā api pañca skandhāḥ ca anye syuḥ
translated: The self and the five aggregates would also be different.

analyzed: kiñca pañca skandhāḥ naśyanti
translated: Moreover, the five aggregates perish,

analyzed: ātmā tu na naśyati
translated: but the self does not perish.

analyzed: asmāt lokāt cyutaḥ paraloka utpadyate
translated: It passes away from this world and arises in the next world.

analyzed: ubhayatra nandi yukta tvāt
translated: Because it is associated with joy in both cases.

analyzed: yaḥ pañca skandhān anusṛtya sa vināśaḥ sa utpādaḥ ca
translated: He who, following the five aggregates, is perishable and has origination,

analyzed: sa pañca skandha samaḥ na ubhayatra nandikaḥ bhavati
translated: he is equal to the five aggregates and is not joyful in both cases.

original: bhavāṃstu abhūtasaṃjñayā imamātmānaṃ vikalpya keṣāṃ hitaṃ prāpayati /
analyzed: bhavān tu abhūta saṃjñayā imam ātmānam vikalpya keṣām hitam prāpayati
translated: But you, having imagined this self through the conception of the unreal, bring about the benefit of whom?

analyzed: viṣayeṣu na kaḥ api asti ṣaṣ vijñāna vijñeyaḥ
translated: There is no one cognizable by the six consciousnesses among the objects.

original: ṣaḍvijñānavijñeya iti bhavatokta ātmā na ṣaḍviṣayarūpo bhavati /
analyzed: ṣaṣ vijñāna vijñeyaḥ iti bhavatā uktaḥ ātmā na ṣaṣ viṣaya rūpaḥ bhavati
translated: The self spoken of by you as cognizable by the six consciousnesses is not of the nature of the six objects.

analyzed: yaḥ dvādaśa āyataneṣu a saṅgṛhītaḥ
translated: He who is not included among the twelve sense bases,

analyzed: na saḥ āyataneṣu bhavati
translated: he does not exist among the sense bases.

original: caturṣu satyeṣu asaṅgraprahītaśca na satyeṣu bhavati /
analyzed: caturṣu satyeṣu a saṅgra prahītaḥ ca na satyeṣu bhavati
translated: And he who is not included among the four truths does not exist among the truths.

analyzed: tasmāt asti ātmā iti yat vacanam sa mṛṣāvādaḥ
translated: Therefore, the statement that the self exists is false speech.

original: bhavatāṃ śāsana ucyate jñeyadharmā yaduta pañcadharmakośāḥatītā anāgatāḥ pratyutpannā asaṃskṛtā avaktavyā iti /
analyzed: bhavatām śāsane ucyate jñeya dharmāḥ yat uta pañca dharma kośāḥ atītāḥ anāgatāḥ pratyutpannāḥ asaṃskṛtāḥ avaktavyāḥ iti
translated: In your doctrine it is said that knowable dharmas are the five dharma-baskets: past, future, present, unconditioned, and inexpressible.

analyzed: ātmā pañcama dharma antargataḥ  tadā caturbhyaḥ dharmebhyaḥ nyaḥ
translated: The self is included among the five dharmas.🔽Then it is other than the four dharmas.

original: sa caturbhyo dharmebhyo'nya itīcchanti khalu bhavantaḥ /
analyzed: sa caturbhyaḥ dharmebhyaḥ nyaḥ iti icchanti khalu bhavantaḥ
translated: And they indeed wish that it is other than the four dharmas.

analyzed: ayam pañcamaḥ tu na sambhavati
translated: But this fifth [objection] is not possible.

analyzed: ātma astitva vādasya īdṛśāḥ doṣāḥ bhavanti
translated: These are the faults of the doctrine of the existence of the self.

analyzed: kim ātmā iti mithyā saṃjñā vikalpena
translated: [The faults are:] by the false conception and discrimination of 'self',

original: ato bhavatā pūrvamuktamtīrthikāḥ pañcaskandhān vihāya pṛthagātmā'stīti manyante /
analyzed: atas bhavatā pūrvam uktam tīrthikāḥ pañca skandhān vihāya pṛthak ātmā asti iti manyante
translated: Therefore, what you said before, that the non-Buddhists think the self exists separately from the five aggregates,

analyzed: vayantu na tathā iti
translated: but we do not do so like that.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: yat bhavān āha ātmā prajñapti mātram iti idam gāḍhataram cintanīyam iti
translated: What you said, that 'the self is merely a designation' should be thought about even more deeply,

analyzed: tat api ayuktam
translated: that is also not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: jinaśāsane hyucyate lokasatyavastu na pragāḍhaṃ cintanīyam iti /
analyzed: jina śāsane hi ucyate loka satya vastu na pragāḍham cintanīyam iti
translated: For in the Jina's teachings it is said that the things of worldly truth should not be thought about too deeply.

analyzed: yat bhavatā uktam mṛṣāvādinaḥ viparyaya darśinaḥ syuḥ iti
translated: What you said, that [we] would be liars and see things wrongly,

analyzed: idam api tathā eva
translated: that is also just the same.

original: yadavādīḥ sūtragatāni pāramārthikāni ityādi vacanaṃ na syāditi /
analyzed: yat avādīḥ sūtra gatāni pāramārthikāni ityādi vacanam na syāt iti
translated: What you said, that the statements in the sūtras would not exist, such as 'the ultimate', and so on,

analyzed: tat tathā prativaktavyam yathā parama arthaḥ jñāyeta
translated: that should be answered in such a way that the ultimate is known.

original: yadavocadbhavān lokoktāni sarvāṇi anusartavyāni yadvadanti īśvarādutpannāni na yutāni vastūni ityādi /
analyzed: yat avocat bhavān loka uktāni sarvāṇi anusartavyāni yat vat anti īśvarāt utpannāni na yutāni vastūni ityādi
translated: What you said, that all the worldly sayings should be followed, such as 'things are produced from Īśvara' and so on,

analyzed: na tat upādeyam
translated: that should not be accepted.

analyzed: yat hita karam paramārtha avilomakam tat upādeyam iti atonavadyam
translated: What is beneficial and not contrary to the highest truth should be accepted, therefore it is faultless.

analyzed: yat loka satyataḥ guṇa utpādakam hita karam ca
translated: What produces qualities from the perspective of worldly truth and is beneficial,

analyzed: īdṛśam sarvam upādeyam iti paścāt vakṣyate
translated: all such things should be accepted, this will be explained later.

analyzed: yat avādīḥ mṛṇmaya gavādi hanane na asti pāpam iti
translated: You said that there is no sin in killing a clay cow, etc.

analyzed: tat idānīm prativaktavyam
translated: That should now be refuted.

original: savijñānānāṃ skandhānāṃ santatyā samudācāre sati asti karma asti vipākaḥ /
analyzed: sa vijñānānām skandhānām santatyā samudācāre sati asti karma asti vipākaḥ
translated: When there is the occurrence of the aggregates with consciousness, there is karma and there is result.

analyzed: mṛṇmaya gavādiṣu tu na idam asti
translated: But in clay cows, etc., this does not exist.

original: tasmāt pañcaskandhānāṃ kalāpaḥ prajñaptyā ātmā ityākhyāyate /
analyzed: tasmāt pañca skandhānām kalāpaḥ prajñaptyai ātmā iti ākhyāyate
translated: Therefore, it should be known that the collection of the five aggregates is called the self conventionally,

analyzed: na vastu sattayā iti jñātavyam
translated: not by real existence.

analyzed: ātma astitva nāstitva vargaḥ pañcatriṃśaḥ
translated: Chapter 35: Existence and Non-existence of the Self.

analyzed: satya siddhi śāstre prathamaḥ prasthāna skandhaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: The first section of the treatise on establishing the truths is completed.

analyzed: atha duḥkha satya skandhaḥ
translated: Now, the section on the truth of suffering.

analyzed: duḥkha satya skandhe rūpa adhikāre
translated: In the section on the truth of suffering, in the chapter on form,

analyzed: rūpa lakṣaṇa vargaḥ
translated: The chapter on the characteristics of form.

analyzed: pṛ pūrvam avādīḥ satya siddhi śāstram pravakṣyāmi iti
translated: Previously you said, I will explain the treatise on establishing the truths.

analyzed: idānīm vaktavyam kim tat satyam iti

analyzed: atas catvāri mahābhūtāni dravya santi
translated: Therefore the four great elements substantially exist.

original: rūpādi bhautikaṃ rūpaṃ caturbhyo mahābhūtebhyaḥ samutpadyate /
analyzed: rūpa ādi bhautikam rūpam caturbhyaḥ mahābhūtebhyaḥ samutpadyate
translated: Material form, such as visible form, arises from the four great elements.

analyzed: na prajñapti san dharmam janayati
translated: A nominally existent dharma does not produce [a dharma].

original: khakkhaṭādinā ca catvāri mahābhūtāni nirucyante yat khakkhaṭaṃ kharagataṃ sā pṛthivīti /
analyzed: khakkhaṭa ādinā ca catvāri mahābhūtāni nirucyante yat khakkhaṭam khara gatam sā pṛthivī iti
translated: And the four great elements are defined by hardness, etc., as stated in the sutra: That which is hard and solid is earth.

analyzed: tasmāt khakkhaṭa ādīni dravya mahābhūtāni
translated: Therefore, hardness, etc. are the substantial great elements.

analyzed: kiñca sūtre dvābhyām ākārābhyām ucyate khakkhaṭam khara gatam
translated: Moreover, in the sutra, hardness and the place of hardness are stated in two aspects.

analyzed: snehaḥ sneha gatam ityādi
translated: Oiliness and the place of oiliness, etc.

original: ato jñāyate khakkhaṭaṃ vastudharmaḥ kharagataṃ prajñaptidharma iti /
analyzed: atas jñāyate khakkhaṭam vastu dharmaḥ khara gatam prajñapti dharmaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is known that hardness is the dharma of a substance, and the place of hardness is the dharma of a nominal [entity].

analyzed: evam anyāni api mahābhūtāni
translated: The same applies to the other great elements.

analyzed: tasmāt khakkhaṭa ādīni dravya mahābhūtāni
translated: Therefore, hardness, etc. are the substantial great elements.

analyzed: khara gata dharmaḥ tu vyavahārataḥ mahābhūtam
translated: But the dharma of the place of hardness is a great element from the perspective of conventional usage.

analyzed: atas asti dvidhā mahābhūtam dravya rūpam prajñapti rūpam iti
translated: Therefore, there are two kinds of great elements: substantial form and nominal form.

analyzed: kiñca uktam abhidharme saṃsthāna āyatanam pṛthivī
translated: Moreover, it is said in the Abhidharma that the sphere of form is earth.

analyzed: khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇaḥ pṛthivī dhātuḥ iti
translated: The earth element has the characteristic of hardness.

analyzed: tathā anyāni api mahābhūtāni
translated: The same applies to the other great elements.

original: sūtre cāha bhagavānyaccakṣuṣi māṃsa piṇḍe khakkhaṭaṃ kharagataṃ iyaṃ pṛthivī /🔽yat snehaḥ snehagataṃ imā āpaḥ /
analyzed: sūtre ca āha bhagavān yat cakṣuṣi māṃsa piṇḍe khakkhaṭam khara gatam iyam pṛthivī  yat snehaḥ sneha gatam imāḥ āpaḥ
translated: And in the sutra, the Blessed One said: That which is hard and solid in the lump of flesh in the eye is earth.🔽That which is moisture and moistness is water.

analyzed: yat ūṣma ūṣma gatam idam tejaḥ
translated: That which is heat and heat-related is fire.

analyzed: māṃsa piṇḍam pṛthivī iti
translated: The lump of flesh is earth.

original: asmin māṃsapiṇḍe bhagavānāha santi catvāri mahābhūtāni iti /
analyzed: asmin māṃsa piṇḍe bhagavān āha santi catvāri mahābhūtāni iti
translated: In this lump of flesh, the Blessed One said there are the four great elements.

analyzed: khakkhaṭa ādīni dravya mahābhūtāni
translated: The hard and other [elements] are the substantial great elements.

analyzed: tad saṃsthānāni prajñapti mahābhūtāni iti jñātavyam
translated: One should know that the forms composed of them are the nominal great elements.

analyzed: kiñca bhagavān na avocat
translated: Moreover, the Blessed One did not say that there is a basis for wind.

analyzed: atas jñāyate vāyuḥ dravya mahābhūtam iti
translated: Therefore, it is known that wind is a substantial great element.

original: yadi kaścit brūyāt catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñaptisantīti /
analyzed: yadi kaścid brūyāt catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñapti santi iti
translated: If someone were to say that the four great elements are nominally existent,

original: tadā mahābhūtalakṣaṇāni vinirbhaktāni syuḥ /🔽yadi kharagataṃ pṛthivīti āpaḥ kharagatā iti tā api pṛthivī syuḥ /
analyzed: tadā mahābhūta lakṣaṇāni vinirbhaktāni syuḥ  yadi khara gatam pṛthivī iti āpaḥ khara gatāḥ iti tāḥ api pṛthivī syuḥ
translated: then the characteristics of the great elements would be mixed up.🔽If that which is hard and solid is earth, and water is also hard and solid, then water would also be earth.

original: mṛtpiṇḍaḥ snehagata iti so'pi āpaḥ syāt /
analyzed: mṛd piṇḍaḥ sneha gataḥ iti saḥ upi āpaḥ syāt
translated: A lump of clay is moist and wet, so that too would be water.

analyzed: yathā jvara pīḍitasya kāyaḥ utkampyate
translated: Just as the body trembles when afflicted by fever,

analyzed: taptaḥ kāyaḥ eva tejaḥ syāt
translated: the heated body itself would be fire.

analyzed: tat na yujyate
translated: That is not reasonable.

original: ato na vaktuṃ śakyate kharagataṃ pṛthivī /
analyzed: atas na vaktum śakyate khara gatam pṛthivī
translated: Therefore, it cannot be said that hardness alone is the earth element.

analyzed: khakkhaṭa mātram pṛthivī dhātuḥ iti
translated: Hardness alone is the earth element.

analyzed: tathā anyāni mahābhūtāni api
translated: So it is with the other great elements.

analyzed: sahajāta tvāt catvāri mahābhūtāni a vinirbhaktāni
translated: The four great elements are inseparable because they are co-originated.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtre yatkiñcidrūpaṃ sarvaṃ tat caturmahābhūtakṛtamiti /🔽catvāri mahābhūtāni dravyasantīti vaktustānyavinirbhaktāni bhavanti /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre yat kiñcid rūpam sarvam tat catur mahābhūta kṛtam iti  catvāri mahābhūtāni dravya santi iti vaktuḥ tāni a vinirbhaktāni bhavanti
translated: As it is said in the sutra, Whatever form there is, all of it is made of the four great elements.🔽For one who says that the four great elements exist as substances, they must be inseparable.

original: catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñaptisantīti vaktustāni vinirbhaktāni syuḥ /
analyzed: catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñapti santi iti vaktuḥ tāni vinirbhaktāni syuḥ
translated: For one who says that the four great elements exist as designations, they would be separable.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is this?

analyzed: khara rūpa ādi āśrayāḥ sneha ādi āśrayebhyaḥ vinirbhaktāḥ
translated: Hard form and so on are separable from the bases of moisture and so on.

original: tathā ca sati cakṣurmāsapiṇḍe catvāri mahābhūtāni na syuḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca sati cakṣuḥ māsa piṇḍe catvāri mahābhūtāni na syuḥ
translated: If that were so, there would be no four great elements in the mass of the eye.

analyzed: tathā ca sūtra virodhaḥ
translated: And that contradicts the sutra.

original: sūtrasyāvirodhaṃ kāmayānasya bhavataḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni dravyāṇi bhavanti /
analyzed: sūtrasya avirodham kāmayānasya bhavataḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni dravyāṇi bhavanti
translated: One who wishes to avoid contradicting the sutra must say that the four great elements are substances.

analyzed: yat bhavatā pūrvam uktam tīrthikebhyaḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni avocat iti
translated: What you said earlier, that the Buddha taught the four great elements to the non-Buddhists,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is this?

original: sarve hi tīrthikā vadanti catvāri mahābhūtāni rūpādibhirekāni yadi vonakānīti /
analyzed: sarve hi tīrthikāḥ vadanti catvāri mahābhūtāni rūpa ādibhiḥ ekāni yadi vā ūnakāni iti
translated: For all non-Buddhists say that the four great elements are the same as form, etc., or different.

analyzed: vayantu vadāmaḥ spraṣṭavya āyatana eka deśaḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni iti
translated: But we say that one part of the tangible element is the four great elements.

analyzed: atonavadyam
translated: Therefore, it is faultless.

original: kiñca vayaṃ vadāmaḥ pratyakṣadṛṣṭāni khakkhaṭādīni caturmahābhūtāni na tu vaiśeṣikāṇāmiva tānyapratyakṣadṛṣṭānyapi /
analyzed: kiñca vayam vadāmaḥ pratyakṣa dṛṣṭāni khakkhaṭa ādīni catur mahābhūtāni na tu vaiśeṣikāṇām iva tāni a pratyakṣa dṛṣṭāni api
translated: Moreover, we say that solidity, etc., the four great elements, are directly perceived, not like the Vaisheshikas, who say they are not directly perceived.

analyzed: yat uktam bhavatā khakkhaṭam khara gatam iti
translated: What you said, that solidity is included in solidity,

analyzed: tatra asti dvidhā āśraya arthaḥ
translated: there is a twofold basis meaning.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtrerūpam rūpa adhikaraṇam iti
translated: As it is said in the sutra, form is based on form,

original: āha ca cittaṃ mahatāṃ dharmāṇāmāśraya iti /
analyzed: āha ca cittam mahatām dharmāṇām āśrayaḥ iti
translated: and it is said that the mind is the basis of great dharmas.

original: asminnartha uktam khakkhaṭameva svaragataṃ na punardhamāntaramiti /
analyzed: asmin arthe uktam khakkhaṭam eva svara gatam na punar dhama antaram iti
translated: In this meaning, it is said that solidity itself is included, not another dharma.

analyzed: tathā ca kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: And what is the fault in that?

original: laukikāḥ sarve śraddadhante yāvadaṣṭaguṇā āpa iti yadbhavato vacanaṃ tat vyavahārānuvartanamātrato vadanti na dravyamahābhūtā nuvartanataḥ
analyzed: laukikāḥ sarve śraddadhante yāvat aṣṭaguṇāḥ āpaḥ iti yat bhavataḥ vacanam tat vyavahāra anuvartana mātrataḥ vadanti na dravya mahābhūta anuvartanataḥ
translated: All worldly people believe up to the eight qualities of water. What you say, they say merely following worldly convention, not following the substantial great elements.

analyzed: kiñca uktam bhavatā upādāya dharmāḥ sarve prajñapti ātmakāḥ iti
translated: Moreover, it is said by you that all things that are dependent are of the nature of designation.

analyzed: na idam yujyate
translated: This is not reasonable.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: uktaṃ hi sūtreyadi vā ṣaṭ sparśāyatanāni yadi vā ṣaṭ sparśāyatanānyupādāya dharmā iti /
analyzed: uktam hi sūtre yadi vā ṣaḍ sparśāyatanāni yadi vā ṣaḍ sparśāyatanāni upādāya dharmāḥ iti
translated: For it is said in the sutra: Whether it is the six sense bases or the dharmas based on the six sense bases.

analyzed: kaścid bhikṣuḥ bhagavantam pṛcchati ka tat cakṣuḥ iti
translated: A certain monk asked the Blessed One: Is that eye?

original: bhagavān pratyāhacakṣurbhikṣo catvāri mahāmūtānyupādāya rūpaprasāda iti /
analyzed: bhagavān pratyāha cakṣuḥ bhikṣo catvāri mahā mūtāni upādāya rūpa prasādaḥ iti
translated: The Blessed One replied: The eye, O monk, is based on the four great elements, and is a subtle form.

analyzed: evam daśa āyatanāni api
translated: Thus it is with the ten sense bases.

analyzed: yat tu sa āśrayam sa adhiṣṭhānakam iti
translated: But what is based on something, what has a basis,

analyzed: na tathā vadāmaḥ
translated: we do not say that.

original: dharme dharmo vartata iti mātraṃ vadāmaḥ /
analyzed: dharme dharmaḥ vartate iti mātram vadāmaḥ
translated: We simply say that the dharma exists in the dharma.

original: yadbhavānāhakhakkhaṭādayaḥ kimarthā bhavantīti kevalaṃ mahābhūtārthā iti bhavanti iti prāpyate iti /
analyzed: yat bhavān āha khakkhaṭa ādayaḥ kimarthāḥ bhavanti iti kevalam mahābhūta arthāḥ iti bhavanti iti prāpyate iti
translated: What you say, that hardness and so on have no purpose, that they are simply the purpose of the great elements, is obtained.

original: khakkhaṭādayaḥ sārthakā yaduta khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇaṃ sandhatta iti /🔽ablakṣaṇaṃ snehayatīti /🔽tejolakṣaṇaṃ paripācayatīti /
analyzed: khakkhaṭa ādayaḥ sārthakāḥ yat uta khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam sandhatte iti  ap lakṣaṇam snehayati iti  tejaḥ lakṣaṇam paripācayati iti
translated: Hardness and so on have a purpose, namely: the characteristic of hardness supports,🔽the characteristic of fluidity moistens,🔽the characteristic of heat ripens,

analyzed: vāyu lakṣaṇam abhinirvartayati iti
translated: and the characteristic of wind causes to expand.

analyzed: atas catvāri mahābhūtāni dravyāṇi santi
translated: Therefore, the four great elements are real substances.

analyzed: catur mahābhūta dravya sattā vargaḥ ekonacatvāriṃśaḥ
translated: The thirty-ninth chapter on the reality of the four great elements.

analyzed: tad a prāmāṇa vargaḥ
translated: The chapter on the unreality of that.

analyzed: atra pratibrūmaḥ
translated: Here we reply.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñapti mātrāṇi
translated: The four great elements are mere designations.

analyzed: yadi api uktam bhavatā abhidharmaḥ uktaṃkhakkhaṭa lakṣaṇaḥ pṛthivī dhātuḥ
translated: Although you say that the Abhidharma says that the earth element has the characteristic of hardness,

analyzed: ityādi
translated: and so on.

analyzed: na tat yujyate
translated: That is not reasonable.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: bhagavān hi svayamāhakhakkhaṭaḥ kharagataśca pṛthivī iti /
analyzed: bhagavān hi svayam āha khakkhaṭaḥ khara gataḥ ca pṛthivī iti
translated: For the Blessed One himself said, Hardness and the abode of hardness are earth.

analyzed: na khakkhaṭa mātram āha
translated: He does not say mere hardness.

analyzed: atas na ayam samyak hetuḥ
translated: Therefore, this is not a correct reason.

original: rūpādikaṃ caturbhyo mahābhūtebhyaḥ samutpadyata iti bhavaduktaṃ na yujyate /
analyzed: rūpa ādikam caturbhyaḥ mahābhūtebhyaḥ samutpadyate iti bhavat uktam na yujyate
translated: And what you say, that form and so on arise from the four great elements, is not reasonable.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: rūpa ādiḥ karma kleśa anna pāna maithuna rāga ādibhyaḥ samutpadyate
translated: Form and so on arise from karma, afflictions, food, drink, sexual desire, and so on.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre cakṣuḥ kim upādāya bhavati
translated: As it is said in the sutra, What is the eye based on?

analyzed: karma upādāya bhavati
translated: It is based on karma.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus it is said.

analyzed: kiñca āha sukha asaṅga samudayāt rūpa samudayaḥ iti
translated: And it is also said, The arising of form is from the arising of pleasure and attachment.

original: yathā cānando bhikṣuṇīśikṣaṇāya bhaginīmāhaayaṃ kāyaḥ āhārasambhūtaḥ tṛṣṇāsambhūto mānasambhūto maithunasambhūta iti /
analyzed: yathā ca ānandaḥ bhikṣuṇī śikṣaṇāya bhaginīm āha ayam kāyaḥ āhāra sambhūtaḥ tṛṣṇā sambhūtaḥ māna sambhūtaḥ maithuna sambhūtaḥ iti
translated: And as the monk Ānanda said to his sister for the sake of instructing the nun: This body is born from food, born from craving, born from the mind, born from sexual intercourse.

original: ato jñāyate rūpādi rna caturmahābhūtasambhūt iti /
analyzed: atas jñāyate rūpa ādi rna catur mahābhūta sambhūt iti
translated: Therefore, it is known that form, etc. are not born from the four great elements.

analyzed: yadi api rūpa ādi karma sambhūtam
translated: Even though form, etc. are born from karma,

original: tathāpi catvāri mahābhūtāni ca aṃśena hetavaḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: tathā api catvāri mahābhūtāni ca aṃśena hetavaḥ syuḥ
translated: still the four great elements would be causes in part.

analyzed: yathā karma vaśāt vrīhiḥ bhavati
translated: Just as rice comes to be by the power of karma,

analyzed: sa brīhiḥ bīja ādi apekṣya ca prādurbhavati
translated: and that rice appears in dependence on the seed, etc.

original: tathā cakṣurādīnāṃ karmasambhūtatve'pi catvāri mahābhūtāni aṃśato hetavo bhavanti /
analyzed: tathā cakṣuḥ ādīnām karma sambhūta tve pi catvāri mahābhūtāni aṃśataḥ hetavaḥ bhavanti
translated: In the same way, even though the eye, etc. are born from karma, the four great elements become causes in part.

original: u kadācit kiñcidvastu vināpi hetupratyayān utpadyate /
analyzed: u kadācid kiñcid vastu vinā api hetu pratyayān utpadyate
translated: Sometimes a thing arises even without causes and conditions.

original: yathā kalpāvasāne kalpādau ca mahatī vṛṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: yathā kalpa avasāne kalpa ādau ca mahatī vṛṣṭiḥ
translated: For example, at the end of a kalpa and at the beginning of a kalpa, there is a great rain.

analyzed: tāḥ āpaḥ kasmāt sambhavanti
translated: From what do those waters arise?

analyzed: devānām abhīpsitam anusmaraṇa mātrāt labhyeta
translated: It would be obtained merely by the gods' desire and recollection.

analyzed: yathā dhyāna niṣaṇṇasya bhadantasya ca abhīpsitam chandam anuvartate
translated: Just as the desire of the venerable one seated in meditation conforms to his wish.

analyzed: asya ke pratyayāḥ
translated: What are the conditions for that?

analyzed: nanu karma mātram
translated: Isn't it just karma?

original: yathā ca rūpasantānaḥ vyucchidya punaḥ pratisandhīyate /
analyzed: yathā ca rūpa santānaḥ vyucchidya punar pratisandhīyate
translated: And just as the continuum of form is cut off and then reconnected,

analyzed: yaḥ rūpadhātau upapadya punar rūpadhātau upapadyate
translated: when one who has been reborn in the formless realm is reborn again in the form realm.

analyzed: rūpasya asya kim mūlam
translated: What is the basis of this form?

original: pṛ kasmāt kiñcit karmamātrādutpadyate kiñcittu bāhyapratyayamapekṣyotpadyate /
analyzed: kasmāt kiñcid karma mātrāt utpadyate kiñcid tu bāhya pratyayam apekṣya utpadyate
translated: Why does something arise from mere karma, while something else arises depending on external conditions?

analyzed: u yaḥ sattvaḥ uvara karma balaḥ bhavati
translated: That being who has weak karma and power

analyzed: sa bīja sāmagrī sāhāyyataḥ sādhayati
translated: accomplishes it with the help of a collection of seeds.

original: utkaṭakarmabalastu na bāhyapratyayamapekṣate tathā dharmā api syuḥ /
analyzed: utkaṭa karma balaḥ tu na bāhya pratyayam apekṣate tathā dharmāḥ api syuḥ
translated: But one with strong karma and power does not depend on external conditions. Dharmas would also be like that.

analyzed: kecid sakarmakāḥ
translated: Some have karma,

analyzed: kecid sadharmakāḥ
translated: some have dharmas.

analyzed: keṣāñcid upapatti āyatanam karma bala mātrāt labhyate
translated: For some, the basis for rebirth is obtained by the power of karma alone,

analyzed: na bāhya pratyayam apekṣya
translated: not depending on external conditions.

original: hetupratyayāpekṣī vadet bījamaṅkurādīnāṃ heturiti /🔽kasmāducyate khakkhaṭādimupādāya rūpādirutpadyate /
analyzed: hetu pratyaya apekṣī vadet bījam aṅkura ādīnām hetuḥ iti  kasmāt ucyate khakkhaṭa ādim upādāya rūpa ādiḥ utpadyate
translated: One who depends on causes and conditions would say that the seed is the cause of the sprout and so on.🔽Why is it said that form and so on arise from hardness and so on?

original: kenārthena khakkhaṭādito rūpādirutpadyate na rūpāditaḥ khakkhaṭādiḥ /
analyzed: kena arthena khakkhaṭa āditaḥ rūpa ādiḥ utpadyate na rūpa āditaḥ khakkhaṭa ādiḥ
translated: In what sense does form and so on arise from hardness and so on, and not hardness and so on from form and so on?

analyzed: tayoḥ ca sahajāta tvāt katham ucyate khakkhaṭa ādim upādāya rūpa ādiḥ bhavati
translated: And because they are born together, how can it be said that form, etc. arise from hardness, etc.?

analyzed: na rūpa ādim upādāya khakkhaṭa ādiḥ iti
translated: But not that hardness, etc. arise from form, etc.

analyzed: nahi eka kālīna ṛyoḥ dharmayoḥ anyonya hetu tvam bhavati
translated: For two things that exist at the same time cannot be the mutual cause of each other.

analyzed: yathā śṛṅga dvayam yugapad jāyamānam
translated: Like the two horns that are born simultaneously.

original: na vaktuṃ śakyaṃ vāmadakṣiṇe hetū iti /
analyzed: na vaktum śakyam vāma dakṣiṇe hetū iti
translated: It cannot be said that one is the cause of the other.

original: pṛ yathā pradīpaprakāśayorekakālikayorapi pradīpamupādāya prakāśa ityucyate /
analyzed: yathā pradīpa prakāśayoḥ eka kālikayoḥ api pradīpam upādāya prakāśaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Just as it is said that light is in dependence on the lamp, even though light and the lamp exist at the same time.

analyzed: na prakāśam upādāya pradīpaḥ iti
translated: But not that the lamp is in dependence on the light.

analyzed: tathā idam api
translated: This is also like that.

analyzed: pradīpaḥ na prakāśāt anyaḥ
translated: The lamp is not different from the light.

original: pradīpo hi rūpaṃ prakāśa iti dharmadvayasamavāyātmakaḥ /
analyzed: pradīpaḥ hi rūpam prakāśaḥ iti dharma dvaya samavāya ātmakaḥ
translated: For the lamp is the essence of the combination of two dharmas: form and light.

original: rūpameva prakāśa iti na pradīpaḥ pṛthagbhavati /
analyzed: rūpam eva prakāśaḥ iti na pradīpaḥ pṛthak bhavati
translated: Light is just form, so the lamp does not exist separately.

analyzed: evam asya dṛṣṭāntasya tathyam na cintitavān asi
translated: You have not considered the truth of this example.

original: pṛ prakāśaḥ pradipādanyatra gacchatīti anyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: pṛ prakāśaḥ pradipād anyatra gacchati iti anyaḥ syāt
translated: If the light goes to something other than the lamp, it would be different.

analyzed: u na anyatra gacchati
translated: It does not go to something other.

analyzed: idam prakāśa rūpam pradīpaḥ eva pratyakṣam upalabhyate
translated: This light-form is directly perceived to be in the lamp itself.

analyzed: yadi anyatra gacchati
translated: If it went to something else,

analyzed: pradīpam vihāya api upalabhyeta
translated: It would be perceived even when separated from the lamp.

analyzed: na tu upalabhyate vastutas
translated: But in reality it is not perceived.

analyzed: tat rūpam na pradīpāt anyat iti jñātavyam
translated: Therefore, it should be known that that form is not different from the lamp.

analyzed: yugapad jāyamānayoḥ api dharmayoḥ hetu phala bhāvaḥ asti
translated: Even for two phenomena arising simultaneously, there is a cause-effect relationship.

original: yathā sapratidhe vijñānasya cakṣūrūpaṃ hetupratyayo bhavati /
analyzed: yathā sapratidhe vijñānasya cakṣuḥ rūpam hetu pratyayaḥ bhavati
translated: For example, form is a cause and condition for consciousness with resistance,

analyzed: na tu cakṣuḥ rūpasya vijñānam
translated: but consciousness is not for form.

analyzed: u na yujyate
translated: This is not tenable.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ vijñānasya pūrvacittam hetuḥ cakṣuḥ rūpam pratyayaḥ
translated: For eye-consciousness, a previous mind is the cause, and form is the condition.

original: pūrvaniruddhaṃ cittaṃ hetuḥ iti kathaṃ yugapajjāyamānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: pūrva niruddham cittam hetuḥ iti katham yugapad jāyamānam bhavati
translated: How can a previously ceased mind be the cause, when it arises simultaneously?

original: yo dharmo yaṃ hetumanuvartyotpadyate sa tasya hetuḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ dharmaḥ yam hetum anuvartya utpadyate sa tasya hetuḥ
translated: A phenomenon that arises depending on a certain cause is the effect of that cause.

original: yaccittaṃ yadindriyāṇyupādāya bhavati sa tadupādāya dharmaḥ /
analyzed: yat cittam yat indriyāṇi upādāya bhavati sa tat upādāya dharmaḥ
translated: A mind that arises in dependence on the faculties is a phenomenon that arises in dependence on them.

analyzed: atha catvāri mahābhūtāni eva na rūpa karāṇi
translated: Now, if the four great elements alone do not produce form,

analyzed: sarūpa hetu sambhūta tvāt
translated: because they arise from a cause that produces form.

analyzed: pratyakṣam upalabhāmaḥ khalu loke vastūni sarūpa hetoḥ jāyamānāni
translated: We directly perceive in the world things arising from a cause that produces form.

analyzed: yathā sāleḥ śāliḥ bhavati
translated: For example, rice arises from rice,

analyzed: yavāt yavaḥ
translated: barley from barley.

analyzed: evam pṛthivītaḥ pṛthivī bhavati nābādayaḥ
translated: In the same way, earth arises from earth, not from water and so on.

analyzed: evam rūpāt rūpam bhavati iti evamādi
translated: In the same way, form arises from form, and so on.

original: pṛ dṛśyate sa kiñcidvastu asarūpahetorjāyata iti /
analyzed: dṛśyate sa kiñcid vastu asarūpa hetoḥ jāyate iti
translated: Is it seen that a certain thing arises from a cause that is not similar to it?

analyzed: yathā vyākīrṇa go purīṣa kūṭe kṛmiḥ jāyate
translated: For example, a worm is born from a heap of scattered cow dung,

analyzed: śṛṅga kūṭe tṛṇam prarohati
translated: grass grows from a heap of horns.

original: u na vayaṃ vadāmaḥ asarūpahetorna jāyata iti /
analyzed: na vayam vadāmaḥ a sarūpa hetoḥ na jāyate iti
translated: We do not say that it does not arise from a cause that is not similar to it.

original: kintu sarūpahetau ca sati jāyata iti vadāmaḥ /🔽tasmāducyate rūpādibhyo rūpādayo jāyante na caturmahābhūtebhya eva jāyanta iti /
analyzed: kintu sarūpa hetau ca sati jāyate iti vadāmaḥ  tasmāt ucyate rūpa ādibhyaḥ rūpa ādayaḥ jāyante na catur mahābhūtebhyaḥ eva jāyante iti
translated: But we say that it arises when there is a cause that is similar to it.🔽Therefore it is said that form and so on arise from form and so on, and not only from the four great elements.

original: ato nābadhāraṇaṃ bhavati rūpādayaścaturmahābhūtebhya eva jāyanta iti /
analyzed: atas na ap dhāraṇam bhavati rūpa ādayaḥ catur mahābhūtebhyaḥ eva jāyante iti
translated: Therefore it is not determined that form and so on arise only from the four great elements.

original: khakkhaṭādinā catvāri mahābhūtāni nirūpyanta iti yadavocadbhavān /
analyzed: khakkhaṭa ādinā catvāri mahābhūtāni nirūpyante iti yat avocat bhavān
translated: As for what you said that the four great elements are determined by hardness and so on,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: niyataiḥ khakkhāṭādilakṣaṇaiḥ catvāraḥ saṅghātā vibhaktavyāḥ /🔽saukumāryādestu aniyataḥ kadācit khakkhaṭabahule saṅghāte vartate /
analyzed: niyataiḥ khakkhāṭa ādi lakṣaṇaiḥ catvāraḥ saṅghātāḥ vibhaktavyāḥ  saukumārya ādeḥ tu aniyataḥ kadācid khakkhaṭa bahule saṅghāte vartate
translated: The four aggregates should be distinguished by the definite characteristics of hardness and so on.🔽But softness and so on are indefinite. Sometimes it exists in an aggregate with much hardness,

analyzed: kadācid sneha bahule saṅghāte vartate
translated: sometimes it exists in an aggregate with much moisture.

analyzed: atas na anena saukumārya ādinā saṅghātāḥ vibhaktavyāḥ
translated: Therefore, the aggregates should not be distinguished by this softness, etc.

analyzed: tathā anyaiḥ api
translated: And so by others as well.

analyzed: khakkhaṭa ādīnām sparśa viśeṣāḥ saukumārya ādayaḥ ucyante
translated: Softness, etc. are said to be the specific touches of hardness, etc.

analyzed: kim iti
translated: What is the reason?

analyzed: yadi snehena utpatti svabhāvena api su kumāra sūkṣma ślakṣṇāni bhavanti
translated: If they are soft, subtle, and smooth by the nature of moisture,

analyzed: khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇa bahula tvāt khakkhaṭam kharam audārikam karkaśam iti evamādi bhavati
translated: they become hard, rough, and coarse due to the predominance of the characteristic of hardness.

analyzed: atas khakkhaṭa ādi mātreṇa catvāraḥ saṅghātāḥ vibhajyante
translated: Therefore, the four aggregates are distinguished by hardness alone.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtrekhakkhaṭā digatānīti caturṇāṃ mahābhūtānāṃ vibhāgā nirdiśyanta iti /
analyzed: yathoktam sūtrekhakkhaṭāḥ di gatāni iti caturṇām mahābhūtānām vibhāgāḥ nirdiśyante iti
translated: As it is said in the sutra, the distinctions of the four great elements are indicated by the words hardness, etc.

original: ato jñāyate khakkhaṭagatadharmaḥ pṛthivīdhātuḥ na tu khakkhaṭamātralakṣaṇa iti /
analyzed: atas jñāyate khakkhaṭa gata dharmaḥ pṛthivī dhātuḥ na tu khakkhaṭa mātra lakṣaṇaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is known that the earth element is the dharma of the category of hardness, not just the characteristic of hardness.

analyzed: tasmāt khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam pṛthivī prasādhana hetuḥ iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, the characteristic of hardness is said to be the cause of establishing the earth.

analyzed: pṛthivī prasādhane ca khakkhaṭa tvam pradhāna hetuḥ
translated: And in establishing the earth, hardness is the primary cause.

analyzed: atas pṛthakkṛtya ucyate
translated: Therefore, it is spoken of separately.

analyzed: tathā anyāni lakṣaṇāni api vaktavyāni
translated: So should the other characteristics also be spoken of.

original: saṃjñākriyāyai yat kiñcan khakkhaṭaṃ kharagataṃ sarvaṃ tat pṛthividhātuḥ /
analyzed: saṃjñā kriyāyai yat kiñcan khakkhaṭam khara gatam sarvam tat pṛthivi dhātuḥ
translated: Whatever is hard and has the nature of hardness is the earth element for the purpose of designation and action.

analyzed: kecid vadanti kevalam khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam pṛthivī dhātuḥ iti
translated: Some say that the earth element has only the characteristic of hardness.

analyzed: tad pratyākhyānāya bhagavān āha khakkhaṭam khara gatam pṛthivī dhātuḥ iti
translated: To refute that, the Blessed One said, The earth element is what is hard and has the nature of hardness.

analyzed: anyat api evam
translated: Other things are also like this.

analyzed: khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇa saṅghāte khakkhaṭasya bāhulyāt dvidhā asti vyavahāraḥ
translated: In the aggregate characterized by hardness, hardness is predominant, so there are two kinds of usage.

analyzed: sarveṣu saṅghāteṣu khakkhaṭa ādi sparśāḥ santi
translated: In all aggregates, the tactile sensations of hardness, etc. exist.

original: yat khakkhaṭaṃ kharagataṃ sa pṛthivīdhātuḥ /🔽yat snigdhaṃ snigdhagataṃ sa āpodhātuḥ /
analyzed: yat khakkhaṭam khara gatam sa pṛthivī dhātuḥ  yat snigdham snigdha gatam saḥ āpaḥ dhātuḥ
translated: What is hard and has the nature of hardness is the earth element.🔽What is moist and has the nature of moisture is the water element.

analyzed: yat uṣṇam uṣṇa gatam sa tejaḥ dhātuḥ
translated: What is hot and has the nature of heat is the fire element.

analyzed: khakkhaṭam pṛthivī prasādhanasya pradhāna hetuḥ iti atas tatra pṛthivī iti nāma
translated: Hardness is the primary cause for the manifestation of earth, therefore it is named earth there.

original: prajñaptitaḥ prasiddhe hetau prajñaptitaḥ saṃjñā bhavati yathā vadantipaśyāmyahaṃ vṛkṣasya chettāraṃ puruṣamiti /
analyzed: prajñaptitaḥ prasiddhe hetau prajñaptitaḥ saṃjñā bhavati yathā vadanti paśyāmi aham vṛkṣasya chettāram puruṣam iti
translated: When the cause is well-known through designation, the name arises through designation, just as they say, I see the man who cuts down the tree.

analyzed: dvābhyām ākārābhyām iti yat avocaḥ
translated: What you said about the two aspects,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: yadi vyavahāra bhaṅgīm anusṛtya tattvam bhavati
translated: If reality is in accordance with the mode of expression,

analyzed: tadā dvādaśa āyatana ādīni tattvāni na syuḥ
translated: then the twelve sense bases and so on would not be realities.

analyzed: atas cakṣuḥ pratītya rūpam ca utpadyate cakṣuḥ vijñānam iti idam atattvam syāt
translated: And therefore, Dependent on the eye and forms, eye-consciousness arises would be unreal,

analyzed: vyavahāra bhaṅgayā abhāvāt
translated: because of the absence of expression.

analyzed: idam ca mithyā śāstram syāt
translated: And this would be a false treatise.

original: kiñca tathāgate tejovatī samādhimupasampanne tatkāyā dvividhāni jvālārūpāṇi niścaranti /
analyzed: kiñca tathāgate tejovatī samādhim upasampanne tad kāyāḥ dvividhāni jvālā rūpāṇi niścaranti
translated: Moreover, when the Tathāgata enters the fiery samādhi, two kinds of flame forms emerge from his body.

analyzed: tatra kimitti tejaḥ dhātuḥ na bhavati
translated: There, how could that not be the fire element?

analyzed: tejaḥ sidhyati na tu ūṣma mātra lakṣaṇataḥ
translated: Fire is established from form and so on, not merely from the characteristic of heat.

analyzed: kiñca āha bhagavān kāyaḥ iyam karaṇḍakaḥ iti
translated: Moreover, the Blessed One said, This body is a basket.

analyzed: tatra nakha loma keśa ādayaḥ samṛddhāḥ santi
translated: There, nails, hair, body hair, and so on are abundant.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre santi kāye ismin nakha loma keśa ādayaḥ iti
translated: As it is said in the sūtra, There are nails, hair, body hair, and so on in this body.

analyzed: atas nakha loma keśa ādayaḥ pṛthivī dhātuḥ
translated: Therefore, nails, hair, body hair, and so on are the earth element.

analyzed: na hi dhatuvādaḥ asti iti dravya dharmaḥ bhavati
translated: For there is no such thing as the doctrine of elements, so it becomes a property of substance.

original: uktañcabīja sūtre yataḥ pṛthivīdhātuḥ syāt nābdhātuḥ na bījāni vṛddhiṃ virūḍhiṃ vipulatā māpadyanta iti /
analyzed: uktañcabīja sūtre yatas pṛthivī dhātuḥ syāt na ap dhātuḥ na bījāni vṛddhim virūḍhim vipula tā mā āpadyante iti
translated: And it is said in the Bīja Sūtra: “From where there is the earth element, but not the water element, the seeds do not attain growth, increase, and abundance.”

original: tatra kiṃ pṛthivīdhātuḥ yaduta prajñaptitaḥ kṣetram /
analyzed: tatra kim pṛthivī dhātuḥ yat uta prajñaptitaḥ kṣetram
translated: There, what is the earth element? Namely, the field conventionally,

analyzed: na tu khakkhaṭa mātra lakṣaṇam
translated: but not just the characteristic of hardness.

analyzed: āpaḥ api prajñaptitaḥ na sneha mātra lakṣaṇam
translated: Water is also conventionally, not just the characteristic of moisture.

original: ekasya dharmasya dravyatvaṃ prajñaptitvamiti dviprakāro'pi nopalabhyate /
analyzed: ekasya dharmasya dravya tvam prajñapti tvam iti dvi prakāraḥ api nā upalabhyate
translated: The substantiality and conventionality of a single dharma are not found in either of the two ways.

analyzed: kasmāt rūpa ādīni dravyāṇi
translated: Why? The substances such as form,

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādīni prajñaptitaḥ santi
translated: the eyes, etc. are conventionally existent,

original: mahābhūtāni tu dravyataśca prajñaptitaśca santīdaṃ mithyāśāstram /
analyzed: mahābhūtāni tu dravyataḥ ca prajñaptitaḥ ca santi idam mithyāśāstram
translated: but the great elements exist both substantially and conventionally. This is a false treatise.

analyzed: ṣaṣ dhātu sūtre ca bhagavān āha keśa loma nakha ādīni pṛthivī dhātuḥ iti
translated: And in the Ṣaḍdhātu Sūtra, the Blessed One said: “The hair, nails, etc. are the earth element.”

original: hastipadopamasūtre coktamkeśā lomā nakhā ityādīni ayamucyate pṛthivīdhāturiti /
analyzed: hastipadopama sūtre ca uktam keśāḥ lomā nakhāḥ ityādīni ayam ucyate pṛthivī dhātuḥ iti
translated: And in the Hastīpradakṣiṇa Sūtra, it is said: “The hair, body hair, nails, etc. are called the earth element.”

analyzed: kena arthena dhātuḥ dravyam na prajñaptiḥ iti ucyate
translated: By what meaning is the element said to be a substance and not a convention?

analyzed: na ca saḥ ṛthaḥ sūtra ārūḍhaḥ
translated: And that meaning is not found in the sūtras.

original: yadavādīḥ bhagavānāhayaccakṣurmāsapiṇḍe khakkhaṭaṃ kharagataṃ iyaṃ pṛthivī ityādi /
analyzed: yat avādīḥ bhagavān āha yat cakṣuḥ māsa piṇḍe khakkhaṭam khara gatam iyam pṛthivī ityādi
translated: You said: The Blessed One said, What is hard and solid in the ball of flesh of the eye is the earth element, etc.

original: vacanenānena bhagavān pradarśayati pañcendriyāṇi catvāri mahābhūtānyupādāya bhavanti iti /
analyzed: vacanena anena bhagavān pradarśayati pañca indriyāṇi catvāri mahābhūtāni upādāya bhavanti iti
translated: By this statement, the Blessed One shows that the five sense faculties arise based on the four great elements.

analyzed: kecid vadanti ahaṅkāra sambhūtam indriyam iti
translated: Some say the sense faculties arise from egoism.

analyzed: kecid vadanti mahābhūta vyatiriktam indriyam asti iti
translated: Some say the sense faculties exist separately from the great elements.

original: kecidvadanti indriyāṇi nānāsvabhāvajāni yaduta pṛthivīmahābhūtāt sambhūtaṃ ghrāṇamityādi /
analyzed: kecid vadanti indriyāṇi nānā svabhāva jāni yat uta pṛthivī mahābhūtāt sambhūtam ghrāṇam ityādi
translated: Some say the sense faculties have different natures, such as the nose faculty arises from the earth great element, etc.

analyzed: tad pratyākhyānāya bhagavān āha cakṣuḥ ādi indriyāṇi catur mahābhūta samavāya ātmakāni śūnyāni avastūni iti
translated: To refute that, the Blessed One said the eye sense faculty, etc. are empty, non-entities, having the nature of a combination of the four great elements.

analyzed: vikalpaḥ prajñapteḥ hetum pratyayam sādhayati
translated: Conceptualization establishes the cause and condition for designation.

analyzed: sā prajñaptiḥ api na asti
translated: That designation also does not exist.

original: asmin māṃsapiṇḍe santi catvāro bhāgāḥ khakkhaṭaṃ kharagatamityādi vacanena bhagavān pradarśayati sarvapadārthāḥ caturmahābhūtasambhūtā iti /
analyzed: asmin māṃsa piṇḍe santi catvāraḥ bhāgāḥ khakkhaṭam khara gatam ityādi vacanena bhagavān pradarśayati sarva padārthāḥ catur mahābhūta sambhūtāḥ iti
translated: By the statement In this ball of flesh there are four parts: what is hard and solid, etc., the Blessed One shows that all things arise from the four great elements.

analyzed: bhagavān na avocat dvayoḥ āśrayaḥ asti iti atas dravya mahābhūtam vāyuḥ iti yat avocaḥ
translated: The Blessed One did not say that both have a basis, so your statement that air is a substantial great element is not correct.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: vāyoḥ laghu tvam viśiṣṭam lakṣaṇam na laghu gata dharmaḥ
translated: Lightness is a distinctive characteristic of air, not a quality of lightness.

original: pṛthivyādīnāṃ khakkhaṭagatadharmādayo viśiṣṭāḥ vāyostu na tathā /
analyzed: pṛthivī ādīnām khakkhaṭa gata dharma ādayaḥ viśiṣṭāḥ vāyoḥ tu na tathā
translated: For earth and others, hardness and other qualities are distinctive, but for air it is not so.

analyzed: laghu gata dharmaḥ ca alpaḥ iti na avocat
translated: And the quality of lightness is small, so it was not said.

original: yadavādīḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñaptisantīti vaktuḥ tanmahābhūtalakṣaṇāni vinirbhaktāni syuriti /
analyzed: yat avādīḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñapti santi iti vaktuḥ tad mahābhūta lakṣaṇāni vinirbhaktāni syuḥ iti
translated: You said that one who speaks of the four great elements as nominally existent would have to distinguish their characteristics as great elements.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

original: yat khakkhaṭaṃ kharagataṃ caturmahābhūtasambhūtaṃ sa pṛthivīdhātuḥ /
analyzed: yat khakkhaṭam khara gatam catur mahābhūta sambhūtam sa pṛthivī dhātuḥ
translated: That which is hard and has the nature of hardness, and is produced from the four great elements, that is the earth element.

analyzed: na tu ucyate nyat vastu lakṣaṇasya āśrayaḥ iti
translated: But it is not said that another substance is the basis of the characteristic.

original: yo dharmo lakṣaṇādanya na sa āśrayaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ dharmaḥ lakṣaṇāt anyaḥ na saḥ āśrayaḥ
translated: A dharma that is other than the characteristic is not its basis.

analyzed: ayam eva lakṣaṇasya avinirbhāgaḥ
translated: This alone is the inseparability of the characteristic.

original: pṛ yadutpadyamānaṃ na sa āśrayo bhavati /🔽āśrayo hi yatanyadvastu tat āśrayatāmupayāti /
analyzed: yat utpadyamānam na saḥ āśrayaḥ bhavati  āśrayaḥ hi yatan yat vastu tat āśraya tām upayāti
translated: What arises is not its basis.🔽For a basis is a different substance that becomes its basis.

original: u āśraya iti saṃjñāyate nānyadvastu lakṣaṇasyāśraya iti /
analyzed: āśrayaḥ iti saṃjñāyate na anyat vastu lakṣaṇasya āśrayaḥ iti
translated: It is called a basis, not another substance that is the basis of the characteristic.

analyzed: utpadyamānasya pravibhāgāt
translated: Because the arising is distinguished.

analyzed: yathā vadanti ākāśam sarva gāmi iti
translated: As they say, space moves everywhere.

analyzed: vastutas tu na asti tat yat gacchati
translated: But in reality there is nothing that moves.

analyzed: yat uktam bhavatā catvāri mahābhūtāni sahajātāni iti
translated: What you said that the four great elements are born together,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

original: yathā ātape kevalaṃ rūpayuktaḥ sparśa upalabhyate nānye dharmaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ātape kevalam rūpa yuktaḥ sparśaḥ upalabhyate na anye dharmaḥ
translated: For example, in heat only form and touch are perceived, not other dharmas.

original: candrikāyāṃ kevalaṃ rūpayuktaḥ śītasparśa upalabhyate nānye dharmāḥ /
analyzed: candrikāyām kevalam rūpa yuktaḥ śīta sparśaḥ upalabhyate na anye dharmāḥ
translated: In moonlight only form and cold touch are perceived, not other dharmas.

original: tasmānna sarveṣu padārtheṣu caturmahābhūtāni santi /🔽tadyathā kiñcidvastu nīrasaṃ yathā suvarṇavajrādi /
analyzed: tasmāt na sarveṣu padārtheṣu catur mahābhūtāni santi  tat yathā kiñcid vastu nīrasam yathā suvarṇa vajra ādi
translated: Therefore, the four great elements do not exist in all things.🔽For example, some things are flavorless, like gold, diamond, etc.

analyzed: kiñcid vastu nirgandham yathā suvarṇa rajata ādi
translated: Some things are odorless, like gold, silver, etc.

original: kiñcidvastu nīrūpaṃ yathā gṛhaprāsādadharma /🔽kiñcidvastu nirūṣma yathā candrakāntaādi /
analyzed: kiñcid vastu nīrūpam yathā gṛha prāsāda dharma  kiñcid vastu nirūṣma yathā candrakānta ādi
translated: Some things are formless, like houses, palaces, etc.🔽Some things are without heat, like moonstone, etc.

original: kiñcidvastu niśśītam yathā teja ādi /🔽kiñcidvastu īraṇalakṣaṇaṃ yathā vāyvādi /
analyzed: kiñcid vastu niśśītam yathā tejaḥ ādi  kiñcid vastu īraṇa lakṣaṇam yathā vāyu ādi
translated: Some things are without cold, like fire, etc.🔽Some things have the characteristic of motion, like wind, etc.

analyzed: kiñcid vastu nirīraṇam yathā pāṣāṇa ghaṇḍaḥ
translated: Some things are without motion, like a stone pillar.

analyzed: evam kiñcid vastu niṣkarkaśam
translated: Similarly, some things are without roughness.

analyzed: kiñcid nisneham
translated: Some are without moisture.

analyzed: kiñcid nirūṣma
translated: Some are without heat.

analyzed: kiñcid nirīraṇam
translated: Some are without movement.

analyzed: atas catvāri mahābhūtāni na a vinirbhāga vartīni
translated: Therefore, the four great elements do not exist separately.

original: pṛ bāhyaiḥ kāraṇairmahābhūtānāṃ svabhāva āvirbhavati /🔽yathā suvarṇapāṣāṇādau dravalakṣaṇaṃ teja apekṣyāvirbhavati /
analyzed: bāhyaiḥ kāraṇaiḥ mahābhūtānām svabhāvaḥ āvirbhavati  yathā suvarṇa pāṣāṇa ādau drava lakṣaṇam tejaḥ apekṣya āvirbhavati
translated: The nature of the great elements manifests due to external causes.🔽Just as the characteristic of fluidity in gold and stone manifests in dependence on fire.

original: apsu kāṭhinyalakṣaṇa atiśaityamupādāyodbhavati /🔽vāyau śītoṣmalakṣaṇa aptejasī upādāyodbhavati /
analyzed: apsu kāṭhinya lakṣaṇaḥ atiśaityam upādāya udbhavati  vāyau śīta ūṣma lakṣaṇaḥ ap tejasī upādāya udbhavati
translated: In water, the characteristic of solidity arises in dependence on extreme cold.🔽In air, the characteristics of cold and heat arise in dependence on water and fire.

analyzed: tṛṇa vṛkṣeṣu īraṇa lakṣaṇam vāyum prāpya udbhavati
translated: In grass and trees, the characteristic of movement arises in dependence on air.

analyzed: tasmāt pūrva vartinaḥ svabhāvāḥ pratyayam apekṣā udbhavanti
translated: Therefore, the previously existing natures arise in dependence on conditions.

original: ataścatvāri mahābhūtāni na vinirbhāgalābhina iti jñāyate /
analyzed: atas catvāri mahābhūtāni na vinirbhāga lābhinaḥ iti jñāyate
translated: And for that reason, it is known that the four great elements do not gain separation.

analyzed: yadi sa svabhāvaḥ
translated: If that nature did not exist before,

analyzed: katham udbhavet
translated: how could it arise?

original: u tathā cet vāyau kadācidgandho'stīti gandho vāyugataḥ syāt /
analyzed: u tathā ced vāyau kadācid gandhaḥ asti iti gandhaḥ vāyu gataḥ syāt
translated: And if so, sometimes there is smell in air, so smell would be in the air.

analyzed: yathā vāsita taila gandhaḥ taila gataḥ
translated: Just as the smell of perfumed oil is in the oil.

analyzed: na tu idam yujyate
translated: But this is not reasonable.

analyzed: na hi mahābhūtebhyaḥ bhautikam rūpam utpadyate
translated: Because derivative form does not arise from the great elements,

analyzed: yathā snehāt snehaḥ bhavati
translated: just as oil comes from oil.

analyzed: tathā rūpāt rūpam bhavati
translated: Similarly, form arises from form.

analyzed: yadi tāni a vinirbhāga vartīni
translated: If those [four great elements] exist without separation,

analyzed: tadā satkāryam syāt
translated: then the effect would exist in the cause.

analyzed: yathā kanyāyām putraḥ
translated: Just as a son exists in a maiden, and impurity exists in food.

original: na vayaṃ brūmaḥ satkāryam /🔽yadyapi nāsti payasi dadhi /
analyzed: na vayam brūmaḥ satkāryam  yadi api na asti payasi dadhi
translated: We do not say the effect exists in the cause.🔽Even though curd does not exist in milk,

analyzed: tathā api dadhi payasaḥ utpadyate
translated: still curd arises from milk.

original: evaṃ kiṃ saṃjñānusmaraṇavikalpena yaduta catvāri mahābhūtāni sahajātāni apṛthagbhāgavartīnīti //
analyzed: evam kim saṃjñā anusmaraṇa vikalpena yat uta catvāri mahābhūtāni sahajātāni apṛthak bhāga vartīni iti
translated: In the same way, what is the use of conceptualizing and remembering as such, that the four great elements are co-existent and do not exist separately?

analyzed: tad apramāṇa vargaḥ catvāriṃśaḥ
translated: This is the fortieth chapter on the theory of non-apprehension.
Chapter on the Explanation of the Ancient Established Doctrine

original: pūrvaṃ yadavādīḥna vayaṃ brūmaḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni rūpādibhirekāni yadi vānekāni ityato'navadyam iti /
analyzed: pūrvam yat avādīḥ na vayam brūmaḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni rūpa ādibhiḥ ekāni yadi vā anekāni iti atonavadyam iti
translated: You said earlier, We do not say the four great elements are the same as form, etc., or different, so there is no fault.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: tīrthikāḥ sarve siṣādhayiṣantītyata ścaturṇāṃ mahābhūtānāmekatvanānātve udāharanti /
analyzed: tīrthikāḥ sarve siṣādhayiṣanti iti atas caturṇām mahābhūtānām ekatva nānātve udāharanti
translated: Because all non-Buddhists seek to prove [the existence of the self], they cite the oneness and manyness of the four great elements.

original: ato bhagavān prajñaptau catarṇāṃ mahābhūtānāmudāhṛtatvāt teṣāmarthamupadiśati /
analyzed: atas bhagavān prajñaptau catarṇām mahābhūtānām udāhṛta tvāt teṣām artham upadiśati
translated: Therefore, because the Blessed One has cited the four great elements in the Abhidharma, he teaches their meaning.

analyzed: tathā no ced na brūyāt
translated: If it were not so, he would not have said it.

original: laukikāḥ svabhāvataḥ pṛthivyādimahābhūtāni jānanto'pi na vidanti teṣāṃ vastubhāvam /
analyzed: laukikāḥ svabhāvataḥ pṛthivī ādi mahābhūtāni jānantaḥ api na vidanti teṣām vastu bhāvam
translated: The worldly people, though knowing the great elements like earth etc. by their nature, do not know their real nature.

analyzed: atas upadeśam karoti
translated: Therefore, he teaches.

analyzed: na upadiśati hasta ādi
translated: He does not teach the hand etc.

analyzed: yadi khakkhaṭa ādibhiḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni bhavanti iti
translated: If the four great elements exist by means of hardness etc.,

analyzed: kaḥ upakāraḥ bhavet
translated: what benefit would there be?

original: asti dvidhā āśrayārtha ityuktvā mahābhūtāni dravyāṇīti yadavocaḥ /
analyzed: asti dvidhā āśraya arthaḥ iti uktvā mahābhūtāni dravyāṇi iti yat avocaḥ
translated: Having said that the great elements are substances, having said that the meaning of support is twofold,

analyzed: tatra na pratīmaḥ ayam āśraya arthaḥ
translated: we do not understand this meaning of support there.

analyzed: tad anyaḥ yaḥ sa prajñapti san iti
translated: The other one is nominally existent.

original: aṣṭaguṇā āpa iti vyavahārānuvartanato vadanti na tu dravyamahābhūtānuvartanata iti yadvacanaṃ tadayuktam /
analyzed: aṣṭaguṇāḥ āpaḥ iti vyavahāra anuvartanataḥ vadanti na tu dravya mahābhūta anuvartanataḥ iti yat vacanam tat ayuktam
translated: The statement that they say that water has eight qualities in accordance with worldly convention, but not in accordance with the real great elements, is incorrect.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

original: yadi vā pravacane yadi vā loke na hetupratyayairvinā rūpādiṣu caturmahābhūta saṃjñāṃ kurvanti /
analyzed: yadi vā pravacane yadi vā loke na hetu pratyayaiḥ vinā rūpa ādiṣu catur mahābhūta saṃjñām kurvanti
translated: Whether in the scriptures or in the world, they do not give the name of the four great elements to form etc. without causes and conditions.

analyzed: yathā loke vadanti paśyāmi aham puruṣam iti
translated: Just as in the world they say I see a person.

original: rūpādiṣu hi puruṣa iti saṃjñā na hetupratyayairvinā bhavati /
analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu hi puruṣaḥ iti saṃjñā na hetu pratyayaiḥ vinā bhavati
translated: For in form etc. the name person does not exist without causes and conditions.

original: yo vināpi sudṛḍhahetupratyayaiḥ saṃjñāṃ karoti so'śvaṃ dṛṣṭvā puruṣa ityāhvayet /
analyzed: yaḥ vinā api su dṛḍha hetu pratyayaiḥ saṃjñām karoti saḥ ūśvam dṛṣṭvā puruṣaḥ iti āhvayet
translated: One who makes a designation even without firm causes and conditions would call a horse a man upon seeing it.

analyzed: vastutas tu na tathā
translated: But in reality it is not so.

analyzed: kasmāt śabde pṛthivī iti na vadanti
translated: Why do they not say sound is earth?

original: laukikāḥ sadā pṛthag vadanti pṛthivīti śabda iti /
analyzed: laukikāḥ sadā pṛthak vadanti pṛthivī iti śabdaḥ iti
translated: The worldly always speak separately, saying earth and sound.

analyzed: na kadācid api vadanti śabdaḥ pṛthivī iti
translated: They never say sound is earth.

analyzed: yaḥ vinā su dṛḍha hetu pratyayaiḥ saṃjñām karoti
translated: One who makes a designation even without firm causes and conditions.

analyzed: sa śabdam pṛthivī iti āhvayet
translated: Would call sound earth.

analyzed: vastutas tu na tathā
translated: But in reality it is not so.

analyzed: tasmāt rūpa ādayaḥ catvāraḥ dharmāḥ eva pṛthivī
translated: Therefore, the four dharmas of form and so on are indeed earth.

analyzed: pṛthivī bhāge pi pṛthivī iti saṃjñā bhavati
translated: Even in a part of earth, the designation earth occurs.

original: yathārūpamidaṃ prajñapterhetuṃ sādhayati tatra puruṣa iti saṃjñā /
analyzed: yathārūpam idam prajñapteḥ hetum sādhayati tatra puruṣaḥ iti saṃjñā
translated: Just as the designation man occurs there where the cause of designation is established as form,

analyzed: vṛkṣeṣu vanam iti saṃjñā
translated: the designation forest occurs in trees,

analyzed: bhikṣuṣu saṅghaḥ iti saṃjñā
translated: the designation saṅgha occurs in monks.

original: evaṃ rūpādiṣu dharmeṣu catvāri mahābhūtānīti saṃjñāṃ vadanti /
analyzed: evam rūpa ādiṣu dharmeṣu catvāri mahābhūtāni iti saṃjñām vadanti
translated: Thus, they speak of the designation four great elements in the dharmas of form and so on.

original: yadavocaḥyadi vā ṣaṭ sparśāyatanāni yadi vā ṣaṭ sparśāyatanānyupādāya siddhā dharmā iti /
analyzed: yat avocaḥ yadi vā ṣaḍ sparśāyatanāni yadi vā ṣaḍ sparśāyatanāni upādāya siddhāḥ dharmāḥ iti
translated: As for what you said: Whether it is the six bases of contact or the dharmas established based on the six bases of contact,

analyzed: na idam sūtram yuktam
translated: This sūtra is not correct.

original: yathā bhavatāṃ śāsane bhautikaṃ rūpaṃ na kasyacijjanakam /
analyzed: yathā bhavatām śāsane bhautikam rūpam na kasyacid janakam
translated: Just as in your doctrine, material form is not the producer of anything.

original: tathā mama śāsane'pi prajñaptau na tatkasyacit janyam /
analyzed: tathā mama śāsane pi prajñaptau na tat kasyacid janyam
translated: In the same way, in my doctrine also, in the conventional, it is not the product of anything.

analyzed: atas idam sūtram na bhavet
translated: Therefore, this sūtra would not exist.

analyzed: asti ced tasya arthaḥ nyathayitavyaḥ
translated: If it does exist, its meaning should be interpreted otherwise.

analyzed: yat avādīḥ catvāri mahābhūtāni upādāya bhautikaḥ rūpa prasādaḥ cakṣuḥ iti
translated: You said: The eye is a subtle form derived from the four great elements.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is incorrect.

analyzed: caturṇām mahābhūtānām samavāyaḥ prajñaptau cakṣuḥ iti ucyate
translated: The collection of the four great elements is called the eye in the conventional.

analyzed: prajñapti santi catvāri mahābhūtāni rūpam
translated: The four great elements that exist conventionally are form.

analyzed: tad rūpa prasādaḥ cakṣuḥ
translated: That subtle form is the eye.

original: yadyupyuktaṃ bhavatā dharme dharmo vartate nirāśrayo niradhiṣṭhātā ceti /
analyzed: bhavatā dharme dharmaḥ vartate nirāśrayaḥ niradhiṣṭhātā ca iti
translated: Even though you said: A dharma exists in a dharma, without a basis and without a support.

original: tatra yo dharmaḥ sa evāśrayaḥ adhiṣṭhātā ca /
analyzed: tatra yaḥ dharmaḥ saḥ eva āśrayaḥ adhiṣṭhātā ca
translated: There, that dharma is the basis and the support.

analyzed: yena vartate saḥ āśrayaḥ
translated: By which it exists, that is the basis.

analyzed: yasmin dharme tiṣṭhati saḥ adhiṣṭhātā
translated: In which dharma it abides, that is the support.

analyzed: yat avocaḥ khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam saṃghatte ityādi
translated: You said: The characteristic of hardness supports, etc.

analyzed: na idam yujyate
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: na khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam kevalam dhatte
translated: The characteristic of hardness does not merely support.

analyzed: api tu hetu pratyaya sāmagrīn ca apekṣate
translated: But it also depends on the collection of causes and conditions.

analyzed: tathā anyāni api
translated: So it is with the others.

analyzed: tasmāt catvāri mahābhūtāni prajñapti santi
translated: Therefore, the four great elements are nominally existent.

analyzed: pūrvatana siddhānta prakāśana vargam ekacatvāriṃśaḥ
translated: The fortieth chapter on revealing the former established doctrine.

analyzed: khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇa asattā vargaḥ
translated: Chapter on the non-existence of the characteristic of hardness

original: pṛ yadāha bhavānkhakkhaṭabahulo rūpādi samavāyaḥ pṛthivīmahābhūtamityataḥ pṛthivyādayaḥ prajñaptisanta iti /
analyzed: yat āha bhavān khakkhaṭa bahulaḥ rūpa ādi samavāyaḥ pṛthivī mahābhūtam iti atas pṛthivī ādayaḥ prajñapti santaḥ iti
translated: You said: The collection of form, etc. dominated by hardness is the earth great element. Therefore, earth, etc. are nominally existent.

analyzed: na idam yujyate
translated: This is not reasonable.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: khakkhaṭa dharmaḥ eva na asti
translated: The characteristic of hardness itself does not exist.

analyzed: kim punar prajñapti satī pṛthivī
translated: Then what is the nominally existent earth?

original: yo mṛtpiṇḍaḥ khakkhaṭaḥ sa eva kadācit mṛduḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ mṛd piṇḍaḥ khakkhaṭaḥ saḥ eva kadācid mṛduḥ
translated: That very clay ball which is hard sometimes becomes soft.

analyzed: atas jñāyate khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam aniyatam iti  alpatara kāraṇena ca khakkhaṭa buddhiḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, it is known that the characteristic of hardness is uncertain.🔽And the cognition of hardness arises from a very small cause.

analyzed: aṇūnām viśliṣṭa samavāye mṛduḥ iti buddhiḥ bhavati
translated: In the disjoined conjunction of atoms, there is the cognition of softness.

analyzed: saṃśliṣṭa samavāye khakkhaṭam iti
translated: In the conjoined conjunction, there is the cognition of hardness.

analyzed: atoniyatam
translated: Therefore, it is uncertain.

analyzed: na hi ekasmin dharme sparśa dvayam bhavati
translated: For in one dharma, two tactile sensations do not occur.

original: yena khakkhaṭaḥ kāyaḥ mṛduḥ kāya iti buddhirbhavet /
analyzed: yena khakkhaṭaḥ kāyaḥ mṛduḥ kāyaḥ iti buddhiḥ bhavet
translated: By which there would be the cognition of the body as hard and the body as soft.

analyzed: atoniyatam khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam
translated: Therefore, the characteristic of hardness is indeterminate.

analyzed: aniyatā khakkhaṭa tā mṛdu tā ca anyonyam apekṣya asti
translated: Hardness and softness are indeterminate, existing in mutual dependence.

analyzed: yathā kambalam apekṣya paṭam mṛdu bhavati
translated: For example, cloth is soft in dependence on a blanket,

analyzed: paṭam apekṣya kambalam karkaśam bhavati
translated: and a blanket is rough in dependence on cloth.

analyzed: na hi tāttviakaḥ sparśa dharmaḥ anyonyam apekṣya asti
translated: But a real tactile object does not exist in mutual dependence.

analyzed: suvarṇa pāṣāṇe cakṣuṣā draṣṭuḥ jñāyate idam khakkhaṭam iti
translated: And it is known by one who sees with the eye that gold and stone are hard.

analyzed: na hi sparśaḥ cakṣuṣā upalabhyate
translated: A tactile object is not perceived by the eye.

analyzed: atas na asti khakkhaṭa tā
translated: Therefore, there is no hardness.

original: anenaiva kāraṇena mṛdvādayaḥ sparśā api na santi //🔽khakkhaṭalakṣaṇāsattāvargo dvipaṃñcāśaḥ /
analyzed: anena eva kāraṇena mṛdu ādayaḥ sparśāḥ api na santi  khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇā sattā vargaḥ dvipaṃñcāśaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the tactile objects such as softness do not exist either.🔽Chapter 52: The Non-existence of the Characteristic of Hardness

analyzed: khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇa sattā vargaḥ
translated: Chapter 53: The Existence of the Characteristic of Hardness

analyzed: atra ucyate dravya sat khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam
translated: Here it is said: The characteristic of hardness exists as a substance.

original: yadyapyāha bhavānyo mṛtpiṇḍaḥ khakkhaṭaḥ sa eva kadācit mṛduriti /
analyzed: yadi api āha bhavān yaḥ mṛd piṇḍaḥ khakkhaṭaḥ saḥ eva kadācid mṛduḥ iti
translated: Although you say that the same lump of clay that is hard may sometimes be soft,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: nahi asti asmākam dravyataḥ mṛd piṇḍaḥ
translated: Because for us, a lump of clay does not exist as a substance.

original: bahūnāṃ dharmāṇāṃ kalāpaḥ prajñaptyā mṛtpiṇḍa ityucyate /
analyzed: bahūnām dharmāṇām kalāpaḥ prajñaptyā mṛd piṇḍaḥ iti ucyate
translated: A collection of many dharmas is called a lump of clay by conceptual designation.

analyzed: alpatara kāraṇena ca khakkhaṭa buddhiḥ bhavati iti yat avocaḥ
translated: And what you said that the notion of hardness arises from a very small cause,

analyzed: na tat yujyate
translated: that is not correct.

original: mama saṃśliṣṭasaṃṅghātāṇuṣu idaṃ khakkhaṭalakṣaṇaṃ labhyata iti asti khakkhaṭatā /
analyzed: mama saṃśliṣṭa saṃṅghāta aṇuṣu idam khakkhaṭa lakṣaṇam labhyate iti asti khakkhaṭa tā
translated: For me, in atoms that are closely packed together, this characteristic of hardness is obtained, so hardness exists.

analyzed: asaṃśliṣṭeṣu tat mṛdu lakṣaṇam labhyate
translated: In those that are not closely packed, that characteristic of softness is obtained.

analyzed: iti atas na asti doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore there is no fault.

analyzed: yaḥ dharmaḥ upalabhyate
translated: That dharma which is perceived,

analyzed: saḥ eva asti iti ucyate
