analyzed: yathā āha sūtram samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam prajānāti iti
translated: As the sutra says: One who is concentrated knows things as they really are.

analyzed: na vikṣipta cittaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: not with a distracted mind.

analyzed: pṛ asyāḥ mithyādṛṣṭeḥ ke doṣāḥ
translated: What are the faults of this wrong view?

original: u sarve doṣā vipattivyasanāni ca mithyādṛṣṭyā bhavanti /
analyzed: u sarve doṣāḥ vipatti vyasanāni ca mithyādṛṣṭyāḥ bhavanti
translated: All faults, misfortunes, and calamities arise from wrong view.

original: sa āhanāsti pāpaṃ nāsti puṇyaṃ sukṛtaduṣkṛtānāṃ phalaṃ vipāka iti /
analyzed: saḥ āha na asti pāpam na asti puṇyam sukṛta duṣkṛtānām phalam vipākaḥ iti
translated: He says: There is no evil, no merit, no fruit or result of good or bad actions.

original: ato dṛṣṭadharma eva na santi suvṛttāni /
analyzed: atas dṛṣṭa dharme eva na santi su vṛttāni
translated: Therefore, in this very life, there are no good actions.

analyzed: kim punar anāgatāni
translated: What to speak of future ones?

analyzed: evam dūṣita sukṛta duṣkṛtaḥ pumān samucchinna kuśala mūlaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Thus, a person who has corrupted good and bad actions is said to have cut off the roots of good.

analyzed: sa niyatam avīcau patiṣyati
translated: He will certainly fall into Avīci.

analyzed: yathā uktam ṣaṭpāda abhidharme krimi pipīlikā hananam puruṣa hananāt gurutaram iti
translated: As it is said in the Abhidharma of Six Chapters: Killing an ant or an ant is graver than killing a man.

original: sa mithyādṛṣṭikaḥ puruṣaḥ lokadūṣakaḥ satvānāṃ bhūyasāpakārāya pravartate /
analyzed: sa mithyādṛṣṭikaḥ puruṣaḥ loka dūṣakaḥ satvānām bhūyasā apakārāya pravartate
translated: That person with wrong view, who corrupts the world, acts to harm beings in many ways.

analyzed: yathā viṣa vṛkṣaḥ hiṃsāyai prarohati
translated: Just as a poisonous tree grows to harm.

original: tena kṛtaṃ kāyikaṃ vācikaṃ mānasaṃ karma sarvamaśubhavipākāya bhavati /
analyzed: tena kṛtam kāyikam vācikam mānasam karma sarvam aśubha vipākāya bhavati
translated: Any bodily, verbal, or mental action done by him leads to all unwholesome results.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtremithyādṛṣṭikasya bhikṣavaḥ puruṣapudgalasya yatkāyakarma yathādṛṣṭisamāttaṃ samādattaṃ yacca vākkarma / / / / / / / /yacca manaḥkarma yā cetanā yā prārthanā yaḥ praṇidhiḥ ye ca saṃskārāḥ sarve te'niṣṭāya akāntāya amanāpāya ahitāya duḥkhāya saṃvartate /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre mithyādṛṣṭikasya bhikṣavaḥ puruṣa pudgalasya yat kāya karma yathā dṛṣṭi samāttam samādattam yat ca vāc karma yat ca manaḥ karma yā cetanā yā prārthanā yaḥ praṇidhiḥ ye ca saṃskārāḥ sarve teniṣṭāya akāntāya amanāpāya ahitāya duḥkhāya saṃvartate
translated: As it is said in the sutra: Monks, for a person with wrong view, whatever bodily action there is, whatever verbal action there is, whatever mental action there is, whatever intention, whatever aspiration, whatever vow, and whatever formations there are, all of that leads to what is undesirable, unpleasant, disagreeable, harmful, and suffering.

original: tadyathā tiktakālābubījaṃ koṣātakībījaṃ picumandabījamādrāyāṃ pṛthivyāṃ nikṣiptaṃ yaccaiva pṛthivīrasamupādīyate yaccāporasaṃ tejorasaṃ vāyurasamupādīyate sarvaṃ tat tiktakatvāya kaṭukatvāya asātatvāya saṃvartate /
analyzed: tat yathā tiktakālābu bījam koṣātakī bījam picumanda bījam ādrāyām pṛthivyām nikṣiptam yat ca eva pṛthivī rasam upādīyate yat ca apaḥ rasam tejaḥ rasam vāyu rasam upādīyate sarvam tat tiktaka tvāya kaṭuka tvāya asāta tvāya saṃvartate
translated: Just as, for example, the seed of a bitter gourd, the seed of a kośātaki, or the seed of a picumanda, when planted in moist soil, and whatever earth element it takes up, and whatever water element, fire element, or air element it takes up, all of that leads to bitterness, bitterness, and unpalatability.

original: tatkasya hetoḥ bījaṃ hi bhikṣavaḥ pāpakam /
analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ bījam hi bhikṣavaḥ pāpakam
translated: Why is that? Because, monks, the seed is bad.

original: evameva mithyādṛṣṭikasya puruṣapudgalasya cittacaitasikā dharmā aniṣṭāya akāntāya amanāpāya ahitāya duḥkhāya saṃvartate /
analyzed: evam eva mithyādṛṣṭikasya puruṣa pudgalasya citta caitasikāḥ dharmāḥ aniṣṭāya akāntāya amanāpāya ahitāya duḥkhāya saṃvartate
translated: In the same way, for a person with wrong view, whatever mental and mental factors there are, all of that leads to what is undesirable, unpleasant, disagreeable, harmful, and suffering.

original: tatkasya hetoḥ dṛṣṭirhi bhikṣavaḥ pāpikā iti /
analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ dṛṣṭiḥ hi bhikṣavaḥ pāpikā iti
translated: Why is that? Because, monks, view is bad.

original: atastasya puruṣapudgalasya kṛtamapi dānādi neṣṭaphalaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: atas tasya puruṣa pudgalasya kṛtam api dāna ādi na iṣṭa phalam bhavati
translated: Therefore, even the giving and so on done by that person do not become the desired result.

analyzed: pūrva kṛta mithyādṛṣṭi cittena vinaṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because they are destroyed by the mind of wrong view done previously.

analyzed: tad kṛtasya aśubham eva adhimātram bhavati
translated: The unwholesome karma done by him becomes extremely strong.

analyzed: pāpaka cittasya cira sañcita tvāt
translated: Because the unwholesome mind has been accumulated for a long time.

analyzed: saṃvareṇa ca kaścid asat dharmam pratiroddhum śaknoti
translated: And by restraint, someone can resist unwholesome dharmas.

original: asya puruṣapudgalasya nāsti sukṛtaṃ duṣkṛtamityato na yataḥ kutaścitprativiratiḥ /
analyzed: asya puruṣa pudgalasya na asti sukṛtam duṣkṛtam iti atas na yatas kutaścid prativiratiḥ
translated: For this person, there is neither good nor bad karma, so there is no turning away from anywhere.

analyzed: carati
translated: He practices unwholesome dharmas with extreme negligence.

analyzed: hrī apatrapā ākhya dvividha śukla dharma sabhinnaḥ paśusamaḥ bhavati
translated: He becomes like an animal, lacking the two kinds of pure dharmas called shame and embarrassment.

original: yaśca vadati nāsti sukṛtaṃ duṣkṛtaṃ veti sa sadā citte'kuśalameva kāṅkṣate /
analyzed: yaḥ ca vadati na asti sukṛtam duṣkṛtam vā iti sa sadā citte kuśalam eva kāṅkṣate
translated: And he who says there is no good or bad karma always desires unwholesome things in his mind.

analyzed: tasya saddharma samādāpana kāraṇam eva nā asti
translated: He has no cause for accepting the true Dharma at all.

analyzed: kasmāt na hi sa sat janam upagacchati
translated: Why? Because he does not approach the virtuous.

original: nāpi saddharmaṃ śṛṇoti /🔽tasya duṣkṛtacittaṃ sūtthānaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na api saddharmam śṛṇoti  tasya duṣkṛta cittam sūtthānam bhavati
translated: And he does not hear the true Dharma.🔽His unwholesome mind becomes very active.

analyzed: su kṛta cittam durutpādam
translated: His wholesome mind is difficult to arouse.

analyzed: duṣkṛtasya su utthāna tvāt sukṛtasya kāraṇam eva na asti
translated: Because evil is easily aroused, there is no cause for good.

analyzed: evam krameṇa duṣkṛta upacaye samucchinna kuśala mūlaḥ bhavati
translated: In this way, evil gradually accumulates, and one becomes one whose wholesome roots are cut off.

analyzed: mithyādṛṣṭikasya puruṣa pudgalasya dusthāna gataḥ iti ākhyā
translated: A person with wrong views is called one who has gone to a bad place.

analyzed: yathā nārakāḥ sattvāḥ na mārga pratilābha pravaṇāḥ
translated: Just as hell beings are not inclined to attain the path,

original: tathā ca pudgalo madhyamadeśa utpanna iṣṭāniṣṭavivekāya ṣaḍindriyasampanno'pi na mārgapratilābhapravaṇo bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca pudgalaḥ madhyama deśe utpannaḥ iṣṭa aniṣṭa vivekāya ṣaṣ indriya sampannaḥ api na mārga pratilābha pravaṇaḥ bhavati
translated: and a person born in the central country, even with the six senses complete, is not inclined to attain the path for distinguishing what is desirable and undesirable,

analyzed: mithyādṛṣṭikasya na asti yat kiñcid duṣkṛta makuṭam
translated: for one with wrong views, there is no small amount of evil that is not covered.

analyzed: na asti viratiḥ laghoḥ alpāt vā duṣkṛtāt
translated: There is no abstention from even a small amount of evil.

analyzed: alpam api akuśalam kurvan narake patati
translated: Even doing a small amount of evil, one falls into hell.

analyzed: karmaṇaḥ usya guru pāpaka cittena samutpanna tvāt
translated: Because this karma arises from a mind of great evil.

original: yathā karmavarge narakavimocakaṃ karma ityanena kāraṇena tatpuruṣakṛtaṃ sarvaṃ narakāya saṃvartate /
analyzed: yathā karma varge naraka vimocakam karma iti anena kāraṇena tat puruṣa kṛtam sarvam narakāya saṃvartate
translated: For the same reason, as stated in the Karma Section, karma that liberates from hell, all that is done by that person leads to hell.

original: na ca sa pāpakamakuśalaṃ karma kṣapayati /
analyzed: na ca sa pāpakam akuśalam karma kṣapayati
translated: And he does not exhaust evil, unwholesome karma.

analyzed: akuśala dharmasya sadā citta gata tvāt
translated: Because unwholesome dharmas always remain in the mind.

analyzed: durlabhā ca tasya uttara uttarāt narakāt vimuktiḥ
translated: And it is difficult for him to be liberated from the hells, one after another.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

original: samucchinnakuśalamūlasya hi yadā kuśalaṃ na pravartate tadanantaraṃ narakānnaiva vimuktiḥ /
analyzed: samucchinna kuśala mūlasya hi yadā kuśalam na pravartate tad anantaram narakāt nā eva vimuktiḥ
translated: For one who has cut off the roots of good, when good does not arise, there is no liberation from hell immediately after that.

original: citte mithyādṛṣṭikatvāt tasya kuśalamūlaṃ kathaṃ pravarteta /
analyzed: citte mithyādṛṣṭika tvāt tasya kuśala mūlam katham pravarteta
translated: How can the roots of good arise for him, because his mind is of wrong view?

analyzed: mithyādṛṣṭikaḥ pudgala ucikitsyaḥ tat yathā samupasthita maraṇa nimittaḥ rogī
translated: A person with wrong view is incurable, just like a patient with the signs of imminent death.

analyzed: cikitsakaḥ san api na cikitsitum śaknoti
translated: Even a doctor cannot cure him.

analyzed: evam ayam api
translated: This is also so.

analyzed: anya kuśala rahita tvāt yāvat buddhāḥ api na cikitsante
translated: Because he lacks other good qualities, even the Buddhas cannot cure him.

analyzed: atas vaśyam avīcyām patati
translated: Therefore, he necessarily falls into Avīci.🔽The thirty-second chapter on wrong view.

analyzed: mithyādṛṣṭi vargaḥ dvātriṃśat uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: The two kinds of clinging

original: abhūtavastuni idameva satyamanyanmithyeti vacanaṃ dṛṣṭiparāmarśa ityucyate /
analyzed: abhūta vastuni idam eva satyam anyat mithyā iti vacanam dṛṣṭi parāmarśaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Speaking This alone is true, the others are false about an unreal thing is called the clinging to views.

analyzed: pūrva uktena utkṛṣṭa dharmaḥ utkṛṣṭa saṃjñā viniścayaḥ api dṛṣṭi parāmarśaḥ
translated: The determination of the notion of superiority towards a previously mentioned non-superior dharma is also the clinging to views.

analyzed: pṛ dṛṣṭi parāmarśasya ke doṣāḥ
translated: What are the faults of the clinging to views?

original: u sa puruṣo nyūnaguṇaṃ labdhvā ātmānaṃ pūrṇaṃ manyate /
analyzed: u sa puruṣaḥ nyūna guṇam labdhvā ātmānam pūrṇam manyate
translated: That person, having obtained a virtue that is inferior, considers himself to be complete.

analyzed: tasya guṇan ca ativakti
translated: And he praises his own virtue.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: akuśale vastuni atyanta kuśala saṃjñām utpādya vīryam ārabhate
translated: Because, having generated the notion of extreme wholesomeness towards an unwholesome object, he exerts his effort.

analyzed: tena hetunā ca paścāt paritapati
translated: And for that reason, he repents later.

analyzed: viduṣām parihāsyaḥ ca bhavati
translated: And he becomes an object of ridicule for the wise.

analyzed: anutkṛṣṭe utkṛṣṭa saṃjñāyāḥ kṛta tvāt
translated: Because he has generated the notion of excellence towards what is not excellent.

analyzed: yaḥ anutkṛṣṭam utkṛṣṭam vadati sa bālaḥ mūḍha saṃjñaḥ
translated: He who speaks of what is not excellent as excellent is a fool, having the notion of a fool.

original: yathāndho ghaṭaśakale suvarṇasaṃjñāmutpādya cakṣuṣmatāṃ laghu hāsyo bhavati /
analyzed: yathā andhaḥ ghaṭa śakale suvarṇa saṃjñām utpādya cakṣuṣmatām laghu hāsyaḥ bhavati
translated: Just as a blind man, having generated the notion of gold towards a piece of pottery, becomes quickly ridiculed by those with eyes.

analyzed: dṛṣṭi parāmarśasya īdṛśāḥ doṣāḥ
translated: Such are the faults of the overesteeming of morality and rituals.

original: yat kaścit bodhimupekṣamāṇaḥ snānādiśīlena viśuddhiprāptiṃ kāṅkṣate tat śīlavrataparāmarśa ityucyate /
analyzed: yat kaścid bodhim upekṣamāṇaḥ snāna ādi śīlena viśuddhi prāptim kāṅkṣate tat śīla vrata parāmarśaḥ iti ucyate
translated: When someone, disregarding enlightenment, desires to attain purification through the morality of bathing and so on, that is called the overesteeming of morality and rituals.

analyzed: pṛ nanu śīlena na viśuddhi lābhaḥ
translated: Isn't purification attained through morality?

analyzed: u prajñayā eva viśuddhi lābhaḥ
translated: Purification is attained only through wisdom.

analyzed: śīlantu prajñā indriyasya mūlam
translated: But morality is the root of the faculty of wisdom.

analyzed: pṛ ke doṣāḥ śīla vrata parāmarśasya
translated: What are the faults of the overesteeming of morality and rituals?

original: u ye doṣā uktā dṛṣṭiparāmarśasya nyūnaṃ vastu labdhvā sampūrṇaṃ manyate ityādinā ta eva doṣāḥ /
analyzed: ye doṣāḥ uktāḥ dṛṣṭi parāmarśasya nyūnam vastu labdhvā sampūrṇam manyate ityādinā te eva doṣāḥ
translated: The faults that were said to be of clinging to views, such as obtaining a lesser thing and considering it complete, are the same faults.

analyzed: śīla vrata parāmarśa pratyayam atyadhikam duḥkhāni anubhavati
translated: One experiences excessive suffering due to the condition of clinging to rules and rituals.

analyzed: yat uta śīta uṣṇa vedanā
translated: Namely, the feelings of cold and heat.

analyzed: bhasma bhūmi taru kaṇṭaka ādiṣu śayanam jala hrada agnipraveśaḥ bhṛgupatanam ityādi
translated: Sleeping on ashes, on the ground, on thorny plants, entering water, fire, and pits, and so on.

analyzed: para loke api atimātra duḥkha vipākaḥ
translated: In the next world also, there is the ripening of excessive suffering.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtregovratikaḥ saṃsiddhavrataḥ kāyasya bhedātparaṃ maraṇāt gavāṃ sahavyatāmupapadyate /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtregovratikaḥ saṃsiddha vrataḥ kāyasya bhedāt param maraṇāt gavām sa havya tām upapadyate
translated: As it is said in the sutra: The cow-vow practitioner, having perfected the vow, upon the dissolution of the body after death, is reborn in the company of cows.

analyzed: a saṃsiddhaḥ narake patati iti
translated: The unperfected one falls into hell.

analyzed: sa tamasaḥ tamaḥ praviśati
translated: He enters from darkness into darkness.

analyzed: yatas tam dharmam samādadānaḥ dṛṣṭa dharme duḥkham anubhavati
translated: Because by undertaking that practice, he experiences suffering in this very life.

analyzed: ūrdhvam api duḥkham
translated: And also in the future, there is suffering.

analyzed: sa gurutaram pāpañca vindate
translated: He obtains a heavier sin.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: adharmam dharmam matvā sat dharmam vināśayati
translated: Considering non-Dharma as Dharma, he destroys the true Dharma.

analyzed: saddharma caryā apabādakaḥ ca bahūn sattvān narake pātayati
translated: And he causes many beings to fall into hell by denouncing the practice of the true Dharma.

analyzed: su viśuddha dharmasya pṛṣṭhīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because it is contrary to the well-purified Dharma.

analyzed: sañcita mahā pāpaḥ uvaśyam avīci narake vipākam anubhavati
translated: One who has accumulated great evil necessarily experiences retribution in the Avīci hell.

analyzed: atas anācārāt virama
translated: Therefore, refrain from misconduct.

analyzed: mā cara mithyā mārgam
translated: Do not practice the wrong path.

original: kasmāt ya ādito nācarati tasya mārgacaraṇaṃ sukaram /
analyzed: kasmāt yaḥ āditas na ācarati tasya mārga caraṇam sukaram
translated: Why is it that for one who does not practice from the beginning, practicing the path is easy?

analyzed: mithyā ācāra parāhata cittasya tu duṣkaraḥ mārga praveśaḥ
translated: But for one whose mind is defeated by wrong practice, entering the path is difficult.

original: śatrurapi na tathā pudgalaṃ glapayati yathā mithyādṛṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: śatruḥ api na tathā pudgalam glapayati yathā mithyādṛṣṭiḥ
translated: Even an enemy does not torment a person as much as wrong view.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

original: na hi śatrustathā pudgalaṃ paribhāvayati yathā mithyādṛṣṭayanugāmināṃ tīrthikācaritānāṃ nānāduḥśīlānāṃ nagnatānirlajjatābhasmarajaḥkāyatākeśolluñcchanādīnāṃ samādānam /
analyzed: na hi śatruḥ tathā pudgalam paribhāvayati yathā mithyādṛṣṭay anugāminām tīrthika ācaritānām nānā duḥśīlānām nagna tā nirlajja tā bhasma rajaḥ kāya tā keśa ulluñchana ādīnām samādānam
translated: For an enemy does not torment a person as much as the adoption of the practices of non-Buddhists who follow wrong views, such as various forms of bad conduct, nakedness, shamelessness, smearing the body with ashes and dust, pulling out hair, and so on.

analyzed: mithyādṛṣṭikaḥ sarvasmāt laukika hita kāmāt bhraśyati
translated: One with wrong view falls away from all worldly good things that are desired.

analyzed: dṛṣṭadharme pañca kāmaguṇebhyaḥ bhraśyati
translated: In this very life, he falls away from the five sense pleasures.

analyzed: tad ūrdhvam sugati sukhāt nirvāṇāt ca bhraśyati
translated: After that, he falls away from the happiness of good destinies and from nirvana.

original: sukhaṃ prārthayitvā duḥkhaṃ labhamāno vimuktiṃ prārthayitvā bandhaṃ labhamānaḥ puruṣaḥ kiṃ na mattaḥ /
analyzed: sukham prārthayitvā duḥkham labhamānaḥ vimuktim prārthayitvā bandham labhamānaḥ puruṣaḥ kim na mattaḥ
translated: Is a person who, having sought happiness, obtains suffering, and having sought liberation, obtains bondage, not mad?

analyzed: tat kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: yaḥ ekena anna dāna pratyayena svarge janma lābha arhaḥ bhavati
translated: One who is worthy of rebirth in heaven by the condition of giving food with one [action],

original: tasya puruṣasya mithyācāracāritvāt dānāya kāyajīvite satyapi na kiñcana hitaṃ bhavati //🔽parāmarśadvayavargastrayastiṃśaduttaraśatatamaḥ /
analyzed: tasya puruṣasya mithyā ācāra cāri tvāt dānāya kāya jīvite sati api na kiñcana hitam bhavati  parāmarśa dvaya vargaḥ trayastiṃśat uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: because that person's conduct is false, even if he has a body and life for giving, it is of no benefit at all.🔽The thirty-third chapter on the two kinds of clinging.

analyzed: upakleśa vargaḥ  guru cittasya svāpa kāma tā middham
translated: The chapter on secondary afflictions🔽The desire to sleep of a heavy mind is drowsiness.

analyzed: citta samādhānāya prabodha viratiḥ svāpaḥ  viṣayeṣu vikṣipta citta tā auddhatyam
translated: Sleep is the cessation of wakefulness for the sake of concentrating the mind.🔽Distracting the mind towards objects is restlessness.

analyzed: citta ākāṃkṣite daurmanasya bandhaḥ kaukṛtyam
translated: Regret is the bondage of mental dissatisfaction towards what the mind desires.

analyzed: tat yathā kṛtam akartavyam akṛtam ca kartavyam iti  kuśala kuhana kuṭila cittam māyā
translated: For example, doing what should not be done and not doing what should be done.🔽A crooked mind that deceives is deceit.

analyzed: sva kṛta akuśalasya āhrepaṇam āhrīkyam
translated: Cunning is the manifestation of a mind of deceit.🔽Lack of shame is not being ashamed of one's own evil deeds.

analyzed: saṅghe kṛta akuśalasya a hrepaṇam an apatrāpyam
translated: Lack of conscience is not being ashamed of one's evil deeds towards the Saṅgha.

analyzed: akuśala anugam cittam pramādaḥ
translated: A mind that follows evil is negligence.

original: yadasantaṃ guṇaṃ khyāpayati tena janā vadanti astīti /
analyzed: yat asantam guṇam khyāpayati tena janāḥ vadanti asti iti
translated: When one proclaims a non-existent virtue, people say it exists.

analyzed: sā kuhanā
translated: That is hypocrisy.

original: lābhasatkārāyādbhutaṃ prakhyāpya pareṣāṃ manaḥprahlādinī vāk lapanā /
analyzed: lābha satkārāya adbhutam prakhyāpya pareṣām manaḥ prahlādinī vāc lapanā
translated: Flattery is speaking words that delight the minds of others by proclaiming their gains and honors.

original: paradravyalipsayā tallipsāmupagūhya vadati idaṃ vastu sundaramityādi /
analyzed: para dravya lipsayā tad lipsām upagūhya vadati idam vastu sundaram ityādi
translated: Covetousness is speaking that this thing is beautiful, etc., with the intention of obtaining another's property.

analyzed: tad naimittika tā
translated: That is the state of being a fortune-teller.

original: yadetatpuruṣanindāyai anyaṃ stautitava pitā vyavasāyī tvantu neti /
analyzed: yat etat puruṣa nindāyai anyam stauti tava pitā vyavasāyī na iti
translated: When one praises another for the purpose of disparaging a man, saying Your father is resolute, but you are not,

analyzed: tat niṣpeṣika tā
translated: that is the state of being a slanderer.

original: yat dānena dānaṃ prārthayamāno vadatiidaṃ dānavastu amukātpatyantāllabdhamityādi /
analyzed: yat dānena dānam prārthayamānaḥ vadati idam dānavastu amukāt pati antāt labdham ityādi
translated: When one speaks, desiring a gift in return for a gift, saying This gift was obtained from so-and-so, etc.,

analyzed: tat lābhena lābha jigṛkṣā
translated: that is the desire for gain through gain.

original: yat puruṣasya nidrāvyādhau niratiḥ sā tandrītyucyate /
analyzed: yat puruṣasya nidrā vyādhau niratiḥ sā tandrā iti ucyate
translated: That drowsiness which is a man's fondness for sleep and illness is called sloth.

analyzed: yā mārga caryā kāraṇa su deśa saṃpattau api sadā utkaṇṭhita tā sā aratiḥ iti ucyate
translated: That dissatisfaction which is constant longing even when there is a good path, practice, cause, and place, is called discontent.

original: yat puruṣasya kāyasya jṛmbhaṇā adamanaṃ styānamiddhasya pratyayaḥ sā vijṛmbhikā /
analyzed: yat puruṣasya kāyasya jṛmbhaṇā adamanam styānam iddhasya pratyayaḥ sā vijṛmbhikā
translated: That yawning, lack of self-control, and condition of sloth and torpor in a man's body is called yawning.

analyzed: yaḥ āhāre bahu alpa tā damana anabhijñaḥ
translated: He who is not skilled in the self-control of much or little food,

analyzed: saḥ āditodamaḥ iti ucyate
translated: he is called one who is not self-controlled from the beginning.

analyzed: yaḥ na atimātra vyavasāyī bhavati
translated: He who does not make excessive effort,

analyzed: sa vivartya cittaḥ iti ucyate
translated: he is called one whose mind turns back.

original: yo mahāmātrāṇāṃ vacanaṃ na satkaroti na bibheti /
analyzed: yaḥ mahāmātrāṇām vacanam na satkaroti na bibheti
translated: One who does not respect the words of great teachers and is not afraid of them,

analyzed: sā ubahumānī iti ucyate
translated: is called disrespectful.

analyzed: akuśala rucikaḥ puruṣaḥ pāpa mitraḥ iti ucyate
translated: A person who delights in unwholesome things is called an evil friend.

analyzed: ityādayaḥ upakleśāḥ
translated: These and others are secondary afflictions.

analyzed: kleśebhyaḥ utpanna tvāt
translated: Because they arise from afflictions.

analyzed: upakleśa vargaḥ catustriṃduttaraśatatamaḥ
translated: The chapter on secondary afflictions is the 430th.

analyzed: māna ādikam moha aṅgam

analyzed: atas na pṛthak ucyate

original: trayaḥ kleśā sāvānāṃ cetasi bhūyasā vartante /
analyzed: trayaḥ cetasi bhūyasā vartante

analyzed: na māna ādi

analyzed: na evam mada māna ādiḥ  rāge sati dveṣaḥ kuśala mūlam bhavati

analyzed: anuraktasya virodhe dveṣaḥ nupravartate

analyzed: mohaḥ tu dvayoḥ mūlam

analyzed: kasmāt

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre daśa akuśalakarmāṇi trividhāni lobha dveṣa moha jāni iti
translated: As it is said in the sutra, the ten unwholesome actions are of three kinds: born of greed, hatred, and delusion.

analyzed: na tu uktam māna ādi jāni iti

original: santi ca tisra eva vedanā na punarasti caturthī /
analyzed: santi ca tisraḥ eva vedanāḥ na punar asti caturthī

analyzed: yadi asti pṛthak māna ādiḥ
translated: If pride and so on exist separately,

analyzed: kasyām vedanāyām anuśayaḥ syāt

analyzed: tat vastutas nā abhidhātum śakyate
translated: It cannot be said that they exist as real entities.

analyzed: iti jñātavyam tāni trīṇi eva kleśa mūlāni iti

analyzed: kasmāt sukha vedanāyām rāgaḥ anuśayaḥ

analyzed: pratyakṣam hi tatra tasya utpattiḥ

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre sukha vedanīya sparśam labhamānasya bhavati prītiḥ

analyzed: duḥkha vedanīya sparśam labhamānasya bhavati aprītiḥ
translated: For one who obtains a contact that is to be experienced as pain, there is sorrow.

analyzed: tasya vedanānām udaya vyaya āsvāda ādīnava nissaraṇānām yathā bhūta aprajñānāt
translated: Because of not knowing as it really is the arising, passing away, enjoyment, danger, and escape of those feelings.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: aduḥkha asukha vedanāyām avidyā anuśayaḥ
translated: In the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant, ignorance is a latent tendency.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: na hi ayam ārūpya dhātu āptānām skandhānām santānam yathābhūtam prajānāti
translated: For he does not know the continuum of the aggregates belonging to the formless realm as it truly is.

original: tadā khalvasya tatra bhavati nirvāṇasaṃjñā vā vimuktisaṃjñā vā aduḥkhāsukhasaṃjñā vā ātmasaṃjñā vā /
analyzed: tadā khalu asya tatra bhavati nirvāṇa saṃjñā vā vimukti saṃjñā vā aduḥkha asukha saṃjñā vā ātma saṃjñā vā
translated: At that time, he has the notion of nirvana, the notion of liberation, the notion of neither-pain-nor-pleasure, or the notion of self there.

analyzed: atas uktam aduḥkha asukha vedanāyām mohaḥ anuśayaḥ bhavati iti
translated: Therefore it is said that delusion is an underlying tendency in the feeling of neither-pain-nor-pleasure.

original: pṛ anuśayāḥ kiṃ dharme'nuśerate ki vā sattve'nuśerate /
analyzed: anuśayāḥ kim dharmenuśerate kim vā sattvenuśerate

analyzed: dharmān upādāya sattva buddhiḥ bhavati
translated: The notion of a being arises based on dharmas.

analyzed: sattva buddhim anusṛtya vedanāḥ vedyante
translated: Feelings are experienced based on the notion of a being.

analyzed: vedanāḥ anusṛtya lobha ādayaḥ kleśa anuśayāḥ
translated: The underlying tendencies of defilements such as greed are based on feelings.

analyzed: atas jñāyate dharmān upādāya utpannaḥ anuśayaḥ sattve anuśete iti
translated: Therefore it is known that the underlying tendency that arises based on dharmas underlies beings.

original: kasmāt tat jñāyate /🔽yasya sattvasyāprahīṇaḥ so'nuśayaḥ tasya so'nuśayo'nuśete /
analyzed: kasmāt tat jñāyate  yasya sattvasya aprahīṇaḥ saḥ anuśayaḥ tasya saḥ anuśayaḥ anuśete
translated: Why is that known?🔽The underlying tendency that is not abandoned for a being underlies that being.

analyzed: yasya tu prahīṇaḥ na tasya anuśeta anuśayaḥ
translated: But for one whose underlying tendency is abandoned, the underlying tendency does not underlie.

analyzed: yadi
translated: If the underlying tendency is in the dharma,

analyzed: dharmāṇām nitya sattvāt anuśayāḥ nitya anuśayāḥ syuḥ
translated: since the dharmas always exist, the underlying tendencies would always underlie.

analyzed: nityasya a prahātavya tvāt
translated: Because what is always existent cannot be abandoned.

analyzed: a sattva saṃkhyātaḥ api sa anuśayaḥ syāt
translated: Even that which is not counted as a sentient being could have latent tendencies.

analyzed: tathā ced puruṣasya anuśayaḥ usti iti bhitti ādiḥ anuśayavān syāt
translated: If so, then the wall and so on would have latent tendencies, as the person does.

analyzed: puruṣasya vijñānam asti iti bhitti ādiḥ api vijñānavān syāt
translated: And the wall and so on would have consciousness, as the person does.

analyzed: na idam vastutas asti
translated: This is not actually so.

analyzed: tathā arhan na syāt
translated: In the same way, the Arhat would not be so.

original: anyeṣāṃ puruṣapudgalānāmanuśayo'stīti so'nuśayavānsyāt /🔽pṛ ayamanuśayaḥ aprahīṇaḥ san anuśete /
analyzed: anyeṣām puruṣa pudgalānām anuśayaḥ usti iti saḥ anuśayavān syāt  ayam anuśayaḥ aprahīṇaḥ san anuśete
translated: And others, other persons, would have latent tendencies, so they would have latent tendencies.🔽This latent tendency, existing unabandoned, lies latent.

analyzed: prahīṇaḥ san na anuśete
translated: Existing abandoned, it does not lie latent.

analyzed: u dvidhā anuśayaḥ unuśete
translated: The latent tendency lies latent in two ways.

analyzed: ālambanataḥ nuśayanam
translated: Lying latent as an object

analyzed: samprayogataḥ nuśayanam iti
translated: lying latent through association.

original: ayamanuśayo yadi prahīṇo yadi vā'prahīṇaḥ sa ālambanataḥ saṃprayogataśca /
analyzed: ayam anuśayaḥ yadi prahīṇaḥ yadi vā aprahīṇaḥ saḥ ālambanataḥ saṃprayogataḥ ca
translated: This latent tendency, whether abandoned or unabandoned, lies latent as an object and through association.

analyzed: kasmāt ucyate prahīṇaḥ san na anuśete iti
translated: Why is it said that existing abandoned, it does not lie latent?

analyzed: tathā ced tṛtīya anuśayana lakṣaṇam vaktavyam
translated: If so, then a third way of lying latent should be stated.

analyzed: anabhidhānāt jñātavyam na asti iti
translated: Because it is not mentioned, it should be known that it does not exist.

analyzed: anuśayaḥ bhūmi antara ālambanaḥ na anuśete
translated: The latent tendency that takes another realm as its object does not lie latent.

original: ato jñāyate sattvamātre'nuśayo na dharma iti /
analyzed: atas jñāyate sattva mātra inuśayaḥ na dharmaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is known that the latent tendency lies latent in sentient beings alone, not in dharmas.

analyzed: dvidhā anuśayaḥ unuśeta
translated: The latent tendency lies latent in two ways

analyzed: ālambanataḥ nuśayaḥ
translated: The latent tendency as an object

analyzed: samprayogataḥ nuśayaḥ iti
translated: By association, there is latent tendency.

analyzed: eṣām sattvānām anuśayāḥ na ālambanataḥ na samprayogataḥ
translated: The latent tendencies of these beings are not by object or by association.

analyzed: katham bhaviṣyati anuśayaḥ
translated: How will there be latent tendency?

analyzed: pratyukta pūrvam idam anuśayāḥ dharmam upādāya utpannāḥ sattvena anuśerate iti
translated: This has already been answered: The latent tendencies are produced in dependence on dharmas and adhere to beings.

analyzed: yathā uktam abhidharmakāya īkāmadhātuka sattvānām kati anuśayāḥ ityādi
translated: As it is said in the Abhidharma treatise: How many latent tendencies are there for beings in the desire realm? and so on.

analyzed: yadi sattveṣu na anuśayīran
translated: If they did not adhere to beings,

analyzed: katham etādṛśaḥ praśnaḥ syāt
translated: how could there be such a question?

analyzed: yadi anuśayaḥ sattve nuśete
translated: If a latent tendency adheres to a being,

original: sukhāyāṃ vedanāyāṃ rāgo'nuśaya iti sūtroktaṃ virudhyeta /
analyzed: sukhāyām vedanāyām rāgaḥ anuśayaḥ iti sūtra uktam virudhyeta

analyzed: u na idam pāryantikam vacanam
translated: This is not a final statement.

original: vaktavyaṃ khalu sukhāyāṃ vedanāyāṃ samutpanno rāgaḥ sattve'nuśeta iti /
analyzed: vaktavyam khalu sukhāyām vedanāyām samutpannaḥ rāgaḥ sattvena anuśete iti

analyzed: sa rāgaḥ rūpa ādīn upādāya api bhavati
translated: If attachment arises in relation to form and so on,

analyzed: kutas utra ucyate kevalam sukha vedanām upādāya bhavati iti
translated: how can it be said here that it arises only in relation to pleasant feeling?

original: u saṃjñānusmaraṇavikalpaprītyādinā rāga utpadyate na tu rūpādimātrāt /
analyzed: saṃjñā anusmaraṇa vikalpa prīti ādinā rāgaḥ utpadyate na tu rūpa ādi mātrāt

analyzed: duḥkha vedanām upādāya api rāgaḥ bhavati
translated: Attachment can also arise in relation to painful feeling.

original: yathā vadantisukhī na prārthayate duḥkhī tu bahu prārthayate /
analyzed: yathā vadanti sukhī na prārthayate duḥkhī tu bahu prārthayate
translated: As it is said: One who is happy does not desire, but one who is suffering desires much.

analyzed: kasmāt kevalam uktam sukha vedanātaḥ bhavati iti
translated: Why is it said that it arises only from the feeling of pleasure?

analyzed: u na duḥkha vedanayā rāgaḥ utpadyate
translated: Because attachment does not arise from the feeling of suffering.

original: duḥkhasya pīḍanātmakatvāt puruṣasya sukhāyāṃ vedanāyāmeva rāga utpadyate /
analyzed: duḥkhasya pīḍana ātmaka tvāt puruṣasya sukhāyām vedanāyām eva rāgaḥ utpadyate
translated: Because suffering has the nature of affliction, attachment arises for a person only in the feeling of pleasure.

analyzed: aduḥkha asukhāyām vedanāyām api rāga anuśayaḥ anuśete
translated: And the latent tendency of attachment lies dormant even in the feeling that is neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant.

analyzed: kasmāt uktam kevalam sukhāyām vedanāyām iti

original: u aduḥkhāsukhavedanāḥ sukharūpa tvāt tatra puruṣasya rāga utpadyate /

original: ata ucyate sukhāyāṃ vedanāyāṃ rāgānuśaya iti /

analyzed: tāsu triṣu vedanāsu trayaḥ kleśāḥ anuśayāḥ iti atas trayaḥ eva ucyante

analyzed: akuśalamūla vargaḥ pañcatriṃśat uttara śatatamaḥ

analyzed: saṅkīrṇa kleśa vargaḥ

analyzed: katame ime

analyzed: kāmadhātau avidyām varjayitvā anye sarve kleśāḥ kāma āsravāḥ iti ucyante

analyzed: evam rupa ārūpya dhātvoḥ bhava āsravaḥ

analyzed: traidhātukī ca avidyā avidyā āsravaḥ

analyzed: pṛ āsravāḥ katham vardhante

analyzed: uttama adhama dhyama dharmaiḥ kramaśas vardhante

analyzed: rūpa ādi viśiṣṭa ālambana lābhāt ca vardhante

analyzed: pṛ ime trayaḥ āsravāḥ
translated: These are the three outflows.

analyzed: katham vadanti sapta āsravāḥ iti

analyzed: vastutas āsravāḥ dvividhāḥ satya darśana heyāḥ ye āsravāṇām mūla bhūtāḥ

analyzed: bhāvanā heyāḥ ye āsravāṇām phala bhūtāḥ

analyzed: pañcabhiḥ ārā āsrava sahakāribhiḥ militvā sapta bhavanti
translated: They become seven by combining the five co-factors of the outflows with the outflows.

analyzed: te kleśāḥ eva
translated: They are just the afflictions.

analyzed: bhagavān arthataḥ āha trayaḥ āsravāḥ  catvāraḥ oghāḥ
translated: The Blessed One said in meaning: There are three outflows,🔽four floods,🔽four bonds,

analyzed: catvāraḥ bandhāḥ  catvāri upādānāni
translated: four clingings,

analyzed: catvāraḥ granthāḥ ityādi
translated: four knots, and so on.

original: pṛ catvāra oghāḥ kāmaugho bhavaugho dṛṣṭyodho'vidyaugha iti /
analyzed: catvāraḥ oghāḥ kāma oghaḥ bhava oghaḥ dṛṣṭi odhaḥ vidyā oghaḥ iti
translated: The four floods are the flood of desire, the flood of existence, the flood of views, and the flood of ignorance.

analyzed: katame ime
translated: Which are these?

analyzed: dṛṣṭim avidyām ca varjayitvā tad anye kāmadhātuka kleśāḥ sarve kāma oghaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Except for view and ignorance, all other afflictions belonging to the desire realm are called the flood of desire.

analyzed: rūpa ārūpyadhātuka bha baugha upi evam
translated: The floods of the form and formless realms are also like this.

analyzed: sarvāḥ dṛṣṭayaḥ dṛṣṭayā oghaḥ
translated: All views are the flood of views.

analyzed: avidyā avidyā oghaḥ
translated: Ignorance is the flood of ignorance.

analyzed: pṛ ogheṣu kasmāt dṛṣṭyā oghaḥ pṛthak ucyate
translated: Why is the flood of views explained separately among the floods?

analyzed: na āsraveṣu
translated: Not among the contaminants.

analyzed: u tīrthikāḥ bahavaḥ dṛṣṭi vāhitāḥ
translated: Because many non-Buddhists are carried away by views.

analyzed: atas ogheṣu pṛthak ucyate
translated: Therefore, it is explained separately among the floods.

analyzed: cyutim bahati iti oghaḥ
translated: It is a flood because it carries one to death.

analyzed: trīn bhavān badhnāti iti bandhaḥ
translated: It is a bond because it binds one to the three existences.

analyzed: catvāri upādānāni kāma upādānam dṛṣṭi upādānam śīla vrata upādānam ātma vāda upādānam iti
translated: There are four clingings: clinging to desire, clinging to views, clinging to morality and asceticism, and clinging to a doctrine of self.

analyzed: katamāni imāni
translated: What are these?

analyzed: ātmanobhāvāt tad vāda upādānam ātma vāda upādānam
translated: Because there is no self, clinging to that doctrine is clinging to a doctrine of self.

analyzed: asti ātmā iti bhavati ayam ātmā nityaḥ nityaḥ vā iti
translated: For one who sees that there is a self, there are two extremes: this self is either permanent or impermanent.

analyzed: anityaḥ iti avadhārayan pañca kāmaguṇān upādatte
translated: Determining it to be impermanent, one clings to the five sense pleasures.

analyzed: na asti para lokaḥ iti dṛṣṭa sukhaḥ āsajyate
translated: Thinking there is no afterlife, one is attached to pleasures seen in this life.

analyzed: nityaḥ iti avadhārayan manda indriyaḥ pāralaukika sukham ākāṃkṣamāṇaḥ śīla vratam upādatte
translated: The person of dull faculties, who determines that the self is permanent, and who desires happiness in the next world, undertakes morality and asceticism.

original: kiñcittīkṣṇendriya evaṃ cintayatiyadi jīvo nityaḥ tadā aduḥkhasukhavikāraḥ /
analyzed: kiñcid tīkṣṇa indriyaḥ evam cintayati yadi jīvaḥ nityaḥ tadā aduḥkha sukha vikāraḥ
translated: But the person of sharp faculties thinks thus: If the soul is permanent, then it is without the modifications of pain and pleasure.

analyzed: tadā puṇya pāpa abhāvāt iti mithyādṛṣṭim utpādayati
translated: Then, because of the absence of merit and demerit, he generates a false view.

analyzed: evam ātma vādam upādāya eva catvāri upādānāni bhavanti
translated: Thus, taking up the doctrine of self, there are four clingings.

original: pṛ catvāro granthāḥ abhidhyākāyagrantho vyāpādaḥ kāyagranthaḥ śīlavrataparāmarśaḥ kāyagranthaḥ idaṃ satyābhiniveśaḥ kāyagrantha iti /

translated: The four knots are: the knot of covetousness in the body, the knot of ill-will in the body, the knot of clinging to rules and rituals in the body, and the knot of false view in the body.

analyzed: katame ime
translated: What are these?

analyzed: u para dravya abhidhyayā anyasmin a dadati dveṣa buddhim utpādayati
translated: Due to covetousness for another's property, one generates a mind of hatred towards another.

analyzed: kaśā śastra ādinā gṛhṇāti
translated: One takes it by means of a whip, a weapon, etc.

analyzed: gṛhasthānām idam vigraha mūlam
translated: This is the root of disputes for householders.

analyzed: sukha anta nuvartanam iti ucyate
translated: It is called the continuation of happiness.

original: yaḥ śīlavrataparāmarśakaḥ kāmayate anena śīlavratena viśuddhiṃ labheya iti /
analyzed: yaḥ śīla vrata parāmarśakaḥ kāmayate anena śīla vratena viśuddhim labheya iti
translated: One who clings to rules and rituals desires: By this morality and asceticism, I will attain purification.

analyzed: tasya idam eva tathyam anyat mithyā iti dṛṣṭiḥ bhavati
translated: For him, this alone is true, and anything else is false. This is his view.

analyzed: idam pravrajitānām vivāda mūlam
translated: This is the root of disputes for those who have gone forth.

analyzed: duḥkhānta anuvartanam iti ucyate
translated: It is said to be following after the end of suffering.

analyzed: pañca skandhāḥ kāyaḥ iti ucyante
translated: The five aggregates are called the body.

original: catvāra ime granthā avaśyaṃ kāyavāṅmayā iti kāyagrantha ityucyante /
analyzed: catvāraḥ ime granthāḥ avaśyam kāya vāc mayāḥ iti kāya granthaḥ iti ucyante
translated: These four knots are necessarily bodily and verbal, so they are called bodily knots.

original: kecidāhuḥcatvāra ime dharmā jananamaraṇe saṅgra'thnantīti granthāḥ /
analyzed: kecid āhuḥ catvāraḥ ime dharmāḥ janana maraṇe saṅgrathnanti iti granthāḥ
translated: Some say: these four dharmas bind birth and death, so they are knots.

original: pṛ pañca nīvaraṇānikāmacchando vyāpādaḥ styānamiddhaṃ auddhatyakukṛtyaṃ vicikitsā ceti /
analyzed: pañca vyāpādaḥ styānam iddham auddhatya kukṛtyam vicikitsā ca iti
translated: The five hindrances are sensual desire, ill-will, sloth and torpor, restlessness and worry, and doubt.

analyzed: katamāni imāni
translated: What are these?

analyzed: u puruṣasya kāmeṣu abhiniveśāt vyāpādaḥ nuvartate
translated: Due to a person's attachment to sensual pleasures, ill-will follows.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtretṛṣṇātaḥ utpadyate vyāpādaḥ
translated: As it is said in the sutra: ill-will arises from craving.

original: īrṣyādayaḥ kleśāḥ kaśāśastrādiduścaritāni ca kāmacchandādutpadyante iti /
analyzed: īrṣyā ādayaḥ kleśāḥ kaśā śastra ādi duścaritāni ca kāma chandāt utpadyante iti
translated: Jealousy and other defilements, and misconduct with whips, weapons, etc., arise from sensual desire.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ yam kāya cittayoḥ rāga dveṣa parikṣipyamāṇayoḥ bahu vyāpāraiḥ paricchinnayoḥ ca styānam iddham icchati
translated: This person, with body and mind tossed about by attachment and aversion, and with many activities, desires sloth and torpor.

original: styānamiddhena kiñcidviśramya punā rāgadveṣavikṣiptacitto na dhyānasamādhiṃ labhate /
analyzed: styānam iddhena kiñcid viśramya punar rāga dveṣa vikṣipta cittaḥ na dhyāna samādhim labhate
translated: Having rested a little with sloth and torpor, he again does not attain meditative concentration due to his mind being tossed about by attachment and aversion.

analyzed: cittasya bāhya ālambana anuvartanāt auddhatyam bhavati
translated: Restlessness arises from the mind following external objects.

original: aśuddhakarmakasya puruṣasya citte sadā daurmanasyakaukṛtyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: aśuddha karmakasya puruṣasya citte sadā daurmanasya kaukṛtyam bhavati
translated: For a person of impure action, there is always sorrow and regret in the mind.

analyzed: vikṣipta citta tvāt kaukṛtya citta tvāt ca sadā vicikitsate vimuktiḥ asti na vā iti
translated: Because of the distracted mind and the mind of regret, one always doubts whether liberation exists or not.

analyzed: yathā rāja kumāra ūciravatam śramaṇa uddeśam avocat
translated: Just as Prince Achiravata said to the novice monk.

original: pṛ kasmānnīvaraṇamityākhyā /🔽u kāmacchando vyāpādaśca śīlaskandhaṃ nivṛṇutaḥ /
analyzed: kasmāt nīvaraṇam iti ākhyā  u kāma chandaḥ vyāpādaḥ ca śīla skandham nivṛṇutaḥ
translated: Why are they called hindrances?🔽Desire for sensual pleasures and ill-will obstruct the aggregate of morality.

analyzed: auddhatya kukṛtyam samādhi skandham nivṛṇoti
translated: Restlessness and regret obstruct the aggregate of concentration.

analyzed: sthānam ittham prajñā skandham
translated: Doubt obstructs the aggregate of wisdom.

original: kecit teṣāṃ nīvaraṇānāṃ varjanāya vadanti idaṃ kuśalamidamakuśalamiti /
analyzed: kecid teṣām nīvaraṇānām varjanāya vadanti idam kuśalam idam akuśalam iti
translated: Some, for the avoidance of those hindrances, say this is wholesome, this is unwholesome.

original: sa tatra vicikitsate kimasti kiṃ vā nāstīti /
analyzed: sa tatra vicikitsate kim asti kim vā na asti iti
translated: He doubts there, whether it exists or not.

analyzed: sā vicikitsā siddhā skandha trayam nivṛṇoti
translated: That doubt, being established, obstructs three aggregates.

original: eṣu pañcasu nīvaraṇeṣu trīṇi dṛḍhabalānīti kevalaṃ nīvaraṇamityucyante /
analyzed: eṣu pañcasu nīvaraṇeṣu trīṇi dṛḍhabalāni iti kevalam nīvaraṇam iti ucyante
translated: Among these five hindrances, three are called hindrances only because they are strong.

original: anye dve nīvaraṇe tanubale iti dvau dharmau sāṃsargikau /
analyzed: anye dve nīvaraṇe tanu bale iti dvau dharmau sāṃsargikau
translated: The other two hindrances are weak, so two dharmas are associated.

original: ime dve nīvaraṇe jananakāraṇasahite ityataḥ sāṃsargike ityucyeta /
analyzed: ime dve nīvaraṇe janana kāraṇa sahite iti atas sāṃsargike iti ucyeta
translated: These two hindrances are said to be associated because they are accompanied by the causes of origination.

analyzed: styānam iddhasya pañca dharmāḥ pratyayāḥ yat uta cāñcalyam aratiḥ vijṛmbhikā
translated: There are five factors for sloth and torpor: restlessness, lack of delight, yawning,

analyzed: āhāremātra tā cetasaḥ uvalīna tā iti
translated: overeating, and mental depression.

analyzed: auddhatya kaukṛtyasya catvāraḥ dharmāḥ pratyayāḥ jñāti vitarkaḥ janapadaḥ vitarkaḥ maraṇa vitarkaḥ
translated: And for restlessness and remorse, there are four factors: thoughts about relatives, thoughts about one's homeland, thoughts about immortality,

analyzed: pūrva tanīna krīḍita sukhita ālāpita hasita anusmaraṇam iti
translated: and remembering past play, happiness, conversation, and laughter.

analyzed: imāni janana kāraṇāni
translated: These are the causes of origination.

analyzed: pratipakṣaḥ api samānaḥ  styānam iddhasya prajñā pratipakṣaḥ
translated: The counteraction is the same.🔽The counteraction to sloth and torpor is wisdom.

analyzed: auddhatya kukṛtyasya samādhiḥ pratipakṣaḥ
translated: The counteraction to restlessness and remorse is concentration.

analyzed: nivāraṇam api samānam
translated: The prevention is also the same.

analyzed: ime dve sāṃsargike nīvaraṇe
translated: These two hindrances are associated.

analyzed: ime pañca dharmāḥ nīvaraṇāni vā bhavanti
translated: These five factors may be hindrances

analyzed: anīvaraṇāni vā bhavanti
translated: or they may not be hindrances.

analyzed: kāmadhātu āptāḥ akuśalāḥ nīvaraṇāni
translated: Those that are unwholesome and pertain to the desire realm are hindrances.

analyzed: anyātrā nīvaraṇāni
translated: The others are not hindrances.

original: pañcāvarabhāgīyeṣu saṃyojaneṣu kāmacchando vyāpādaḥ śīlabrataparāmarśaḥ avaragamanārthatvādavarabhāgīyāni /
analyzed: pañca avarabhāgīyeṣu saṃyojaneṣu kāma chandaḥ vyāpādaḥ śīla brata parāmarśaḥ avara gamana artha tvāt avarabhāgīyāni
translated: In the five lower fetters, sensual desire, ill-will, clinging to rules and rituals, and doubt are called lower fetters because they lead to lower realms.

original: tadyathā govratikaḥ saṃsiddhaḥ kāyasya bhedātparaṃ maraṇāt gavāṃ sahavyatāmupapadyate /
analyzed: tat yathā govratikaḥ saṃsiddhaḥ kāyasya bhedāt param maraṇāt gavām sahavya tām upapadyate
translated: For example, a cow-herder, having attained perfection, upon the dissolution of the body after death, is reborn among cows.

analyzed: a saṃsiddhaḥ narake patati
translated: One who has not attained perfection falls into hell.

analyzed: vicikitsā vairāgyasya vighna bhūtā
translated: Doubt is an obstacle to detachment.

analyzed: satkāyadṛṣṭiḥ caturṇām mūlam
translated: And the view of the transitory collection is the root of the four.

analyzed: iti imāni pañca
translated: Thus, these are the five.

analyzed: kāma chanda vyāpādau kāmadhātoḥ na ativartete
translated: Sensual desire and ill-will do not transcend the desire realm.

analyzed: sat kāya dṛṣṭiḥ ātma buddheḥ na ativartate
translated: The view of the transitory collection does not transcend the notion of a self.

analyzed: śīla vrata parāmarśaḥ uvara dharmāt na ativartate
translated: Clinging to rules and rituals does not transcend inferior teachings.

analyzed: vicikitsā pṛthagjana tvāt na ativartate
translated: Doubt does not transcend the state of being an ordinary person.

analyzed: kāmacchanda vyāpādau kāmadhātum na atikrāmataḥ
translated: Sensual desire and ill-will do not go beyond the desire realm.

analyzed: atikrame punar ākṣipyate
translated: Even if they go beyond, they are drawn back.

analyzed: anyāni trīṇi pṛthagjana tvam na atikrāmanti
translated: The other three do not go beyond the state of being an ordinary person.

analyzed: atas ucyantevarabhāgīyāni iti
translated: Therefore, they are called lower fetters.

analyzed: pañca ūrdhvabhāgīyāni auddhatyam mānovidyā rūparāgaḥ arūparāgaḥ
translated: The five higher fetters are restlessness, conceit, ignorance, attachment to form, and attachment to formlessness.

analyzed: auddhatyasya dhyāna samādhi vidhāti tvāt na cittam upaśāmyati
translated: Because restlessness disturbs the practice of meditation and concentration, the mind does not become calm.

analyzed: idam auddhatyasya nimitta graha anuvartanāt mānaḥ pravartate
translated: Because of grasping at signs, pride arises.

analyzed: nimitta grāhi cittam idam avidyā sambhūtam iti atas rūparāga urūparāgaḥ ca staḥ
translated: This mind that grasps at signs arises from ignorance. Therefore, there is attachment to form and attachment to the formless.

analyzed: tāni pañca saṃyojanāni śaikṣa janānām ūrdhva samudācaraṇa artha tvāt ūrdhvabhāgīyāni iti ucyante
translated: Those five fetters are called higher fetters because they cause those in training to continue to act in higher realms.

original: tāni śaikṣajanānāṃ citta ucyante na pṛthagjanānām /
analyzed: tāni śaikṣa janānām citte ucyante na pṛthagjanānām
translated: They are said to be in the minds of those in training, not of ordinary people.

original: pṛ auddhatyaṃ kasmāt rūpārūpyadhātukaṃ saṃyojanaṃ na kāmadhātukam /
analyzed: auddhatyam kasmāt rūpa ārūpya dhātukam saṃyojanam na kāmadhātukam
translated: Why is restlessness a fetter belonging to the form and formless realms, not to the desire realm?

analyzed: tatra sthūla kleśa abhāvāt auddhatyam vyaktam bhavati
translated: Because gross afflictions do not exist there, restlessness is manifest.

analyzed: tat auddhatyam samādhi bhaṅge balavat iti atas saṃyojanam iti ucyate
translated: That restlessness is powerful in breaking concentration, therefore it is called a fetter.

analyzed: tad ūrdhva bhāgīyam samucchedayataḥ vimuktiḥ labhyate
translated: Liberation is attained by completely cutting off that which belongs to the higher realms.

original: keṣāñcit rūpe ārūpye ca vimuktisaṃjñā bhavati /
analyzed: keṣāñcid rūpe ārūpye ca vimukti saṃjñā bhavati
translated: Some have the notion of liberation in the form and formless realms.

analyzed: tat pratiṣedhāya ucyate santi ūrdhvabhāgīyāni saṃyojanāni iti
translated: To refute that, it is said that there are fetters belonging to the higher realms.

analyzed: pañca mātsaryāṇi āvāsa mātsaryam
translated: There are five kinds of stinginess: stinginess about dwelling place,

analyzed: kula mātsaryam
translated: Stinginess about family.

analyzed: lābha mātsaryam
translated: Stinginess about gain.

analyzed: varṇa mātsaryam dharma mātsaryam iti
translated: Stinginess about praise. Stinginess about the Dharma.

original: tatra āvāsamātsaryamahameva atra vasāmīti nānyān prayojayati /
analyzed: tatra āvāsa mātsaryam aham eva atra vasāmi iti na anyān prayojayati
translated: Among them, stinginess about dwelling means that one does not engage others, thinking I alone should dwell here.

analyzed: kula mātsaryam kulam idam aham eva praviśāmi iti na anyān prayojayati
translated: Stinginess about family means that one does not engage others, thinking I alone should enter this family.

analyzed: satsu api anyeṣu aham eva utkṛṣṭaḥ iti
translated: Even when others exist, one thinks I alone am superior.

original: lābhamātsaryamitiahamevātra dānaṃ lapsya mānyebhyaḥ prayacchatu iti /
analyzed: lābha mātsaryam iti aham eva atra dānam lapsye mā anyebhyaḥ prayacchatu iti
translated: Stinginess about gain means that one thinks I alone should receive this gift here, let others give to me.

analyzed: anye santyaḥ api mā mām atikrāmantu
translated: One thinks Let others exist, but let them not surpass me.

analyzed: varṇa mātsaryam mām eva varṇaya mā anyān
translated: Stinginess about praise means Praise me alone, not others.

analyzed: anyān varṇayan api mā mām atiricyatu iti
translated: Even if one praises others, one thinks Let them not surpass me.

analyzed: dharma mātsaryam aham eva dvādaśa aṅga pravacana artham jānāmi
translated: Stinginess about the Dharma means I alone know the meaning of the twelve-limbed teaching.

analyzed: gabhīram artha rahasyam jānan api na pravadāmi iti
translated: Even if one knows the profound secret meaning, one does not speak.

analyzed: pṛ pañca mātsaryāṇām ke doṣāḥ
translated: What are the faults of these five kinds of stinginess?

original: u ima āvāsādayo bahūnāṃ puruṣāṇāṃ sādhāraṇāḥ /
analyzed: u ime āvāsa ādayaḥ bahūnām puruṣāṇām sādhāraṇāḥ
translated: These dwellings and so on are common to many people.

analyzed: sva kulam tyaktvā sādhāraṇa bhūteṣu mātsaryam utpādayati
translated: But this one, abandoning his own family, produces stinginess towards those who are common.

analyzed: iti ayam doṣa kleśaḥ
translated: This is the fault of affliction.

analyzed: sa vimukteḥ na eva bhāgī bhavati
translated: He is not a partaker of liberation.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: sa sādhāraṇa bhūtān dharmān eva na tyajati
translated: He does not abandon even the common dharmas,

original: kaḥ punarvādaḥ svīyān pañca skandhān tyajatīti /
analyzed: kaḥ punarvādaḥ svīyān pañca skandhān tyajati iti
translated: what to speak of abandoning his own five aggregates.

analyzed: sa ca preta ādīnām durupapatti āyataneṣu patati
translated: And he falls into the realms of pretas and others, which are difficult to attain.

analyzed: lābha nivṛtta cittasya mānaḥ utpadyate
translated: For one whose mind is turned away from gain, pride arises.

analyzed: sat janān anyān laghūkṛtya narake patati
translated: Despising other good people, he falls into hell.

analyzed: anyebhyaḥ dāna bhaṅgāt manuṣya deham lābhamānaḥ daridraḥ bhavati
translated: Due to breaking giving to others, obtaining a human body, he becomes poor.

original: mātsaryacittena dātarguṇaṃ pratigrahīturdeyañca samucchedayatītyato gurutaraṃ pāpaṃ labhate /
analyzed: mātsarya cittena dātar guṇam pratigrahītuḥ deyam ca samucchedayati iti atas gurutaram pāpam labhate
translated: With a mind of stinginess, he cuts off the virtue of the giver and the gift to be received. Therefore he obtains a heavier sin.

analyzed: dharma matsara undha ādi pāpa bhāj bhavati
translated: One who is stingy with the Dharma becomes a partaker of the sins of the blind and so on.

original: tadyathā jātyandhasya sapatnabahulānāñca janma na svātantrayaprāpakam /
analyzed: tat yathā jāti andhasya sapatna bahulānām ca janma na svātantraya prāpakam
translated: Just as the birth of a congenitally blind person and of those with many enemies does not bring about independence.

analyzed: ārya garbhāt ca parihīyate
translated: And he falls away from the womb of the noble ones.

original: triṣu adhvasu daśasu dikṣu gatānāṃ buddhānāṃ śatruḥ san saṃsāre saṃsaran sadā mūḍho bhavati /
analyzed: triṣu adhvasu daśasu dikṣu gatānām buddhānām śatruḥ san saṃsāre saṃsaran sadā mūḍhaḥ bhavati
translated: Being an enemy of the Buddhas who have gone to the three times and the ten directions, wandering in saṃsāra, he is always deluded.

analyzed: sat janān dūrīkaroti
translated: He keeps good people at a distance.

analyzed: sat jana dūrīkaraṇāt akuśalam vinā na vartate
translated: Due to keeping good people at a distance, he does not exist without unwholesome [actions].

analyzed: akuśalam trividham akuśala akuśalam mahā kuśalam akuśalam adhyākuśalam iti
translated: Unwholesome is threefold: unwholesome, very unwholesome, and moderately unwholesome.

analyzed: akuśalam prāṇa atipāta ādatta ādāna ādi
translated: Unwholesome means killing, stealing, etc.

analyzed: mahā kuśalam yat ātma hananam  parasti ātma hanana samādāpanam
translated: Very unwholesome means self-murder.🔽Encouraging others to commit self-murder.

analyzed: svayam mātsarya karaṇam parasya mātsarya samādāpanam
translated: Personally being stingy and encouraging others to be stingy.

analyzed: sa dharma mātsaryeṇa bahūn puruṣān ukuśale pātayati
translated: Out of stinginess for the Dharma, he causes many people to fall into unwholesomeness.

analyzed: buddha dharma mārgam ca kṣapayati
translated: And he destroys the path of the Buddha's teachings.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtre santyāvāsamātsaryasya pañca doṣāḥanāgatasya subhikṣorāgamanāya necchati /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre santi āvāsa mātsaryasya pañca doṣāḥ anāgatasya subhikṣoḥ āgamanāya na icchati
translated: As it is said in the sutra, there are five faults of stinginess in dwelling places: He does not want to bring in new prosperity.

analyzed: āgatam punar tarjayan na tṛpyati
translated: Having brought it in, he is not satisfied with threatening it.

analyzed: gamanāya anucintayati  saṅgha deyam gopayati
translated: He thinks about going away.🔽He hides what belongs to the Sangha.

analyzed: saṅgha deyeṣu ātmīya buddhim karoti
translated: He has the idea that what belongs to the Sangha is his own.

analyzed: kula mātsaryasya pañca doṣāḥ kula abhiniveśāt avadāta vasanaiḥ tulya sukha duḥkhaḥ bhavati  dhanāya avadāta vasanam prajahāti
translated: There are five faults of stinginess in families: Because of attachment to families, he has the same happiness and suffering as those wearing white robes.🔽He abandons the white-robed one for the sake of wealth.

analyzed: pratigrahītuḥ dānam labhate
translated: He receives gifts from the one who gives.

analyzed: tad ubhaya prahāṇāt tasmin kule varcaḥ kuṭyām bhūta tvāya utpadyate
translated: Because of the abandonment of both, one is born in that family to be a worm in the feces.

analyzed: lābha mātsaryasya pañca doṣāḥ sadā sambhāra sambhavāya klamati
translated: There are five faults of stinginess in gain: One always tires of accumulating provisions.

analyzed: dvayoḥ bhedena lābhī bhavati
translated: One becomes a recipient of two [kinds of] distinctions.

analyzed: sat janān nindati sadā daurmanasya cittaḥ
translated: One always criticizes good people with a dissatisfied mind.

original: varṇamātsaryasya pañca doṣāḥanyeṣāṃ varṇaṃ śrutvā vyākulakaṣāyacitto bhavati /
analyzed: varṇa mātsaryasya pañca doṣāḥ anyeṣām varṇam śrutvā vyākula kaṣāya cittaḥ bhavati
translated: There are five faults of stinginess in praise: Hearing the praise of others, one becomes agitated and defiled in mind.

analyzed: śata sahasreṣu lokeṣu aśuddha cittaḥ sat janān adhikṣipati
translated: In hundreds of thousands of worlds, with an impure mind, one reviles good people.

analyzed: ātma unnatyā parān avanamati
translated: One exalts oneself and belittles others.

analyzed: duryaśaḥ antardhāpayati iti
translated: One conceals one's bad reputation.

original: sarveṣāṃ mātsaryāṇāṃ sāmānyata ime doṣāḥ santiprabhūtadhanasañcayaḥ /
analyzed: sarveṣām mātsaryāṇām sāmānyatas ime doṣāḥ santi prabhūta dhana sañcayaḥ
translated: These faults are common to all kinds of stinginess: Accumulating a great deal of wealth.

analyzed: pariṣad bhīru tā
translated: Fear of assemblies.

analyzed: bahu jana vidveṣitā  sadā vyākula citta tā
translated: Being hated by many people.🔽Always having an agitated mind.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ sadā ekākitā
translated: Always being alone.

analyzed: avara kule janma iti evamādayaḥ upramāṇāḥ pañca mātsaryāṇām doṣāḥ
translated: Being born in a low family - these and other immeasurable faults are of the five kinds of stinginess.

original: pañca cetaḥ khilāḥihāyuṣmanto bhikṣuḥ śāstari vicikitsate /🔽dharme vicikitsate /
analyzed: pañca cetaḥ khilāḥ iha āyuṣmantaḥ bhikṣuḥ śāstari vicikitsate  dharme vicikitsate
translated: There are five mental disturbances: Venerable ones, here a monk doubts the teacher.🔽He doubts the Dharma.

analyzed: śīle vicikitsate
translated: He doubts the precepts.

analyzed: śikṣāyām vicikitsate
translated: He doubts the training.

analyzed: yaḥ bhikṣuḥ śāstuḥ mahāpuruṣāṇām ca varṇa vādī
translated: The monk who praises the Teacher and the great men.

analyzed: tasmin jane an ātta manāḥ āhata cittaḥ bhavati
translated: He becomes displeased and his mind is struck.

analyzed: ayam pañcamaḥ
translated: This is the fifth.

original: śāstari vicikitsaka evaṃ cintayatikiṃ śāstā mahān /
analyzed: śāstari vicikitsakaḥ evam cintayati kim śāstā mahān
translated: One who doubts the Teacher thinks like this: Is the Teacher great?

original: kiṃ vā pūraṇādayaḥ iti /🔽dharme vicikitsaka evaṃ cintayati kiṃ śāstuḥ pravacanamutkṛṣṭamuta vedasyeti /
analyzed: kim vā pūraṇa ādayaḥ iti  dharme vicikitsakaḥ evam cintayati kim śāstuḥ pravacanam utkṛṣṭam uta vedasya iti
translated: Or are Pūraṇa and others?🔽One who doubts the Dharma thinks like this: Is the Teacher's teaching superior or the Veda?

analyzed: śīle vicikitsate kim śāstṛ proktam pravacanam utkṛṣṭam
translated: He doubts the morality: Is the teaching proclaimed by the Teacher superior?

analyzed: kim vā kukkaṭa śva ādi vratam iti
translated: Or is the vow of a cock, dog, etc.?

original: śikṣāyāṃ vicikitsate kiṃ mānapānādi dharmo nirvāṇaṃ gamayati uta neti /

original: anāttamanā āhata citto vyāpādabuddhyā bhayagauravacittaṃ vinā sajjanān garhayati /
analyzed: an ātta manāḥ cittaḥ vyāpāda buddhyā bhaya gaurava cittam vinā sat janān garhayati
translated: Without a mind of fear or respect, he reproaches the good people with a mind of ill-will.

analyzed: ebhiḥ pañcabhiḥ dharmaiḥ vipralupta cittaḥ

analyzed: na nānā kuśala indriyāṇi avaṣṭambhayati
translated: He does not firmly grasp the various wholesome faculties.

analyzed: atas ca itas khilaḥ iti ucyate

analyzed: kasmāt śāstra ādau vicikitsate

translated: He doubts because he has not heard much.

analyzed: bahuśrutasya tu vicikitsā ālpīyasī bhavati
translated: But for one who has heard much, doubt is small.

original: sa ca bālo mūḍho'jño na tathāgatadharmānyadharmayorvivekaṃ prajānāti /

translated: And that fool, ignorant, does not know the distinction between the Tathāgata's Dharma and other Dharmas.

analyzed: atas vicikitsate

analyzed: dharme ca na āsvādam labhate
translated: And he does not attain taste in the Dharma.

analyzed: a taḥ ca
translated: And for that reason,

analyzed: vicikitsate
translated: he doubts.

original: na ca vedadīn granthān śṛṇoti adhyeti vā /

analyzed: janaiḥ varṇitam śrutvā utkṛṣṭa cittam utpādayati

analyzed: yathā śāstuḥ upasthāyakaḥ su nakṣatraḥ

original: kiñca vedavyākaraṇādīni mithyādṛṣṭisūtrāṇyadhīyānaḥ paribhinnasamyakprajño bhavati ityato vicikitsate /

original: pañca cetaso vinibandhāḥyaḥ kāyo'vigatarāgo sa kāya āsajyate /

analyzed: kāmeṣu a vīta rāgaḥ kāmeṣu āsajyate

analyzed: gṛhasthena prabrajitasya samāgamaḥ

analyzed: ārya vacane cetaḥ na prahṛṣyati

analyzed: alpa hita vastunā ātmānam pūrṇam manyate

analyzed: tatra catvāraḥ vinibandhāḥ kāma rāgam upādāya udbhavanti

analyzed: yaḥ ādhyātmika ātma bhāve vigata rāgaḥ sa bāhya rūpa ādi kāmeṣu āsajyate

analyzed: atas ubhayoḥ samāgamam abhilaṣati

original: abhilāṣāvyākulatayā āryavacane upaśamapradarśane dharme na prahṛṣyati /

translated: Due to being disturbed by desire, he does not rejoice in the Dharma that shows tranquility in the words of the noble ones.

original: ataḥ śīlabāhuśrutyadhyānasamādhyādiṣvalpaṃ hitaṃ vastu labdhvā tenātmānaṃ pūrṇaṃ manyate /
analyzed: atas śīla bāhu śruti adhyāna samādhi ādiṣu alpam hitam vastu labdhvā tena ātmānam pūrṇam manyate
translated: Therefore, having obtained a small beneficial thing such as morality, much learning, meditation, concentration, and so on, he considers himself fulfilled by that.

analyzed: tat alpa hita vastu abhiniveśāt mahā hitam vismarati

analyzed: prājñaḥ tu na alpa hita abhiniviṣṭaḥ mahā hitam vighnayet

original: ayaṃ yadyaṣṭākṣaṇavihīnaḥ saḥ puruṣakāyaṃ duṣkaraṃ labdhvavānityataścittaikāgryeṇa vīryamārabheta /

translated: If he is not devoid of the eight unfavorable conditions, having obtained with difficulty a human body, he should therefore arouse effort with single-minded concentration.

analyzed: alpa hitam a kāmayamānaḥ pravrajyā phala vipākam labhate

analyzed: mriyamāṇaḥ ca na vipratisarati

analyzed: svapa rahitam ca karoti  sa guṇeṣu eva na abhiniviśate

analyzed: kaḥ punar vāda okuśale dharme

analyzed: atas sa samyak ācāraḥ iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, he is called one of right conduct.

analyzed: pṛthagjana ādīnavāḥ na kim api saṃkleśayanti
translated: The faults of ordinary people do not at all disturb him.

analyzed: pṛ ke pṛthagjanānām ādīnavāḥ
translated: The faults of ordinary people.

analyzed: sarve mārgāḥ vivṛtāḥ

analyzed: katham idam
