analyzed: atas na anitya saṃjñā kāma rāgam vināśayati
translated: Therefore, the perception of impermanence does not destroy sensual desire.

analyzed: kecid anityam iti jānantaḥ vadha ādikam api kurvanti
translated: Some, knowing that it is impermanent, also commit murder and so on.

original: yāvattiryañcaḥ anityamiti jānanto'pi na kleśān bhindanti /
analyzed: yāvat tiryañcaḥ anityam iti jānantaḥ api na kleśān bhindanti
translated: Even animals, knowing that it is impermanent, do not destroy the defilements.

analyzed: atonitya saṃjñām bhāvayataḥ na kaścid upakāraḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, for one who cultivates the perception of impermanence, there is no benefit at all.

analyzed: anitya tvāt viyoga duḥkham utprekṣamāṇaḥ subhikṣa kāla sukha jīvita dhana mānāni tyajanti
translated: One who contemplates the suffering of separation due to impermanence abandons the pleasures of a time of plenty, a happy life, and wealth.

analyzed: viduṣaḥ na anena prīti cittam utpadyate
translated: The wise man does not arouse the mind of delight on account of this.

analyzed: prīti citta abhāve na kāma cittam utpadyate
translated: In the absence of the mind of delight, the mind of lust does not arise.

analyzed: vedanām pratītya hi tṛṣṇā bhavati
translated: For, thirst arises on the basis of feeling.

analyzed: vedanā nirodhe tṛṣṇā nirudhyate
translated: In the absence of feeling, thirst ceases.

analyzed: atas jñāyate anitya saṃjñā kāma rāgam samucchedayati eva
translated: Therefore, it is evident that the impermanence-notion alone cuts lust.

original: yaśca dharmo'nityaḥ /🔽so'nātmā ityanityamanātma ca bhāvayato yogino nātmabuddhirbhavati /
analyzed: yaḥ ca dharmaḥ nityaḥ  saḥ u na ātmā iti anityam anātma ca bhāvayataḥ yoginaḥ na ātma buddhiḥ bhavati
translated: The dharma which is impermanent is non-soul.🔽The ascetic who cultivates the impermanence and non-soul-notions does not arouse the soul-notion.

analyzed: ātma buddhi abhāve ātmīya buddhiḥ na bhavati
translated: In the absence of the soul-notion, he does not arouse the notion of what belongs to the soul.

analyzed: ātmīya buddhi abhāvāt kutra kāma rāgaḥ syāt
translated: Where would the lust arise in the absence of the notion of what belongs to the soul?

original: anityasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayan svaparakāyaṃ kṣaṇikaṃ maraṇadharma ca paśyati /
analyzed: anitya saṃjñām bhāvayan sva para kāyam kṣaṇikam maraṇa dharma ca paśyati
translated: The ascetic contemplating on the impermanence-notion sees his own body and others’ body as momentary and subject to death.

analyzed: katham rāgam utpādayet
translated: How would he arouse lust?

analyzed: yogī prārthitam sarvam anityam vipralopanam iti anuyāti
translated: The ascetic follows all the desired things as impermanent and perishable.

analyzed: tadā tuccham bhavati
translated: Then they become void.

analyzed: tuccha tvāt na kāma rāgam utpādayati
translated: Being void, he does not arouse lust.

original: yathā kaścidvālakaḥ śūnye hastaḥ tuccha iti jñātvaiva na tatrasaṅgaṃ janayati /
analyzed: yathā kaścid vālakaḥ śūnye hastaḥ tucchaḥ iti jñātvā eva na tatrasaṅgam janayati
translated: For example, a boy knowing that the void hand is void does not arouse attachment towards it.

analyzed: kiñca sattvāḥ na adhruva vastuṣu prīyante
translated: The living beings do not delight in the impermanent things.

original: yathā kaścit bhaṅguratvāt bhājane na pramudyate /
analyzed: yathā kaścid bhaṅgura tvāt bhājane na pramudyate
translated: Just as someone, due to impermanence, does not rejoice in a vessel.

original: yathāpi ca kācinnārī amukasya puruṣasyāyurna saptadinānyeṣyatīti śrutvā vadati satsvapi subhikṣakālārjavabahumānadhanaprabhāvabaleṣu ko vā prīyeta iti /
analyzed: yathā api ca kācid nārī amukasya puruṣasya āyuḥ na sapta dināni eṣyati iti śrutvā vadati satsu api subhikṣa kāla ārjava bahu māna dhana prabhāva baleṣu kaḥ vā prīyeta iti
translated: Just as a certain woman, having heard that the life of a certain man will last only seven days, says: Even when there are good times, honesty, great respect, wealth, power, and strength, who would rejoice?

analyzed: samyak anitya saṃjñā bhāvanayā na kāma rāgam utpādayati
translated: This person, by properly cultivating the perception of impermanence, does not give rise to sensual desire.

analyzed: vidvān hi punarāvṛtti patana ādi duḥkham anusmaran yāvat divya kāmeṣu api na āsajyate
translated: For the wise one, remembering the suffering of returning, falling, and so on, does not become attached even to the divine sensual pleasures.

analyzed: kevala muktim eva prārthayate
translated: He only aspires for complete liberation.

analyzed: anitya saṃjñā kāma rāgam vardhayati iti yat bhavān avocat tat ayuktam
translated: What you said that the perception of impermanence increases sensual desire is not correct.

analyzed: yadi kaścid a prahīṇa asmimānaḥ bhavati
translated: If someone has not abandoned pride,

original: tadā sa bāhyaṃ vastvanityaṃ paśyan śocyate /
analyzed: tadā sa bāhyam vastu anityam paśyan śocyate
translated: then he, seeing external things as impermanent, becomes sorrowful.

analyzed: ca kāma prārthatām karoti
translated: And due to the loss of the power of what is dear, he desires sensual pleasures.

analyzed: pṛthagjanaḥ yam prahīṇa kāma sukhaḥ api na viyoga duḥkham prajānāti
translated: This ordinary person, even though he has abandoned sensual pleasures and happiness, does not understand the suffering of separation.

analyzed: tat yathā kaścid bālakaḥ mātrā tāḍitaḥ punar mātaram eva āyāti
translated: For example, a certain child, beaten by his mother, returns to his mother again.

original: vidvāṃstu duḥkhahetau sthita eva na duḥkhaṃ nirodhyamiti jñātvā tyajati duḥkhahetuṃ yaduta pañcaskandhān /
analyzed: vidvān tu duḥkha hetau sthitaḥ eva na duḥkham nirodhyam iti jñātvā tyajati duḥkha hetum yat uta pañca skandhān
translated: But the wise one, knowing that suffering arises from the cause of suffering, abandons the cause of suffering, namely the five aggregates.

original: ayaṃ yogī ābhyantaraskandhān paribhettuṃ anātmasaṃjñāṃ pratilabhate /
analyzed: ayam yogī ābhyantara skandhān paribhettum anātma saṃjñām pratilabhate
translated: This yogi, in order to destroy the internal aggregates, attains the perception of non-self.

analyzed: bāhya vastu vināśe pi na śokena pīḍyate
translated: Even when external things are destroyed, he is not afflicted by sorrow.

original: anātmapratilābhī kiṃ punaḥ prārthayīta anityasajñyapi na kiñcitprārthayate /
analyzed: anātma pratilābhī kim punar prārthayīta anitya sajñī api na kiñcid prārthayate
translated: One who has attained the perception of non-self, what else would he wish for? Even one with the perception of impermanence does not wish for anything.

analyzed: anitya saṃjñā ca iyam yadi duḥkhena ātma saṃjñām na utpādayati
translated: If this perception of impermanence does not give rise to the perception of suffering and non-self,

analyzed: tadā sā kleśa vināśana sampannā na bhavati
translated: then it is not endowed with the ability to destroy the defilements.

original: ata uktaṃ sūtreekāgreṇa cittena pañcaskandhānanityān bhāvayet /
analyzed: atas uktam sūtre ekāgreṇa cittena pañca skandhān anityān bhāvayet
translated: Therefore it is said in the sutra: With a one-pointed mind, one should contemplate the impermanence of the five aggregates.

original: ya ādhyātmikān skandhān aparibhidya bahirdhā vastu anityaṃ paśyati /
analyzed: yaḥ ādhyātmikān skandhān a paribhidya bahirdhā vastu anityam paśyati
translated: One who does not destroy the internal aggregates, but sees external things as impermanent,

analyzed: tasya sātma saṃjña tvāt śokaḥ utpadyate
translated: because of the perception of self, gives rise to sorrow.

analyzed: tadā iyam asamyak bhāvanā bhavati
translated: That is an incorrect contemplation.

analyzed: anityam iti paśyatām api na nirveda virāgaḥ utpadyate
translated: Even those who see as impermanent do not give rise to disgust and detachment,

analyzed: yathā aurabhrika vyādha ādīnām
translated: like butchers, hunters, and so on.

original: eṣāṃ satyapi anityajñāne na sādhubhāvanā bhavati /
analyzed: eṣām sati api anitya jñāne na sādhu bhāvanā bhavati
translated: Even though they have the knowledge of impermanence, they do not cultivate it well.

analyzed: kaścid samyak bhāvayan api na anavaratam bhāvanām vyavasyati
translated: Even if someone cultivates it correctly, they do not constantly apply the cultivation.

analyzed: tasya kāma cittam ante viparyasyati
translated: At the end, their mind of desire becomes inverted.

analyzed: atas ucyate ekagra citta iti
translated: Therefore it is said to be with a one-pointed mind.

analyzed: kiñca kaścid anitya saṃjñām alpa kālam bhāvayati
translated: Moreover, someone cultivates the perception of impermanence for a short time.

analyzed: kleśāḥ tu bahavaḥ
translated: But the afflictions are many.

analyzed: na tān paribhettum alam bhavati
translated: They are not able to overcome them.

analyzed: yathā alpam auṣadham bahvīḥ vyādhīḥ na vināśayati
translated: Just as a small amount of medicine does not destroy many diseases,

analyzed: tathā idam api
translated: so is this.

original: ata ucyateekāgracittena anityamiti samyambhāvanā kleśān vināśayati / iti / iti /
analyzed: atas ucyate ekāgra cittena anityam iti samyak bhāvanā kleśān vināśayati iti iti
translated: Therefore it is said that the cultivation of impermanence with a one-pointed mind destroys the afflictions.

analyzed: dharmāḥ anityāḥ iti jñānam eva tattva jñānam
translated: The knowledge that dharmas are impermanent is itself the knowledge of reality.

original: sati tattvajñāne na bhavanti kāmādayaḥ kleśāḥ /
analyzed: sati tattva jñāne na bhavanti kāma ādayaḥ kleśāḥ
translated: When there is the knowledge of reality, the afflictions such as desire do not arise.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: avidyā pratyaya tvāt kāma ādīnām
translated: Because desire and so forth are conditioned by ignorance.

analyzed: iti anitya saṃjñā na kāma rāga saṃvardhanī iti veditavyam
translated: Thus it should be known that the perception of impermanence does not increase sensual desire.

analyzed: kiñca anitya saṃjñā sarvān kleśān upaśamayati
translated: Moreover, the perception of impermanence completely pacifies all the afflictions.

analyzed: yogī yadi prajānāti vastu idam anityam iti
translated: If a yogi knows that this thing is impermanent,

original: na tadā tatrasakāmo bhavati /🔽puruṣo'yamavaśyaṃ mariṣyatīti prajānan kasmai dviṣyāt /
analyzed: na tadā tatrasa kāmaḥ bhavati  puruṣaḥ ayam avaśyam mariṣyati iti prajānan kasmai dviṣyāt
translated: At that time, he does not have any desire for it.🔽Understanding that this person will certainly die, to whom should one have hatred?

analyzed: kaḥ sa cetanaḥ mriyamāṇam dviṣyāt
translated: What sentient being would hate one who is dying?

analyzed: yadi dharmāḥ anityāḥ
translated: If dharmas are impermanent,

analyzed: katham tatas uddhata saṃjñām utpādayet
translated: how can one generate the notion of elevation from them?

original: dharmā anityā iti jñānānna moha utyadyate /
analyzed: dharmāḥ anityāḥ iti jñānāt na mohaḥ utyadyate
translated: From the knowledge that dharmas are impermanent, delusion is not produced.

analyzed: moha anudayāt na vicikitsā ādayaḥ bhavanti
translated: From the non-arising of delusion, doubt and so forth do not arise.

analyzed: atas jñāyate anitya saṃjñā kleśānām virodhinī iti
translated: Therefore, it is known that the notion of impermanence is contrary to the defilements.

analyzed: anitya saṃjñā vargaḥ trisaptatti uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: The ninety-third chapter on the section on the notion of impermanence.

analyzed: duḥkha saṃjñā vargaḥ
translated: The Section on the Notion of Suffering

analyzed: yaḥ dharmaḥ bādhā ātmakaḥ tat duḥkham iti ucyate
translated: The dharma that has the nature of obstruction is called suffering.

analyzed: tat trividham duḥkha duḥkham vipariṇāma duḥkham saṃskāra duḥkham iti
translated: It is of three kinds: suffering of suffering, suffering of change, and suffering of the conditioned.

original: pratyutpanne vastuto duḥkhaṃ yadasiśastrādi tad duḥkhaduḥkham /
analyzed: pratyutpanne vastutaḥ duḥkham yat asi śastra ādi tat duḥkha duḥkham
translated: The present thing that is actually suffering, such as a sword or weapon, is the suffering of suffering.

analyzed: priyāṇām punar bhāryā ādīnām viyoga kāle yat bhavati duḥkham
translated: The suffering that arises when there is separation from loved ones such as a wife,

analyzed: idam vipariṇāma duḥkham
translated: this is the suffering of change.

original: śūnyānātmajñānalābhino yaccittaṃ bhavati saṃskṛtadharmāḥ sarve viheṭhanā iti /
analyzed: śūnya anātma jñāna lābhinaḥ yat cittam bhavati saṃskṛta dharmāḥ sarve viheṭhanāḥ iti
translated: For one who has attained the knowledge of emptiness and non-self, the mind becomes, All conditioned dharmas are afflictions.

analyzed: tad saṃskāra duḥkham
translated: That is the suffering of formations.

analyzed: tad duḥkha anuyāyi cittam duḥkha saṃjñā
translated: And the mind that follows that suffering is the perception of suffering.

original: pṛ duḥkhasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayatā kiṃ hitaṃ labhyate /
analyzed: duḥkha saṃjñām bhāvayatā kim hitam labhyate
translated: What benefit is obtained by one who cultivates the perception of suffering?

analyzed: duḥkha saṃjñāyām phalāt nirvedaḥ bhavati
translated: From the fruit of the perception of suffering, detachment arises.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

original: na hi duḥkhasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayitā kāmaprītiṃ sevate /
analyzed: na hi duḥkha saṃjñām bhāvayitā kāma prītim sevate
translated: One who cultivates the perception of suffering does not enjoy sensual pleasures.

analyzed: tad prīti abhāvāt na tṛṣṇā bhavati
translated: Due to the absence of that pleasure, craving does not arise.

analyzed: yogī yadi dharmāḥ duḥkham iti prajānāti
translated: If the yogi understands that dharmas are suffering,

analyzed: tadā na saṃskārān anubhavati
translated: then he does not experience formations.

original: dharmā anityā anātmakā api na duḥkhajanakāḥ tadā naiva tyājyāḥ /
analyzed: dharmāḥ anityāḥ anātmakāḥ api na duḥkha janakāḥ tadā na eva tyājyāḥ
translated: Dharmas that are impermanent and non-self are not producers of suffering, then they are not to be abandoned.

analyzed: duḥkha tvāt tu tyājyāḥ
translated: But they are to be abandoned because they are suffering.

analyzed: duḥkha tyāgāt vimucyate
translated: By abandoning suffering, one is liberated.

original: sarve sattvā atitarāṃ bhītā bhavanti yadidaṃ duḥkhamiti /
analyzed: sarve sattvāḥ atitarām bhītāḥ bhavanti yat idam duḥkham iti
translated: All beings are extremely afraid of this, namely suffering.

original: yadi taruṇo vṛddho vā pāmaraḥ paṇḍito vā āḍhyo daridro vā jānāti idaṃ duḥkhalakṣaṇamiti /
analyzed: yadi taruṇaḥ vṛddhaḥ vā pāmaraḥ paṇḍitaḥ vā āḍhyaḥ daridraḥ vā jānāti idam duḥkha lakṣaṇam iti
translated: If a young person, an old person, a fool, a wise person, a rich person, or a poor person knows this characteristic of suffering,

analyzed: tadā sarve te nirviṇṇāḥ bhavanti
translated: then all of them become disgusted.

original: sarve yogacāriṇaḥ puruṣā nirvāṇe śāntopaśamasaṃjñotpādakā bhavanti /
analyzed: sarve yoga cāriṇaḥ puruṣāḥ nirvāṇe śānta upaśama saṃjñā utpādakāḥ bhavanti
translated: All yogis and practitioners produce the perception of nirvana as peaceful and calm.

analyzed: sarveṣām saṃsāre duḥkha saṃjñā utpādanāt
translated: Because the perception of suffering is produced in the world for all.

analyzed: kena idam jñāyate
translated: How is this known?

analyzed: ye sattvāḥ kāmadhātu āpta duḥkha upadrutāḥ bhavanti
translated: Those beings who are afflicted by suffering in the sphere of desire

analyzed: te prathama dhyāne śānta saṃjñām utpādayanti
translated: generate the notion of peace in the first meditation.

analyzed: evam bhava agra duḥkha upadrutāḥ nirvāṇe śānta saṃjñām utpādayanti
translated: In the same way, those afflicted by suffering in the peak of existence generate the notion of peace in nirvana.

analyzed: saṃsāreḥ asti avadyam yat uta duḥkham
translated: There is a fault in samsara, namely suffering.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtra iyat rūpaṇam anityam duḥkham vipariṇāma dharma
translated: As it is said in the sutra: Whatever form is impermanent, suffering, and subject to change,

analyzed: ayam rūpasya ādīnavaḥ iti
translated: this is the danger in form.

analyzed: avidyayā abhiniviṣṭam idam duḥkham
translated: This suffering is clung to by ignorance.

analyzed: kena idam jñāyate
translated: How is this known?

analyzed: sattvānām paramārthataḥ duḥkhe sukha saṃjñā utpādāt
translated: Because beings generate the notion of pleasure in suffering due to ultimate reality.

analyzed: parama duḥkha saṃjñā utpādanāt tu nirvidyante
translated: But by generating the notion of supreme suffering, they become disgusted.

original: ato bhagavānāhaye duḥkhaṃ budhyanti teṣāmahaṃ duḥkhamāryasatyaṃ vyākaromi iti /
analyzed: atas bhagavān āha ye duḥkham budhyanti teṣām aham duḥkham ārya satyam vyākaromi iti
translated: Therefore the Blessed One said: For those who understand suffering, I declare the noble truth of suffering.

analyzed: tatra bhagavān loka satyam upādāya imam artham prakāśayati
translated: There, the Blessed One elucidates this meaning by taking up worldly truth.

original: sarvadevamanuṣyāṇāṃ yatra sukhasaṃjñā bhavati /🔽tatra mama śrāvakā duḥkhasaṃjñāmutpādayanti /
analyzed: sarva deva manuṣyāṇām yatra sukha saṃjñā bhavati  tatra mama śrāvakāḥ duḥkha saṃjñām utpādayanti
translated: Where there is the notion of pleasure for all gods and humans,🔽there my disciples generate the notion of suffering.

analyzed: utpanna duḥkha saṃjñāḥ nirvidyante iti
translated: Having generated the notion of suffering, they become disgusted.

analyzed: parama moha padam yat duḥkhe sukha saṃjñā utpādanam
translated: The highest state of delusion is the production of the notion of pleasure in pain.

original: anayā saṃjñayā ca sarvasattvānāṃ saṃsāre yātāyātānāṃ mānasaṃ kliśyati /
analyzed: anayā saṃjñayā ca sarva sattvānām saṃsāre yāta āyātānām mānasam kliśyati
translated: By this notion, the minds of all beings who have gone and come in saṃsāra are afflicted.

analyzed: duḥkha saṃjñā pratilābhinaḥ tu mucyante
translated: But those who attain the notion of suffering are liberated.

analyzed: caturbhiḥ āhāraiḥ ca ūrdhva deham samāpadyate
translated: And one attains an upper body with the four nutriments.

analyzed: tatra duḥkha saṃjñayā āhārān prajahāti  yathā putra māṃsa khādanam
translated: There, by the notion of suffering, one abandons the nutriments.🔽As if eating one's son's flesh.

analyzed: yathā vā niścarma go bhakṣaṇam  yathā aṅgāra karṣu bhakṣaṇam
translated: Or as if eating a cow without its hide.🔽As if eating a burning charcoal pit.

analyzed: yathā śakti śata dhārā avalepanam
translated: As if anointing with a hundred sharp-edged razors.

analyzed: tathābhūteṣu āhāreṣu sarvam duḥkha arthakam
translated: In such nutriments, everything has the meaning of suffering.

analyzed: tathā duḥkha saṃjñayā āhārān prajahāti
translated: Thus, by the notion of suffering, one abandons the nutriments.

original: duḥkhasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayato mano na catasṛṣu vijñānasthitiṣu sukhaṃ viharati sarvatra duḥkhadarśitvāt /
analyzed: duḥkha saṃjñām bhāvayataḥ manaḥ na catasṛṣu vijñāna sthitiṣu sukham viharati sarvatra duḥkha darśi tvāt
translated: For one who cultivates the notion of suffering, the mind does not dwell happily in the four abodes of consciousness, because it sees suffering everywhere.

original: yathā mugdhāḥ śalabhāḥ sukhasaṃjñayā pradīpe patanti /
analyzed: yathā mugdhāḥ śalabhāḥ sukha saṃjñayā pradīpe patanti
translated: As if foolish insects fall into a lamp with the notion of pleasure.

analyzed: vidvān agniḥ dahati iti jñātvā tam parīharati
translated: The wise one, knowing that fire burns, avoids it.

analyzed: prākṛtāḥ api tathā avidyā mohāt ūrdhva deha agnau patanti
translated: The ordinary ones also, due to ignorance and delusion, fall into the fire of the upper body.

analyzed: vidvān tu duḥkha saṃjñayā vimucyate
translated: But the wise one is liberated by the notion of suffering.

analyzed: sarvam ca traidhātukam duḥkham duḥkha samudayaḥ
translated: And all the three realms are suffering and the origin of suffering.

analyzed: duḥkhā vedanā duḥkham
translated: Painful feeling is suffering.

analyzed: duḥkha janakam duḥkha samudayaḥ
translated: What causes suffering is the origin of suffering.

analyzed: idānīm aduḥkham api avaśyam cirāt duḥkham janayati
translated: Now, even what is not suffering necessarily generates suffering after a long time.

analyzed: atas loke sarvam duḥkham iti bhāvayet
translated: Therefore, one should contemplate that everything in the world is suffering.

analyzed: nirviṇṇa cittāḥ dharmān vedayantaḥ vimucyante
translated: Having experienced the dharmas with a mind of disgust, one is liberated.

analyzed: duḥkha saṃjñā vargaḥ catussaptati uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: The ninety-seventh chapter on the notion of suffering.

analyzed: an ātma saṃjñā vargaḥ
translated: The Chapter on the Notion of Non-Self

original: yogī sarve dharma bhaṅgavipariṇāmalakṣaṇā iti paśyati /
analyzed: yogī sarve dharma bhaṅga vipariṇāma lakṣaṇāḥ iti paśyati
translated: The yogi sees all dharmas as having the characteristics of disintegration and transformation.

original: yasmin rūpe āttmatayābhiniviśate idaṃ rūpaṃ vipariṇāmadharma /
analyzed: yasmin rūpe āttma tayā abhiniviśate idam rūpam vipariṇāma dharma
translated: In whatever form one becomes attached to as the self, that form has the nature of transformation.

analyzed: tad vipariṇāma dharma jñānāt ātma cittam pariharati
translated: By knowing that it has the nature of transformation, one abandons the notion of self.

analyzed: tathā vedanā ādīn api
translated: Similarly, one should understand feeling and so on.

original: yathā kaścit girinirjharānuvāhito yatkiñcidavalambya tadvihāya mucyate /
analyzed: yathā kaścid giri nirjhara anuvāhitaḥ yat kiñcid avalambya tat vihāya mucyate
translated: Just as someone carried away by a mountain torrent, grasping at anything, is liberated by abandoning it,

analyzed: tathā yogyam pi tad ātma tayā kalpayati
translated: so the yogi imagines that as the self.

analyzed: tad vipariṇāma dharma dṛṣṭvā anātmakam prajānāti
translated: Seeing that it has the nature of transformation, one understands it to be non-self.

analyzed: atonātmakena ātma saṃjñām bhāvayati
translated: Therefore, he cultivates the perception of non-self in what is not the self.

original: pṛ anātmasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayan kiṃ hitaṃ labhate /
analyzed: an ātma saṃjñām bhāvayan kim hitam labhate
translated: What benefit does one obtain by cultivating the perception of non-self?

analyzed: anātma saṃjñā bhāvayitā duḥkha saṃjñām paripūrayati
translated: One who cultivates the perception of non-self fulfills the perception of suffering.

original: pṛthagjanā ātmasaṃjñayā paramārthato duḥkhe na duḥkhaṃ paśyanti /
analyzed: pṛthagjanāḥ ātma saṃjñayā paramārthataḥ duḥkhe na duḥkham paśyanti
translated: Ordinary people, due to the perception of self, do not see suffering as truly suffering in the ultimate sense.

original: anātmasaṃjñayā tu atyalpe'pi duḥkhe tadupaghātaṃ budhyate /
analyzed: anātma saṃjñayā tu ati alpe api duḥkhe tad upaghātam budhyate
translated: But with the perception of non-self, one recognizes the harm in even the slightest suffering.

analyzed: anātma saṃjñayā ca upekṣā cittam samudācarati
translated: And with the perception of non-self, the mind of equanimity arises.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: ātma saṃjñayā hi ātmā naśyet iti bibhyanti
translated: For they fear that the self might perish due to the perception of self.

original: yadi paramārthaṃ jānāti tadā hāyapati duḥkhamanātmakaṃ vināśyamiti /
analyzed: yadi paramārtham jānāti tadā duḥkham anātmakam vināśyam iti
translated: If one knows the ultimate truth, then one's suffering, which is non-self and perishable, would disappear.

analyzed: tadā samudācarati upekṣā
translated: Then equanimity arises.

analyzed: anātma saṃjñayā ca nitya sukham bhavati
translated: And with the perception of non-self, there is eternal bliss.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: sarvam anityam
translated: Everything is impermanent.

analyzed: tatra yadi ātmā ātmīya cittam utpādayati
translated: If one generates the thought of self and what belongs to the self in that [impermanent world],

analyzed: tadā ātmā na bhavet
translated: then the self would not exist.

analyzed: ātmīyam api na bhavet
translated: What belongs to the self would also not exist.

analyzed: sadā duḥkham eva asti iti vadet
translated: One would say that there is only constant suffering.

original: nāstyātmātmīyamiti cintayato dharmeṣu vinaṣṭheṣu na duḥkhamutpadyate /
analyzed: na asti ātma ātmīyam iti cintayataḥ dharmeṣu vinaṣṭheṣu na duḥkham utpadyate
translated: When one thinks that there is no self or what belongs to the self, no suffering arises when things are destroyed.

analyzed: anātma saṃjñayā ca yoginaḥ cittam viśudhyati
translated: And the yogi's mind becomes pure by the perception of non-self.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: sarve hi kleśāḥ ātma dṛṣṭi sambhūtāḥ
translated: Because all defilements arise from the view of self.

original: idaṃ vastu ātmano hitamityataḥ kāmarāga utpadyate /🔽idaṃ vastu ātmano'hitamityato dveṣapratitha utpadyate /
analyzed: idam vastu ātmanaḥ hitam iti atas kāma rāgaḥ utpadyate  idam vastu ātmanaḥ hitam iti atas dveṣa pratithaḥ utpadyate
translated: From the thought this thing is beneficial for the self, lust arises.🔽From the thought this thing is harmful for the self, hatred arises.

analyzed: anena ātmā eva abhimāna janakaḥ
translated: By this, the self itself becomes the generator of pride.

original: ahamāyuṣo'nte kariṣyāmi na kariṣyāmiti dṛṣṭivicikitsā bhavati /
analyzed: aham āyuṣaḥ unte kariṣyāmi na kariṣyāmi iti dṛṣṭi vicikitsā bhavati
translated: I will do it at the end of life, I will not do it - such views and doubts arise.

analyzed: evam ātmanā eva sarve kleśāḥ samudbhavanti
translated: Thus, all defilements arise only from the self.

analyzed: anātma saṃjñayā tu sarve kleśāḥ samucchidyante
translated: But by the perception of non-self, all defilements are completely cut off.

analyzed: kleśānām samucchedāt cittam viśudhyati
translated: By the cutting off of defilements, the mind becomes pure.

original: cittaviśuddhyā ca kāñcanaṃ loṣṭaṃ candanamasidhārāṃ praśaṃsāṃ nindāñca samaṃ manyate /
analyzed: citta viśuddhyā ca kāñcanam loṣṭam candanam asi dhārām praśaṃsām nindām ca samam manyate
translated: By the purity of mind, one considers gold, a clod of earth, sandalwood, a sword's edge, praise, and blame equally.

analyzed: priya vipriyaiḥ viviktam cittam su nivṛttam śāntam bhavati
translated: The mind, free from likes and dislikes, becomes well-restrained and tranquil.

analyzed: atas jñāyate na ātma saṃjñakasya cittam viśudhyati iti
translated: Therefore, it is known that the mind of one with the perception of non-self becomes pure.

analyzed: anātma saṃjñām vihāya na asti anyaḥ mārgaḥ vimukti prāpakaḥ
translated: Apart from the perception of non-self, there is no other path that leads to liberation.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: yadi ātma vādī prajānāti na asti ātmā na asta ātmīyam iti
translated: If one who speaks of the self understands that there is no self and no what belongs to the self,

analyzed: evam vyavasitam cittam utpādayan eva vimucyate
translated: and generates the mind resolved in this way, he is liberated even while generating it.

analyzed: mā evam kadācid anāt saṃjñayā punaḥkāma cittam utpadyate
translated: This is not so. Sometimes a mind of desire arises again due to the perception of non-self.

analyzed: yathā strī rūpe rāgaḥ
translated: Just as there is attachment to the form of a woman.

analyzed: tat sarvam anātma snehāt
translated: All that is due to affection for what is not the self.

analyzed: nairātmyam anusaran eva puṇya pāpam sañcinoti
translated: Following non-self, one accumulates merit and demerit.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: sva kāyasya upakāre pakāre vā na puṇya pāpam
translated: There is no merit or demerit in benefiting or harming one's own body.

analyzed: sa ātmaka cittaḥ kāma rāgam utpādayati
translated: One who has a self-centered mind generates desire for sensual pleasures.

original: svakāye puruṣasaṃjñāṃ parakāye ca strīsaṃjñāmutpādya tatra abhiniviśate /
analyzed: sva kāye puruṣa saṃjñām para kāye ca strī saṃjñām utpādya tatra abhiniviśate
translated: Generating the notion of a man in one's own body and the notion of a woman in another's body, one becomes attached to that.

analyzed: tad abhiniveśa utpādaḥ ca prajñaptyāḥ bhavati
translated: And that attachment arises through designation.

analyzed: tad lakṣaṇā eva prajñaptiḥ
translated: That itself is the characteristic of designation.

analyzed: atas na nairātmyam kāma citta janakam
translated: Therefore, non-self does not generate a mind of desire.

analyzed: anātma cittaḥ ca na karmāṇi sañcinoti
translated: And one with a non-self mind does not accumulate actions.

analyzed: yathā arhataḥ ūna ātma saṃjñayā na karmāṇi sañcīyante
translated: Just as for an arhat, actions are not accumulated through the perception of non-self.

analyzed: anātma saṃjñā iyam sarveṣām kleśānām karmaṇām ca samucchedinī
translated: This perception of non-self cuts off all afflictions and actions.

analyzed: atas tām bhāvayet
translated: Therefore, one should cultivate it.

analyzed: anātma saṃjñā vargaḥ pañcasaptati uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: Chapter on the Perception of Non-Self.🔽

analyzed: āhāre pratikūla saṃjñā vargaḥ
translated: Chapter 75: The Perception of Disgust towards Food

analyzed: sarvam duḥkha jananam āhāra kāmāt bhavati
translated: All sufferings arise from the desire for food.

analyzed: āhārāt ca maithuna rāgaḥ saha utpadyate
translated: And sexual desire arises together with food.

original: kāmadhātau yāni santi duḥkhāni sarvāṇi tāni annapāna maithunarāgaṃ pratītya bhavanti /
analyzed: kāmadhātau yāni santi duḥkhāni sarvāṇi tāni anna pāna maithuna rāgam pratītya bhavanti
translated: All the sufferings that exist in the desire realm arise in dependence on food, drink, and sexual desire.

analyzed: āhāra kāma samucchedāya pratikūla saṃjñām bhāvayet
translated: One should cultivate the perception of disgust in order to eliminate the desire for food.

original: yathā kalpādau sattvāḥ svargādāgatya loke'smin upapādukā abhūvan /🔽te prabhāsvarakāyāḥ khecarāḥ svatantrā bhūtvā pṛthivīrasamādāvaśnuvan /
analyzed: yathā kalpa ādau sattvāḥ svargāt āgatya loke ismin upapādukāḥ abhūvan  te prabhāsvara kāyāḥ khecarāḥ svatantrāḥ bhūtvā pṛthivī rasam ādau aśnuvan
translated: As at the beginning of the eon, beings descended from heaven and were born in this world.🔽They had luminous bodies, moved through the sky, were independent, and enjoyed the essence of the earth and so on.

analyzed: tad aśana bahulāḥ praṇaṣṭa pramā atiśayāḥ abhūvan
translated: As they became accustomed to that food, their extraordinary lifespan and beauty declined.

original: evaṃ krameṇa jarāvyādhimaraṇaśālinaḥ yāvadvatsaraśataṃ bhūyasā duḥkhaiḥ pīḍitāḥ /
analyzed: evam krameṇa jarā vyādhi maraṇa śālinaḥ yāvat vatsara śatam bhūyasā duḥkhaiḥ pīḍitāḥ
translated: In this way, they gradually became subject to old age, sickness, and death, and for more than a hundred years, they were afflicted by many sufferings.

original: āhārābhiniveśavaśāt sarve te tādṛśemyaḥ phalemyaḥ praṇaṣṭāḥ /
analyzed: āhāra abhiniveśa vaśāt sarve te tādṛśāḥ imyaḥ phalemyaḥ praṇaṣṭāḥ
translated: All of them were destroyed by the fruits of their attachment to food.

analyzed: atas āhāram yoniśas bhāvayet
translated: Therefore, one should contemplate food correctly.

analyzed: anna pāna abhiniveśāt maithuna rāgaḥ utpadyate
translated: From attachment to food and drink, sexual desire arises.

analyzed: tatonye kleśāḥ bhavanti
translated: Other defilements arise from that.

original: tebhyo'kuśalaṃ karma kurvanti akuśalakarmataḥ trīn doṣān vardhayitvā devamanuṣyāṇāmapakurvanti /
analyzed: tebhyaḥ kuśalam karma kurvanti akuśala karmataḥ trīn doṣān vardhayitvā deva manuṣyāṇām apakurvanti
translated: From them, they perform unwholesome actions. From unwholesome actions, having increased the three faults, they harm gods and humans.

original: tasmāt sarvāḥ kleśavipattaya āhārakāmāt bhavanti jarāvyādhimaraṇalakṣaṇāni annapānādhīnāni /
analyzed: tasmāt sarvāḥ kleśa vipattayaḥ āhāra kāmāt bhavanti jarā vyādhi maraṇa lakṣaṇāni anna pāna adhīnāni
translated: Therefore, all the calamities of defilements arise from the desire for food. Old age, disease, and death are characterized by being dependent on food and drink.

original: āhāro'yaṃ sthāne paramamabhiniveśayati /🔽kāmarāgo gururapi na puruṣaṃ kleśayati /
analyzed: āhāraḥ yam sthāne paramam abhiniveśayati  kāma rāgaḥ guruḥ api na puruṣam kleśayati
translated: This food causes attachment to the highest state.

analyzed: yathā āhāra kartā
translated: Even strong sexual desire does not torment a person as much as one who indulges in food.

original: yadi vā bālo vṛddho gṛhasthaḥ pravrajito vā anāhārapīḍito bhavati /
analyzed: yadi vā bālaḥ vṛddhaḥ gṛhasthaḥ pravrajitaḥ vā anāhāra pīḍitaḥ bhavati
translated: If a fool, an old man, a householder, or one who has gone forth is afflicted by hunger,

analyzed: āhāram imam bhuṅktvā anāsakta manāḥ bhavet
translated: having eaten this food, he would be free from attachment.

original: avirāgī atitarāṃ khidyate /🔽yathā asidhārāvalepanī /🔽yathā vā viṣasiktauṣadhasevakaḥ /
analyzed: avirāgī atitarām khidyate  yathā asi dhārā avalepanī  yathā vā viṣa sikta auṣadha sevakaḥ
translated: One who is not free from desire is tormented even more.🔽Like one who smears oneself with a sword's edge.🔽Or like one who uses medicine soaked in poison.

analyzed: yathā vā viṣa sarpa poṣakaḥ
translated: Or like one who nourishes a poisonous snake.

analyzed: atas bhagavān āha bhāvita cittaḥ idam āhārayet
translated: Therefore the Blessed One said: One should eat this food with a cultivated mind.

analyzed: na āhāra kāmāya tad duḥkha pīḍitaḥ syāt iti
translated: One should not be tormented by the suffering of desire for food.

analyzed: kecid tīrthikāḥ api niraśana vratam ācaranti
translated: Some non-Buddhists also practice the vow of fasting.

analyzed: atas bhagavān āhanāsya āhārasya upacchedāt vimucyate
translated: Therefore the Blessed One said: One is not liberated by cutting off this food,

analyzed: kintu yoniśas manasi kṛtvā āhārayet iti
translated: but by properly contemplating and consuming it.

original: ye samucchinnāhārāḥ teṣāṃ kleśā na kṣīyante /
analyzed: ye samucchinna āhārāḥ teṣām kleśāḥ na kṣīyante
translated: For those who have cut off food, their defilements are not extinguished.

analyzed: ahitam tīvra maraṇam eva bhavati
translated: It becomes only a harmful and severe death.

analyzed: atas bhagavān āha āhāre ismin pratikūla saṃjñām janayet
translated: Therefore the Blessed One said: One should generate the perception of unpleasantness towards this food.

analyzed: na asti tatovadyam iti
translated: There is no fault in that.

analyzed: katham āhāre pratikūla saṃjñā kuryāt
translated: How should one generate the perception of unpleasantness towards food?

analyzed: u ayam
translated: This body is by nature unwholesome.

analyzed: atyuttaram asamāhāra phalam sarvam aśuci
translated: The fruit of excessive and improper combination is all impure.

analyzed: atas tatas nirvindyāt
translated: Therefore one should be disgusted with it.

analyzed: surabhi gandha madhura pāna bhojanāni śuci kāle eva kāyasya hita karāṇi
translated: Fragrant scents, sweet drinks and foods are beneficial to the body only when they are pure.

original: dantena carvitaṃ lālayā siktaṃ liṅgaṃ vāntavadāmāśayapatitaṃ kāyasya hitakaram /
analyzed: dantena carvitam lālayā siktam liṅgam vānta vat āmāśaya patitam kāyasya hita karam
translated: What is chewed with the teeth and moistened with saliva, falling into the stomach like vomit, is beneficial to the body.

analyzed: atas jñāyate aśuci iti
translated: Therefore it is known to be impure.

analyzed: idam anna pānam ajñānāt sukham
translated: This food and drink is pleasant due to ignorance.

original: yadi kaścinmadhuramāhāraṃ labhamāno'pi punarvāntaṃ na bhunakti /
analyzed: yadi kaścid madhuram āhāram labhamānaḥ api punar vāntam na bhunakti
translated: If someone, even when obtaining sweet food, does not eat it again if vomited,

analyzed: iti jñātavyam ajñāna balāt tat madhuram manyate iti
translated: it should be known that due to the power of ignorance one considers it sweet.

analyzed: āhāra pratyayam kṛṣi karma sevā arjanam saṃrakṣaṇam iti evañjātīya duḥkhāni anubhavati
translated: Due to food, one experiences sufferings such as farming, serving, earning, and preserving.

analyzed: tad pratyayam apramāṇāni pāpāni kurvanti
translated: Due to that, one commits immeasurable evil deeds.

analyzed: yat aśuci sarvam tat āhāra adhīnam
translated: Whatever is impure, all that depends on food.

analyzed: asati āhāre kena bhavanti tvak asthi rakta māṃsa uccāra ādīni aśucīni vastūni
translated: If there were no food, by what would impure things like skin, bones, blood, flesh, and excrement come to be?

analyzed: yāḥ durgatayoḥ varcaḥ kuṭī krimi ādayaḥ te sarve gandha rasa abhiniveśāt atra utpadyante
translated: Those who are born in bad destinies as worms in a latrine, etc., all of them are born there due to attachment to smell and taste.

original: yathoktaṃ karmavargeyastarṣito mriyate sa jalakrimibhāvenotpadyate /🔽nibiḍasthāne mṛtaḥ pakṣiṣūtpadyate /
analyzed: yathā uktam karma vargā iyaḥ tarṣitaḥ mriyate sa jala krimi bhāvena utpadyate  nibiḍa sthāne mṛtaḥ pakṣiṣu utpadyate
translated: As it is said in the Karmavarga: One who dies of thirst is born as a water worm.🔽One who dies in a crowded place is born among birds.

analyzed: maithuna rāgeṇa mṛtaḥ yonau utpadyate
translated: One who dies with sexual desire is born in a womb.

analyzed: iti evamādi
translated: And so on.

analyzed: yaḥ sa mahā sukham pratilabhate
translated: One who is free from this food attains great bliss.

analyzed: yathā rūpadhātau nirvāṇe ca utpadyate
translated: As in the form realm and in nirvana, one is born.

analyzed: āhāra anuvartanataḥ kṛṣṇa ādi duḥkham bhavati
translated: Due to following food, there is suffering beginning with black.

analyzed: evam āhāraḥ śuciḥ duḥkhaḥ iti dṛṣṭvā pratikūla saṃjñām bhāvayet
translated: Thus, seeing that food is impure and suffering, one should cultivate the perception of repulsiveness.

analyzed: āhāre pratikūla saṃjñā vargaḥ ṣaṭsaptati uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: Chapter 77: The Perception of Repulsiveness in Food.

analyzed: sarva loka inabhirati saṃjñā vargaḥ
translated: Chapter on the perception of dissatisfaction with all worlds

analyzed: yogī paśyati lokeṣu sarvam duḥkham
translated: The yogi sees all suffering in the worlds.

analyzed: citte ca na asti kiñcid sukham iti
translated: And there is no happiness at all in the mind.

original: ayañca yogī bhāvayati prītiviviktaṃ samādhiṃ tadyathā anātmasaṃjñāṃ duḥkhasaṃjñāmāhāre pratikūlasaṃjñāṃ maraṇasaṃjñām /
analyzed: ayam ca yogī bhāvayati prīti viviktam samādhim tat yathā anātma saṃjñām duḥkha saṃjñām āhāre pratikūla saṃjñām maraṇa saṃjñām
translated: And this yogi cultivates concentration free from joy, such as the perception of non-self, the perception of suffering, the perception of disgust towards food, the perception of death,

analyzed: ityādi
translated: and so on.

original: tadā tasya cittaṃ na sarvaloke'bhiramate /🔽api cāyaṃ paśyatiyatpriyaṃ tatkāmarāgavardhanam /
analyzed: tadā tasya cittam na sarva lokebhiḥ ramate  api ca ayam paśyati yat priyam tat kāma rāga vardhanam
translated: Then his mind does not delight in any world.🔽Moreover, he sees that what is pleasant increases desire and passion,

analyzed: yat vipriyam tat dveṣa pratigha vardhanam iti
translated: and what is unpleasant increases hatred and aversion.

analyzed: atas ubhayatra na abhiramate  dhanikasya pālana ādi duḥkham asti iti dṛśyate
translated: Therefore he does not delight in either.🔽It is seen that the rich have the suffering of guarding their wealth and so on.

analyzed: daridrasya ākiñcanya duḥkham dṛśyate  susthānikaḥ duḥsthāne patiṣyamāṇaḥ dṛśyate
translated: It is seen that the poor have the suffering of having nothing.🔽One in a good situation is seen falling into a bad situation.

analyzed: duḥsthānikaḥ dṛṣṭe duḥkhāni anubhavan dṛśyate
translated: One in a bad situation is seen experiencing sufferings in this life.

analyzed: pratyutpannaḥ dhanikaḥ uvaśyam patiṣyāmi
translated: The present rich man necessarily sees that he will fall.

analyzed: idam ca kāma ādīnām vihṛti sthānam iti prajānānaḥ dṛśyate
translated: And he is seen knowing that this is the place of enjoyment of desires and so on.

original: pratyutpanno daridro na pratyayopalabhyanirgama iti prajānānaḥ /
analyzed: pratyutpannaḥ daridraḥ na pratyaya upalabhya nirgamaḥ iti prajānānaḥ
translated: Knowing that the present is poor and that there is no escape from the conditions that are perceived.

analyzed: atas na sava lokebhiḥ amate
translated: Therefore, he does not delight in the world.

analyzed: alpatarāḥ ca sattvāḥ su sthāne utpannāḥ
translated: And fewer beings are born in good realms.

analyzed: bahutarāḥ durgatau patanti
translated: Many more fall into bad destinies.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtrealpatarāḥ susthāna utpadyante bahutarā dusthāna utpadyante /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre alpatarāḥ susthāne utpadyante bahutarāḥ dusthāne utpadyante
translated: As it is said in the sutra: Fewer are born in good realms, many more are born in bad realms.

analyzed: tad ādīnavam dṛṣṭvā nirvāṇam eva prārthayante
translated: Seeing that danger, they aspire only for nirvana.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: puruṣo'yaṃ paśyati kāmādayo doṣāḥ kleśāssadā santānamanuvartanta iti /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ yam paśyati kāma ādayaḥ doṣāḥ kleśāḥ sadā santānam anuvartante iti
translated: This man sees that desires and other faults, which are afflictions, always follow the continuum.

analyzed: yathā krodha asevī puruṣa uvakāśe labdhe punar badhyate
translated: Just as a person who serves anger is bound again when an opportunity is obtained.

analyzed: asmin vadhake katham abhirameta
translated: How can one delight in this killer?

analyzed: kleśāt utpannam akuśalam karma sadā anuvartamānam dṛśyate
translated: Unwholesome karma produced by afflictions is seen to always follow.

analyzed: na eva akuśala karma phalāt mucyate
translated: One is not released from the fruits of unwholesome karma.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre
translated: As it is said in the sutra

original: sa cettu pāpakaṃ karma kariṣyati karoṣi vā /
analyzed: sa ced tu pāpakam karma kariṣyati karoṣi vā
translated: If one were to do an evil deed, or if one does,

analyzed: na te duḥkhāt pramokaḥ usti
translated: There is no escape for you from suffering.

analyzed: utpātya api palāyataḥ iti
translated: Even if you run away after creating it.

analyzed: atas na abhiramate
translated: Therefore, he does not delight.

analyzed: jāti ādīni aṣṭa duḥkhāni sadā sukṛtinam anuvartante
translated: The eight sufferings beginning with birth always follow the virtuous person.

analyzed: kim punar pāpinam
translated: How much more so the sinful one?

analyzed: evam katham loke abhirameta
translated: How can one delight in the world in this way?

original: tadyathā āśīviṣakaraṇḍaḥ pañcokṣiptāsikā vadhakāḥ śūnye grāme coraḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā āśīviṣa karaṇḍaḥ pañca ukṣipta asikāḥ vadhakāḥ śūnye grāme coraḥ
translated: Like a basket of venomous snakes, like five murderers with uplifted swords, like a thief in an empty village.

analyzed: tādṛśāni avara tīrāṇi duḥkhāni sadā sattvān anuvartante
translated: Such extremely terrible sufferings always follow beings.

analyzed: katham tatra abhirameta
translated: How can one delight in that?

original: tadyathā lavaṇatiktatṛṣṇānadīvāhitaḥ pañcakāmaguṇaviṣaśalya viddhaḥ avidyāndhakārāṅgārakarṣau patitastādṛśāni duḥkhāni sattvānanuvartante
analyzed: tat yathā lavaṇa tikta tṛṣṇā nadī vāhitaḥ pañca kāmaguṇa viṣa śalya viddhaḥ avidyā andhakāra aṅgāra karṣau patitaḥ tādṛśāni duḥkhāni sattvān anuvartante
translated: Like one carried away by the river of craving for salt and bitter tastes, pierced by the poisoned arrows of the five sense objects, fallen into the charcoal of the darkness of ignorance, such sufferings follow beings.

analyzed: katham tatra abhirameta
translated: How can one delight in that?

analyzed: yogī upaśama sukham alpam vipatti kleśa duḥkhāni bahūni iti prajānāti
translated: The yogi understands that the happiness of tranquility is little, while the sufferings of misfortune and afflictions are many.

original: kasmāt / yasmāt pratidīnaṃ lokaistūyamānā vanaṣaṇḍaprasūtasphītaphalasamṛddhiśālino'pi bhūpā na dīrghakālasukhalābhino dṛśyante /
analyzed: kasmāt yasmāt pratidīnam lokaiḥ stūyamānāḥ vana ṣaṇḍa prasūta sphīta phala samṛddhi śālinaḥ api bhūpāḥ na dīrgha kāla sukha lābhinaḥ dṛśyante
translated: Why is it so? Because it is seen that even kings who are praised daily by the people and who possess abundant fruits and wealth produced in the forests do not attain long-lasting happiness.

analyzed: sukha sampraharṣiṇā ulpāḥ
translated: Those who are delighted by happiness are few.

analyzed: duḥkha vedinaḥ tu bahavaḥ
translated: But those who experience suffering are many.

analyzed: atas na sarva lokebhiḥ amate
translated: Therefore, he does not delight in the whole world.

original: pṛ saṃjñāmimāṃ bhāvayan kāni hitāni vindate /
analyzed: pṛ saṃjñām imām bhāvayan kāni hitāni vindate
translated: Cultivating this perception of foulness, what benefits does one obtain?

analyzed: nānāvidha loka lakṣaṇeṣu na cittam abhiniviśate
translated: One's mind does not become attached to the various characteristics of the world.

original: tāṃ saṃjñāṃ bhāvayatā kṣipraṃ mokṣo labhyate /
analyzed: tām saṃjñām bhāvayatā kṣipram mokṣaḥ labhyate
translated: Cultivating that perception, liberation is quickly attained.

analyzed: saṃsāre ca dīrgha kālam na tiṣṭhati
translated: And one does not remain long in saṃsāra.

analyzed: ayam yogī hitam jñānam vindate
translated: This yogi obtains beneficial knowledge.

analyzed: sadā sarvatra ādīnava bhāvi tvāt
translated: Because he always contemplates danger everywhere.

original: asya ca citte na kleśā udbhavanti /
analyzed: asya ca citte na kleśāḥ udbhavanti
translated: And defilements do not arise in his mind.

analyzed: udbhave vā āśu nirudhyante
translated: Or if they arise, they quickly cease.

analyzed: yathā tapta ayaḥ kapāle patitam jala bindu
translated: Like a drop of water fallen on a heated iron plate.

analyzed: yogī loke na abhiramate iti atas parama upaśamebhiḥ amate
translated: The yogi does not delight in the world, therefore he delights in supreme peace.

analyzed: yaḥ lokān nirviṇṇaḥ saḥ upaśame paramebhiḥ amate
translated: One who is disgusted with the world delights in supreme peace.

analyzed: tasmāt sarva lokena abhirati saṃjñām bhāvayet
translated: Therefore one should cultivate the perception of non-delight in the whole world.

analyzed: sarva loka nabhirati saṃjñā vargaḥ saptasaptati uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: The seventy-seventh chapter on the perception of non-delight in the whole world.

analyzed: aśubha saṃjñā vargaḥ
translated: The Chapter on the Perception of Foulness

analyzed: aśubha saṃjñām katham bhāvayet
translated: How should one cultivate the perception of foulness?

original: u yogī paśyati kāyasya bījamaśubhaṃ yaduta mātāpitoraśucimārgajaśukraśoṇitasaṅghātaḥ /
analyzed: yogī paśyati kāyasya bījam aśubham yat uta mātā pitoḥ aśuci mārga ja śukra śoṇita saṅghātaḥ
translated: The yogi sees the impure seed of the body, namely the aggregation of semen and blood produced from the impure paths of the mother and father.

analyzed: kāyaḥ yam aśucibhiḥ saṃsiddhaḥ yat uta jīrṇa āhāra prasveda prasnigdhaḥ
translated: This body is composed of impurities, namely, old food, sweat, and grease.

original: upapattisthānañcāśuci yaduta mātuḥ kukṣau paripūrṇamaśuci bhavati /
analyzed: upapatti sthānam ca aśuci yat uta mātuḥ kukṣau paripūrṇam aśuci bhavati
translated: And the place of birth is impure, namely, in the mother's womb it is completely impure.

analyzed: viṣ mūtra ādi aśuci padārthāḥ sambhūya kāyam kurvanti
translated: Feces, urine, and other impure substances come together to form the body.

analyzed: navasu dvāreṣu sadā aśucīni sravanti
translated: In the nine orifices, impure things always flow out.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam yatra nikṣipyate tat eva sthānam amaṅgalam aśuci
translated: The place where this body is discarded is itself inauspicious and impure.

original: annaṃ pānaṃ vastraṃ puruṣakāyagataṃ parīhitaṃ sarvaṃmaśuci bhavati /
analyzed: annam pānam vastram puruṣa kāya gatam parīhitam sarvaṃm aśuci bhavati
translated: Food, drink, and clothing worn on the human body all become impure.

analyzed: pareṣām dūṣaṇañca bhavati
translated: And it becomes a source of disgust for others.

analyzed: kāyasya asya padārthaḥ sarvaḥ ūśuciḥ
translated: All the components of this body are impure.

analyzed: yathā snāna jalam yadi vā snāna pātra ādi
translated: Like bath water or a bath vessel, etc.

analyzed: kāya uttham keśa nakha śiṅkhāṇa śleṣma ādi sarvam aśuci
translated: Hair, nails, teeth, saliva, mucus, etc. from the body are all impure.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca mṛta kāya uśucitaḥ
translated: And the dead body is seen to be impure.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam mriyamāṇaḥ kim anyaḥ bhavati
translated: When this body dies, does it become something else?

analyzed: āditas ārabhya ayam aśuciḥ iti veditavyam
translated: It should be known that from the beginning it is impure.

analyzed: jāyamānaḥ tu ātma buddhi viparyayāt śuciḥ iti ucyate
translated: But the one being born is said to be pure due to the reversal of the notion of self.

analyzed: mṛta spṛṣṭī aśuciḥ bhavati
translated: One becomes impure by touching a dead body.

analyzed: keśa nakha ādi sadā mṛta vastu
translated: Hair, nails, etc. are always dead things.

analyzed: apramāṇāḥ mṛta krimayaḥ ca sadā kāyam spṛśanti
translated: And countless dead worms always touch the body.

analyzed: atas jñātavyam kāyaḥ ayam āditas ārabhya aśuciḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it should be known that this body is impure from the very beginning.

original: aśucilūkṣāmakṣikāmaśakādayaḥ sarvā aśucikrimayaḥ sarvadāgatya kāyaṃ spṛśantītyaścāśuciḥ /
analyzed: aśuci lūkṣā makṣikā maśaka ādayaḥ sarvāḥ aśuci krimayaḥ sarvadā āgatya kāyam spṛśanti iti aḥ ca aśuciḥ
translated: Because all impure worms such as flies, mosquitoes, etc. always come and touch the body, it is impure.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam varcaḥ kuṭī vat sadā aśuci pūrṇaḥ
translated: This body is always full of impurities like a pile of excrement.

analyzed: tat pratītya varcaḥkuṭyām sahasradhā krimayaḥ bhavanti
translated: Based on that, worms are born in a pile of excrement in a thousand ways.

analyzed: tathā ayam kāyaḥ api
translated: This body is also like that.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam śmaśāna samaḥ
translated: This body is like a charnel ground.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: mṛta kāyasya hi sthānam śmaśānam iti ucyate
translated: Because a place where dead bodies are kept is called a charnel ground.

analyzed: ayam bahu ayaḥ mṛta krimayaḥ utra tiṣṭhanti
translated: In this body, many dead worms live.

analyzed: ayam kāya uśucim karoti
translated: This body makes things impure.

original: yāni śucisthānāni surabhikusumavastramālādīni tāni sarvāṇyetatkāyavaśādaśucīni bhavanti /
analyzed: yāni śuci sthānāni surabhi kusuma vastra mālā ādīni tāni sarvāṇi etad kāya vaśāt aśucīni bhavanti
translated: All pure places such as fragrant flowers, clothes, garlands, etc. become impure due to this body.

analyzed: brāhmaṇāḥ mṛta gṛhe prasūtikā gṛhe ca na āhāram upabhuñjanti
translated: Brahmins do not eat food in a place where a dead body or a childbirth has occurred.

analyzed: aśuci tvāt
translated: Because it is impure.

original: asmin kāye tu śatasahasradhā krimayaḥ sadā jāyante mriyante ca /
analyzed: asmin kāye tu śata sahasradhā krimayaḥ sadā jāyante mriyante ca
translated: In this body, worms are always born and die in a hundred thousand ways.

analyzed: tadā na upabhojya anna pānaḥ bhavet
translated: Then one should not eat food or drink.

analyzed: atas jñāyate śuciḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is known to be impure.

analyzed: loke ca narakam aśuci
translated: And in the world, hell is impure.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam krimi śata sahasrāṇām narakam
translated: This body is a hell for hundreds of thousands of worms.

analyzed: atośuciḥ
translated: Therefore, it is impure.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam sadā snānam apekṣate
translated: This body always requires bathing.

analyzed: yadi śuciḥ
translated: If it were pure,

analyzed: kimartham snānam apekṣate
translated: why would it require bathing?

original: surabhikusumagandhamālālaṅkṛto'yaṃ kāyaḥ iti veditavyaṃ kāyo'yaṃ svabhāvato'śuciriti /
analyzed: surabhi kusuma gandha mālā alaṅkṛtaḥ yam kāyaḥ iti veditavyam kāyaḥ iyam svabhāvataḥ śuciḥ iti
translated: This body is adorned with fragrant flowers, incense, and garlands. It should be known that this body is impure by nature.

analyzed: prajñaptyā śucibhiḥ bāhyaiḥ alaṅkriyate
translated: It is adorned with external pure things by designation.

analyzed: ayam manuṣya kāyaḥ paramam aśuciḥ
translated: This human body is extremely impure.

analyzed: yathā anyeṣām sattvānām carma roma nakha danta majja asthi māṃsāni kadācid upayujyante
translated: As the skin, hair, nails, teeth, marrow, bones, flesh of other beings are sometimes used,

analyzed: manuṣya kāye tu na ekam asti grāhyam
translated: but in the human body, not a single thing is acceptable.

analyzed: parama aśuci tvāt
translated: Because of its extreme impurity.

analyzed: yathā utpala padbha puṇḍarīka puṣpa ādīni aśuci sa bhūta tvāt aśucīni bhavanti
translated: Just as lotuses, lilies, and other flowers become impure due to their association with impure things,

analyzed: na tathā kāyaḥ iyam anya padārthaiḥ aśucīkriyate
translated: this body is not made impure by other things in the same way.

analyzed: prakṛtitaḥ eva aśuciḥ
translated: It is impure by nature itself.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam yadi śuciḥ
translated: If this body were pure,

analyzed: tadā na vastreṇa ācchādayet
translated: then it would not be covered with clothes.

analyzed: yathā puruṣaḥ vastra ācchādita mala rāśiḥ parān vañcayati
translated: Just as a man covered with a heap of dirt deceives others,

analyzed: tathā strī ācchādana ābharaṇa ācchādita kāyā puruṣam mohayati
translated: Similarly, a woman with her body covered with clothes and ornaments deludes a man.

analyzed: tathā puruṣaḥ api
translated: Similarly, a man also.

analyzed: atas jñātavyam aśuciḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it should be known that it is impure.

original: samantato'yaṃ kāyaḥ sadā aśuci nissārayati yaduta navarandhrāṇi aśucidvārāṇi romakūpeṣu ca naikamasti śuci /
analyzed: samantatoyam kāyaḥ sadā aśuci nissārayati yat uta nava randhrāṇi aśuci dvārāṇi romakūpeṣu ca na ekam asti śuci
translated: This body is always exuding impurity from all sides, namely from the nine orifices which are the doors of impurity, and there is not a single pore that is pure.

original: pṛ aśubhasaṃjñābhāvanā kasya hitasya lābhāya bhavati /
analyzed: aśubha saṃjñā bhāvanā kasya hitasya lābhāya bhavati
translated: For the attainment of what benefit does the cultivation of the perception of foulness occur?

analyzed: strī puruṣayoḥ śubha saṃjñayā kāma rāgaḥ utpadyate
translated: From the perception of beauty in a man and woman, lustful desire arises.

analyzed: tasmāt kāma rāgāt pāpakānām dvāram a prāvriyate
translated: From that lustful desire, the door to evil is opened.

analyzed: aśubha saṃjñā bhāvanāyāḥ tu kāma rāgāṇām nigrahaḥ bhavati
translated: But by the cultivation of the perception of foulness, lustful desires are restrained.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

original: ayaṃ hi kāyo durgandhamalairaśuciścarmāvṛtatvātparaṃ na jñāyate /
analyzed: ayam hi kāyaḥ durgandha malaiḥ aśuciḥ carma āvṛta tvāt param na jñāyate
translated: This body is impure with foul-smelling impurities, because it is covered by skin.

analyzed: vasana ācchādita aśuci rāśi ābhāsavat śuci priya vastu parivarjayet
translated: One should avoid things that are clean and pleasing, like a heap of impurities covered with clothes.

analyzed: yogī ca ayam vinīlaka lohitaka ādi saṃjñayā sarva kāyam paryādāti
translated: And this yogi pervades the whole body with the perception of lividity, blood, and so on.

analyzed: kāya paryādānāt na kāma rāgaḥ bhavati
translated: From the pervasion of the body, lustful desire does not arise.

analyzed: pratyakṣam dṛśyate ca vinīlaka lohitaka ādi rūpam
translated: And the form of lividity, blood, and so on is actually seen.

analyzed: pṛ yat vastutas vinīlakam
translated: If it is not really blue-black,

analyzed: tat kasmāt vinīlakam paśyati
translated: why does one see it as blue-black?

analyzed: adhimukti valāt yogī tat vinīlakam gṛhṇāti
translated: The yogi grasps it as blue-black by the power of his resolve.

analyzed: sarvāṇi rūpāṇi ca vinīlaka lohitakāni paśyati
translated: He sees all forms as blue-black and red.

analyzed: bhāvanā iyam kasmāt na viparyastā bhavati
translated: Why is this cultivation not mistaken?

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam vinīlaka lohita bhāgīyaḥ
translated: This body has parts that are blue-black and red.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre asti vṛkṣe viśuddha tā iti
translated: As it is said in the sutra, There is purity in the tree.

analyzed: vinīlaka lohitaka lakṣaṇam sadā bhāvayan anyāni rūpāṇi abhibhavati
translated: Always cultivating the characteristics of blue-black and red, one overcomes other forms.

analyzed: yathā indra nīlamaṇi prabhā sphaṭika rūpam tiraskaroti
translated: Just as the radiance of an indranila jewel obscures the form of crystal,

original: evaṃ vinīlakalohitakādilakṣaṇaṃ dīrghakālaṃ bhāvayato'śubhasaṃjñā sampūrṇā bhavati /
analyzed: evam vinīlaka lohitaka ādi lakṣaṇam dīrgha kālam bhāvayataḥ śubha saṃjñā sampūrṇā bhavati
translated: so for one who cultivates the characteristics of blue-black, red, etc. for a long time, the perception of foulness becomes complete.

analyzed: aśubha saṃjñāyām na maithu rāgaḥ utpadyate
translated: In the perception of foulness, sexual desire does not arise.

analyzed: anutpanne maithuna rāge sāṃvṛta sarva āpatti vimukhaḥ nirvāṇam eyā anuyāti
translated: When sexual desire has not arisen, one turns away from all worldly faults and follows the path to nirvana.

analyzed: aśubha saṃjñām bhāvayataḥ idṛśam hitam labhyate
translated: Such benefits are obtained by cultivating the perception of foulness.

analyzed: aśubha bhāvanā varga uṣṭasaptati uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: The eighty-seventh chapter on the cultivation of foulness.

analyzed: maraṇa saṃjñā vargaḥ
translated: The chapter on the perception of death

analyzed: yogī maraṇa saṃjñayā jīvite dhruva cittaḥ bhavati
translated: The yogi, by the notion of death, becomes one whose mind is uncertain about life.

analyzed: iti atas tām bhāvayet
translated: Therefore, one should cultivate it.

analyzed: ayam sadā kuśala dharmeṣu paramam abhirata u kuśala dharmān prajahāti
translated: This one is always supremely devoted to wholesome dharmas and abandons unwholesome dharmas.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: sattvāḥ bhūyasā maraṇa vismaraṇāt akuśalam karma kurvanti
translated: Because beings, for the most part, commit unwholesome actions due to forgetting death.

analyzed: yadā tu maraṇam anusmaranti tadā prajahati
translated: But when they remember death, then they abandon [unwholesome actions].

analyzed: satata maraṇa anusmaraṇāt ca mātā pitṛ bhrātṛ svasṛ jñāti sālohita parijana ādiṣu rāga tṛṣṇā alpīyasī bhavati
translated: And because of constantly remembering death, the craving for affection towards mother, father, brother, sister, relatives, friends, attendants, and so on becomes less.

original: maraṇasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayataḥ svasya hitaṃ bhavati yaduta cittaikāgryeṇa kuśaladharmāṇāmupacayaḥ /
analyzed: maraṇa saṃjñām bhāvayataḥ svasya hitam bhavati yat uta citta aikāgryeṇa kuśala dharmāṇām upacayaḥ
translated: For one who cultivates the notion of death, there is benefit for oneself, namely the accumulation of wholesome dharmas through one-pointedness of mind.

original: laukikāḥ sattvā bhūyasā parihitābhiratā svahitaṃ tyajantyeva /
analyzed: laukikāḥ sattvāḥ bhūyasā parihita abhiratā sva hitam tyajanti eva
translated: Worldly beings, for the most part, delight in benefiting others and abandon their own benefit.

analyzed: kiñca ayam kṣipram eva mucyate
translated: Moreover, this one is quickly liberated.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

original: ājavañjavamanughāvatāṃ hi lokānāṃ sadā maraṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: ājavañjavamanughāvatām hi lokānām sadā maraṇam bhavati
translated: Because for worldly beings who are always running and rushing, death always occurs.

analyzed: ayantu maraṇa nirvedāḥ dvi muktim eva prārthayate
translated: But this one, being disgusted with death, aspires only for liberation.

analyzed: katham maraṇa saṃjñām bhāvayet
translated: How should one cultivate the notion of death?

analyzed: sarvam anityam iti pūrvam sāmānyatas uktam
translated: It was previously stated in general that everything is impermanent.

analyzed: idānīm tu kāyaḥ nityaḥ iti mātram bhāvayet
translated: But now one should meditate only on the body as impermanent.

analyzed: skandhānām santāna samucchedaḥ maraṇa saṃjñā iti ucyate
translated: The cessation of the continuum of the aggregates is called death.

analyzed: kāyaḥ iyam bāhya vastu apekṣayā api anityataraḥ
translated: This body is even more impermanent than external things.

analyzed: tat yathā mṛṇmaye ghaṭe dhruva lakṣaṇam
translated: For example, in a clay pot, impermanence is a characteristic.

analyzed: tat api atikrāntaḥ ayam kāyaḥ iti yogī bhāvayati
translated: The yogi meditates that this body is even beyond that.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

original: mṛṇmayo'yaṃ ghaṭo yadi samyak prayogapālitaḥ kadācit ciraṃ tiṣṭhet /
analyzed: mṛṇmayaḥ ūyam ghaṭaḥ yadi samyak prayoga pālitaḥ kadācid ciram tiṣṭhet
translated: If this clay pot is well-maintained, it may sometimes last a long time.

original: ayaṃ kāyastu ciratamaṃ tiṣṭhamāno na vatsaraśatamatikrāmati /
analyzed: ayam kāyaḥ tu ciratamam tiṣṭhamānaḥ na vatsara śatam atikrāmati
translated: But this body, lasting at most, does not exceed a hundred years.

analyzed: adhruva tvāt maraṇa saṃjñām anusmaret
translated: One should remember the idea of death due to impermanence.

analyzed: kiñca ayam kāyaḥ paripanthi dharmaiḥ sambahulaḥ yat uta āśi śastra gadā vadhaka cora prapāta pāna bhojana a paripācana ati śīta ati gharma vāta vyādhayaḥ
translated: Moreover, this body is full of adverse factors, namely, fire, weapons, disease, poison, thieves, precipices, drinking, eating, indigestion, excessive cold, heat, wind, and sickness.

original: saṃkṣepataḥ sarve sattvā asattvāśca kāyasya paripanthino dharmā draṣṭavyāḥ /
analyzed: saṃkṣepataḥ sarve sattvāḥ asattvāḥ ca kāyasya paripanthinaḥ dharmāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ
translated: In short, all beings and non-beings should be seen as adverse factors for the body.

analyzed: atas bhāvayet maraṇa saṃjñām
translated: Therefore, one should meditate on the idea of death.

original: kiñca yogī paśyati kāyaḥ kṣaṇikanityo vipariṇāmalakṣaṇo naikaṃ kṣaṇamapyārakṣya iti /
analyzed: kiñca yogī paśyati kāyaḥ kṣaṇika nityaḥ vipariṇāma lakṣaṇaḥ na ekam kṣaṇam api ārakṣyaḥ iti
translated: Moreover, the yogi sees that the body is momentary and impermanent, and has the characteristic of change, and cannot be protected even for a moment.

analyzed: atas maraṇa saṃjñām bhāvayati
translated: Therefore, he cultivates the perception of death.

original: yogī dṛṣṭadharme ca paśyati bālyayauvanavārdhakyāni savyādhīni nirvyādhīni vā na maraṇaparihārīṇīti /
analyzed: yogī dṛṣṭa dharme ca paśyati bālya yauvana vārdhakyāni sa vyādhīni nirvyādhīni vā na maraṇa parihārīṇi iti
translated: And the yogi sees in this very life that childhood, youth, and old age, with or without disease, do not protect from death.

analyzed: evam kāyena api bhavitavyam iti anusmṛtya maraṇa saṃjñām bhāvayati
translated: Thus, remembering that one must act in the same way, he cultivates the perception of death.

analyzed: kiñca yogī paśyati aniyata vipākam karma
translated: Moreover, the yogi sees that karma has undetermined ripening.

analyzed: na sarva karmāṇi kṣīyante āyuḥ varṣa śataiḥ api
translated: Not all karmas are exhausted even in hundreds of years.

analyzed: karmaṇaḥ a niyata tvāt maraṇam api aniyatam iti
translated: Because of the indeterminacy of karma, death is also undetermined.

analyzed: atas maraṇa saṃjñām anusmaret
translated: Therefore, one should remember the perception of death.

analyzed: anādau ca karma apramāṇam
translated: And in beginningless saṃsāra, there is immeasurable karma.

analyzed: asti kiñcid karma anya karmaṇaḥ varaṇakam
translated: There is some karma that obstructs other karma.

analyzed: mama api bhavet akālika maraṇa karma
translated: There may also be untimely death karma for me.

analyzed: iti katham asmin āyuṣi yogī śraddadhīta
translated: How can this yogi in this life have faith in it?

analyzed: kiñca yogī paśyati maraṇam ati prabhaviṣṇu
translated: Moreover, the yogi sees that death is very powerful.

original: na sāntvavacanenollāpanīyaṃ dhanenānuneyaṃ vigraheṇa vā mocanīyam /
analyzed: na sāntva vacanena ullāpanīyam dhanena anuneyam vigraheṇa vā mocanīyam
translated: It cannot be appeased by soothing words, won over by wealth, or released by fighting.

original: yathā mahati śaile caturbhyo digbhya āgate nāsti palāyanasthānam /
analyzed: yathā mahati śaile caturbhyaḥ digbhyaḥ āgate na asti palāyana sthānam
translated: Just as when a great mountain comes from the four directions, there is no place to escape.

analyzed: yadi kaścid yamam
translated: If someone were to torment Yama,

analyzed: tadā maraṇāt mucyate
translated: then he would be released from death.

analyzed: u ayam bālaḥ mūḍha evam vadati
translated: This fool speaks thus.

analyzed: yamaḥ prāṇinām utpādane vadhe ca asvatantra balaḥ
translated: Yama is not independent in the creation and destruction of beings.

original: kevalaṃ parāmṛśati kiṃ kuśalacārī kiṃ vākuśalacārīti /
analyzed: kevalam parāmṛśati kim kuśala cārī kim vā akuśala cārī iti
translated: He merely examines whether one is a practitioner of good or evil.

analyzed: vipāka vedanāyām kṣīyamāṇāyām hiṃsraka kāya pratyayam mriyate
translated: When the experience of retribution is exhausted, one dies due to the conditions of the body.

original: ato yogī kāyo'niśrayo'śaraṇo maraṇavartmagata iti paśyan maraṇasaṃjñāmanusmarati /
analyzed: atas yogī maraṇa vartma gataḥ iti paśyan maraṇa saṃjñām anusmarati
translated: Therefore, the yogi sees the body as a non-support, a non-refuge, going along the path of death, and thus recollects the perception of death.

original: kiñca yogī sadā paśyati kāyo'yaṃ jarāvyādhiparipīḍito'dhruvasvabhāvaḥ pratikṣaṇamutpannavināśī vijñānasantānavinaṣṭa ityato maraṇasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayati
analyzed: kiñca yogī sadā paśyati kāyaḥ iyam jarā vyādhi paripīḍitaḥ dhruva svabhāvaḥ pratikṣaṇam utpanna vināśī vijñāna santāna vinaṣṭaḥ iti atas maraṇa saṃjñām bhāvayati
translated: Moreover, the yogi always sees this body afflicted by old age and disease, of uncertain nature, arising and perishing every moment, and the consciousness continuum destroyed, and thus cultivates the perception of death.

original: kiñcāyaṃ yogī paśyati maraṇaṃ niyataṃ jīvitamaniyatam /
analyzed: kiñca ayam yogī paśyati maraṇam niyatam jīvitam aniyatam
translated: Moreover, this yogi sees that death is certain, life is uncertain.

analyzed: aniyatāt niyatam viśiṣyate iti atas maraṇa saṃjñām bhāvayati
translated: The uncertain is superior to the uncertain, and thus he cultivates the perception of death.

analyzed: kasmāt jarā vyādhi ādi saṃjñāḥ an uktvā maraṇa saṃjñā mātram ucyate
translated: Why, not mentioning the notions of old age, sickness, etc., is the notion of death alone mentioned?

analyzed: u jarā vyādhi abhibhūtaḥ puruṣaḥ na parikṣīyate
translated: Because a person overwhelmed by old age and sickness is not completely destroyed.

analyzed: vyādhiḥ balam harati jarā yauvanam harati
translated: Sickness takes away strength, old age takes away youth.

analyzed: jñāti sālohitaḥ dhanam anyat caharati
translated: Relatives, friends, wealth and other things are taken away.

analyzed: kāyaḥ tu tathā api tiṣṭhati
translated: But the body still remains.

analyzed: maraṇam punar sarvam apaharati
translated: But death takes away everything.

analyzed: jarā vyādhi ādi ca maraṇasya pratyayaḥ
translated: And old age, sickness, etc. are conditions for death.

analyzed: atas na pṛthak ucyate
translated: Therefore, they are not mentioned separately.

original: uktañca sūtremaraṇaṃ nāma mahātāmastram araśmikamarakṣaṇam asahāyakamanupasthāpakaṃ paramabhayasthānaṃ iti /
analyzed: uktam ca sūtre maraṇam nāma mahā tāmastram a raśmikam a rakṣaṇam a sahāyakam an upasthāpakam param abhaya sthānam iti
translated: And it is said in the sutra: Death is a great darkness, without light, without protection, without companion, without support, the highest place of fear.

analyzed: atas maraṇa saṃjñām anusmaret
translated: Therefore, one should remember the notion of death.

analyzed: kiñca sattvāḥ maraṇa pratyayam para lokāt vibhyati
translated: Moreover, beings are afraid of the next world because of death.

original: traidhātuke sarvasyāsti maraṇaṃ na tathā jarā vyādhiśca /
analyzed: traidhātuke sarvasya asti maraṇam na tathā jarā vyādhiḥ ca
translated: In the three realms, everyone has death, but not so old age and sickness.

original: pṛ yadi sattvān vihāya nāsti maraṇasaṃjñā /
analyzed: yadi sattvān vihāya na asti maraṇa saṃjñā
translated: If the notion of death does not exist apart from beings,

analyzed: sattvāḥ eva prajñapti santaḥ
translated: beings are only nominally existent.

analyzed: yogī kasmāt imām saṃjñām bhāvayati
translated: Why does the yogi cultivate this notion?

analyzed: vinaśvara sattva lakṣaṇa jñāna vihīnaḥ maraṇāt vibheti
translated: One who lacks the knowledge of the characteristics of impermanent and perishable existence is afraid of death.

analyzed: yaḥ maraṇa saṃjñām bhāvayati
translated: One who cultivates the perception of death

analyzed: na sa bibheti
translated: is not afraid.

analyzed: atas bhāvayet
translated: Therefore, one should cultivate it.

analyzed: anitya saṃjñā ādayaḥ mārgasya pratyāsannāḥ
translated: The perceptions of impermanence, etc. are proximate to the path.

analyzed: aśubha āhāre pratikūla maraṇa saṃjñā ādayaḥ mārga viprakṛṣṭāḥ
translated: The perceptions of impurity, repulsiveness in food, and death are distant from the path.

analyzed: mārga pratilābhī īdṛśa saṃjñayā cittam pragṛhṇāti  maraṇa saṃjñā vargaḥ ekonāśītti uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: One who attains the path controls the mind with such perceptions.🔽The ninety-ninth chapter on the perception of death.

analyzed: antima saṃjñā tritaya vargaḥ
translated: The three final perceptions.

analyzed: prahāṇa saṃjñā iti
translated: The perception of abandonment.

original: yathā caturṣu samyakpradhāneṣūktamutpannānāṃ pāpakānāmakuśalānāṃ dharmāṇāṃ prahāṇāya chandaṃ janayati vyāyamati vīryamārabhate /
analyzed: yathā caturṣu samyakpradhāneṣu uktam utpannānām pāpakānām akuśalānām dharmāṇām prahāṇāya chandam janayati vyāyamati vīryam ārabhate
translated: As it is said in the four right efforts: One generates desire, strives, arouses energy, and controls and exerts the mind for the abandonment of arisen evil unwholesome states.

analyzed: cittam pragṛhṇāti pradadhāti iti
translated: One controls and directs the mind.

original: ime ca pāpakā akuśalā dharmā narakādiduḥkhakleśānāṃ pratyayāḥ /
analyzed: ime ca pāpakāḥ akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ naraka ādi duḥkha kleśānām pratyayāḥ
translated: These evil unwholesome states are the conditions for the sufferings and afflictions of hell, etc.

analyzed: pāpa kīrti śabdānām citta paritāpa ādi duḥkhānām ca mūlam
translated: They are the root of evil fame, sounds, mental anguish, and other sufferings.

analyzed: tasmāt prajahyāt
translated: Therefore, one should abandon them.

analyzed: pṛ katham prajahāti
translated: How does one abandon them?

analyzed: dharmāṇām akaraṇam pratibdhaḥ tasmin samaye prajahāti
translated: At that time, he abandons the non-performance of dharmas.

analyzed: ayoniśas manaskāraḥ kāma rāga ādīnām kleśānām pratyayaḥ
translated: Improper attention is a condition for defilements such as sensual desire.

analyzed: tad manaskāra prahāṇāt te dharmāḥ prahīyante
translated: By abandoning that attention, those dharmas are abandoned.

original: pṛ imāṃ prahāṇasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayan kiṃ hitaṃ vidante /
analyzed: pṛ imām prahāṇa saṃjñām bhāvayan kim hitam vidante
translated: What benefit do they see in cultivating this notion of abandonment?

original: u tāṃ saṃjñāṃ bhāvayan sadā na pāpakān dharmānanuvartate /
analyzed: u tām saṃjñām bhāvayan sadā na pāpakān dharmān anuvartate
translated: Cultivating that notion, he always does not follow unwholesome dharmas.

analyzed: kartavyam eva karoti
translated: He does only what should be done.

analyzed: aṣṭau akṣaṇān ca varjayati
translated: And he avoids the eight inopportune times.

analyzed: puruṣasya ātma hitam yat uta kleśānām prahāṇam
translated: What is beneficial for a man is the abandonment of defilements.

original: kleśaprahāṇābhirati dharmacī varasaṃvṛtaliṅgasya pravrajitasya hitam tayā nocet svakāyameva manyeta /
analyzed: kleśa prahāṇa abhirati dharma cī vara saṃvṛta liṅgasya pravrajitasya hitam tayā no ced sva kāyam eva manyeta
translated: It is beneficial for one who has gone forth with the distinguishing mark of the Dharma robe to delight in the abandonment of defilements. Otherwise, he would think only of his own body.

analyzed: yadi yogī prahāṇa saṃjñā bhāvanāyām abhirataḥ
translated: If the yogi delights in the cultivation of the notion of abandonment,

analyzed: tadā buddhe dharma pūjām karoti
translated: then he makes offerings to the Buddha and the Dharma.

analyzed: virāga saṃjñā nirodha saṃjñā iti
translated: The notion of dispassion and the notion of cessation.

analyzed: rāge ca atyanta anutpanne virāgaḥ bhavati  tad virāga anusmaraṇam eva virāga saṃjñā
translated: When desire is completely non-arisen, there is dispassion.🔽The mere recollection of that dispassion is itself the notion of dispassion.

analyzed: prahāṇa saṃjñā eva virāga saṃjñā iti matam
translated: The notion of abandonment is considered to be the same as the notion of dispassion.

analyzed: kasmāt punar ucyate
translated: Why is it said again?

analyzed: u prahāṇāt labhyate virāgam
translated: It is obtained from abandonment, not from detachment.

analyzed: prahāṇam nāma kāma rāgasya apanayanam
translated: Abandonment means the removal of sensual desire.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtrekāmarāgasya prahāṇāt pañcaskandhāḥ prahīyante iti /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtra ekāma rāgasya prahāṇāt pañca skandhāḥ prahīyante iti
translated: As it is said in the sutra: By abandoning sensual desire, the five aggregates are abandoned.

analyzed: prahāṇa saṃjñā ca virāga saṃjñā
translated: And the notion of abandonment is the notion of detachment.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: tasmin samaye na asti kāmaḥ
translated: At that time, there is no sensual desire.

analyzed: tasya dharmasya prahāṇam bhavati
translated: There is the abandonment of that dharma.

analyzed: atas virāga saṃjñā lābhinaḥ duḥkha kleśāḥ nirudhyante
translated: Therefore, for one who has attained the notion of detachment, suffering and afflictions cease.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre vīta rāgaḥ vimucyate iti
translated: As it is said in the sutra: One who is detached is liberated.

analyzed: vimukti lābhaḥ eva prahāṇam
translated: The attainment of liberation itself is abandonment.

analyzed: an upadhi śeṣa nirvāṇam praviṣṭhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: For one who has entered the nirvana without remainder, there is cessation.

original: uktañca sūtretrayaḥ svabhāvāḥ prahāṇasvabhāvo virāgasvabhāvo nirodhasvabhāva iti /
analyzed: uktam ca sūtre trayaḥ svabhāvāḥ prahāṇa svabhāvaḥ virāga svabhāvaḥ nirodha svabhāvaḥ iti
translated: And it is said in the sutra: There are three natures: the nature of abandonment, the nature of detachment, and the nature of cessation.

original: yaducyate prahāṇasvabhāvo virāgasvabhāva iti tadarhata eva bhavati /
analyzed: yat ucyate prahāṇa svabhāvaḥ virāga svabhāvaḥ iti tat arhataḥ eva bhavati
translated: What is called the nature of abandonment and the nature of detachment belong only to the arhat.

analyzed: sa hi prahīṇa sarva kleśaḥ traidhātuka viraktaḥ sa oṣadhi śeṣa nirvāṇe tiṣṭhati
translated: He, having abandoned all afflictions and being detached from the three realms, abides in the nirvana with a remainder of support.

original: yaducyate nirodhasvabhāva iti tadāyuṣo'nte jīvitavyapagame prahīṇasantānasya /
analyzed: yat ucyate nirodha svabhāvaḥ iti jīvita vyapagame prahīṇa santānasya
translated: What is called the nature of cessation belongs to one whose continuum has been abandoned at the end of life, upon the loss of life.

analyzed: nirupadhi śeṣa nirvāṇam samāpannasya eva bhavati
translated: It exists only for one who has attained nirvana without remainder.

analyzed: asti ca dvidhā vimuktiḥ prajñā vimuktiḥ cetaḥ vimuktiḥ iti
translated: And there are two kinds of liberation: liberation by wisdom and liberation by mind.

original: yadabhihitaṃ prahāṇamiti tat avidyāṃ prajahātīti prajñā vimucyate /
analyzed: yat abhihitam prahāṇam iti tat avidyām prajahāti iti prajñā vimucyate
translated: What was said as abandonment is that by wisdom one abandons ignorance and is liberated.

original: yadvirāga iti tat tṛṣṇāṃ vivarjayatīti ceto vimucyate /
analyzed: yat virāge iti tat tṛṣṇām vivarjayati iti cetaḥ vimucyate
translated: What was said as detachment is that by mind one avoids craving and is liberated.

analyzed: dvayoḥ vimuktayoḥ phalam nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: The fruit of the two liberations is cessation.

analyzed: yat prahāṇa saṃjñā iti abhidhānam tat eva avidyā āsrava prahāṇasya abhidhānam yat nirodha saṃjñā iti tat anayoḥ dvayoḥ phalam
translated: The designation abandonment is the designation for the abandonment of the ignorance flow, and the designation cessation is the fruit of these two.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre sarva saṃskārāṇām prahāṇāt prahāṇam  sarva saṃskāreṣu virāgāt virāgaḥ
translated: As it is said in the sutra, Abandonment is due to the abandonment of all formations.🔽Detachment is due to non-attachment to all formations.

analyzed: sarva saṃskārāṇām nirodhāt nirodhaḥ iti
translated: Cessation is due to the cessation of all formations.

analyzed: tathā ca ime trayaḥ ekasya eva nāma antaram
translated: Thus these three are just different names for one thing.

original: yo'nityasaṃjñāṃ yāvannirodhasaṃjñāṃ bhāvayati sa kṛtasarvakṛtyo niruddhasarvakleśaḥ prahīṇaskandhasaṃyojanasantatirnirupadhiśeṣanirvāṇaṃ samāpadyate
analyzed: yaḥ nitya saṃjñām yāvat nirodha saṃjñām bhāvayati sa kṛta sarva kṛtyaḥ niruddha sarva kleśaḥ prahīṇa skandha saṃyojana santatiḥ nirupadhi śeṣa nirvāṇam samāpadyate
