translated: One who cultivates the perception of impermanence up to the perception of cessation has accomplished all that needs to be done, has ceased all defilements, has abandoned the aggregates and fetters, and attains nirvana without remainder.

analyzed: antima saṃjñā tritaya varga ūśīti uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: The eighty-first chapter on the three final concepts.
Among the requisites of concentration, the first five requisites of concentration.

original: pṛ pūrvamuktaṃ bhavatāmārgasatyaṃ dvividhaṃ yat samādhiḥ tatpariṣkāraśceti /
analyzed: pūrvam uktam bhavatā mārga satyam dvividham yat samādhiḥ tad pariṣkāraḥ ca iti
translated: It was previously said by you that the truth of the path is twofold: concentration and its requisites.

analyzed: tatra samādhiḥ uktaḥ
translated: Among them, concentration has been explained.

analyzed: samādhi pariṣkāraḥ idānīm vaktavyaḥ
translated: The requisites of concentration should now be explained.

original: yasmāt sati samādhipariṣkāre samādhiḥ sidhyati na tvasati /
analyzed: yasmāt sati samādhi pariṣkāre samādhiḥ sidhyati na tu asati
translated: Because when there are requisites of concentration, concentration is accomplished, but not when they are absent.

analyzed: samādhi pariṣkārāḥ ye ekādaśa dharmāḥ
translated: The requisites of concentration are the eleven dharmas:

analyzed: pariśuddha śīla tā
translated: Purity of morality.

analyzed: abhisambodhi pratilābhaḥ
translated: Attaining full enlightenment.

analyzed: indriye gupta dvāra tā
translated: Guarding the doors of the senses.

analyzed: bhojane mātra jña tā
translated: Knowing moderation in food.

analyzed: rātryāḥ ādya antima bhāge jāgaraṇa tā  kuśala vitarka sampanna tā
translated: Being watchful in the first and last parts of the night.🔽Being endowed with wholesome thoughts.

analyzed: kalyāṇa adhimukti sampanna tā
translated: Being endowed with wholesome aspirations.
Being endowed with the principal limbs.

analyzed: vimukti āyatana sampanna tā  anāvaraṇa tā
translated: Being endowed with the abode of liberation.🔽Being free from hindrances.

analyzed: anāsaṅgi tāḥ iti
translated: Being free from attachment.

analyzed: pariśuddha śīla tā iti
translated: Purity of morality means:

analyzed: akuśala karmaṇaḥ viratiḥ śīlam
translated: Morality is abstaining from unwholesome actions.

analyzed: akuśala karmāṇi yāni prāṇa atipāta a datta ādāna kāma mithyā ācārāṇi trīṇi kāyika karmāṇi
translated: The three unwholesome actions are killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct.

original: mṛṣāvāda piśunavācā paruṣavācā sampralāpa itīme catvāri vācikakarmāṇi /
analyzed: mṛṣāvāda piśuna vācā paruṣa vācā sampralāpaḥ iti ime catvāri vācika karmāṇi
translated: Lying, slander, harsh speech, and idle chatter are the four verbal actions.

analyzed: ebhyaḥ pāpakebhyaḥ viratiḥ śīlam
translated: Abstaining from these evil actions is morality.

analyzed: vandana pratyudgamana anuvrajana pūjā ādi saddharma ācaraṇam api śīlam iti ucyate
translated: The practice of the true Dharma, such as paying homage, welcoming, following, and making offerings, is also called morality.

analyzed: śīlam samādhi hetum karoti iti samādīyate
translated: Morality is called taken up because it makes concentration the cause.

original: tathā hi tadyathā suvarṇakāraḥ pūrvaṃ sthūlamalamapanayati /
analyzed: tathā hi tat yathā suvarṇakāraḥ pūrvam sthūla malam apanayati
translated: Just as a goldsmith first removes gross impurities,

analyzed: evam prathamatas śīla samādānena sthūlān śīla doṣān apanayati
translated: in the same way, first by taking up morality, one removes the gross faults of morality.

original: paścātsamādhyādinā anyān sūkṣmadoṣānapanayati /🔽yasmādasati śīlasamādāne dhyānasamādhirna bhavati /
analyzed: paścāt samādhi ādinā anyān sūkṣma doṣān apanayati  yasmāt asati śīla samādāne dhyāna samādhiḥ na bhavati
translated: Later, by concentration and so on, one removes the other subtle faults.🔽Because without taking up morality, concentration and meditation do not occur.

analyzed: śīla samādāna pratyayāt tu dhyāna samādhiḥ sulabhaḥ bhavati
translated: But concentration and meditation are easily attained in dependence on taking up morality.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtreśīle mārgasya mūlam sopānam ca iti
translated: As it is said in the sutra: Morality is the root and staircase of the path.

analyzed: kiñca āha śīla prathama ratha vinītam iti
translated: And it is said: Morality is the first training of the chariot.

analyzed: prathamam ratha vinītam an abhiruhya dvitīyam ratha vinītam katham abhirohati
translated: Having first mounted the chariot of morality, how does one mount the chariot of concentration?

analyzed: api ca āha śīlam samā bhūmiḥ
translated: It is said: Morality is the even ground.

original: imāṃ samāṃ bhūmiṃ vyavasthāpya catvāri satyāni paśyati iti /
analyzed: imām samām bhūmim vyavasthāpya catvāri satyāni paśyati iti
translated: Having established this even ground, one sees the four noble truths.

analyzed: āha ca dve bale
translated: And it is said: There are two powers.

analyzed: katame dve  /
translated: What are the two?

analyzed: pratisaṃkhyā balam bhāvanā balam ca iti
translated: The power of discernment and the power of cultivation.

analyzed: pratisaṃkhyā balam śīla samādānam eva
translated: The power of discernment is the undertaking of morality itself.

analyzed: bhāvanā balam mārgaḥ
translated: The power of cultivation is the path.

original: pūrva śīlabhedāpattiṃ śīlasamādānahitañca pratisaṃkhyayā vicārya śīlaṃ samādatte /
analyzed: śīla bheda āpattim śīla samādāna hitam ca pratisaṃkhyayā vicārya śīlam samādatte
translated: First, having considered the transgression of morality and the benefit of undertaking morality through discernment, one undertakes morality.

analyzed: paścāt pratilabdha mārgaḥ pāpakāt prakṛtyāḥ viramati
translated: Afterwards, having attained the path, one naturally abstains from evil.

analyzed: kiñca āha śīlam bodhivṛkṣasya mūlam iti
translated: And it is said: Morality is the root of the tree of enlightenment.

analyzed: asati mūle na asti vṛkṣaḥ
translated: Without a root, there is no tree.

analyzed: atas pariśuddha śīlā āvaśyakī
translated: Therefore, pure morality is necessary.

analyzed: dharmatā ca tathā eva syāt
translated: And the nature of things would be just like that.

analyzed: asati śīla samādāne na bhavati dhyāna samādhiḥ
translated: Without the undertaking of morality, there is no meditation and concentration.

analyzed: tat yathā vyādhi cikitsāyāḥ auṣadham apekṣyate
translated: Just as medicine is required for the treatment of illness,

original: tathā kleśavyādhicikitsāyā asati śīle na sampadyata auṣadham /
analyzed: tathā kleśa vyādhi cikitsāyāḥ asati śīle na sampadyata auṣadham
translated: in the same way, for the treatment of the illness of defilements, if there is no morality, the medicine is not accomplished.

analyzed: āha ca pariśuddha śīlasya cittam na anutapyati
translated: And it is said: The mind of one with pure morality does not burn.

analyzed: yāvat virakta cittaḥ vimucyate iti
translated: Up to one with a detached mind is liberated.

analyzed: ime sarve guṇāḥ śīla samādāna adhīnāḥ
translated: All these qualities depend on taking up morality.

analyzed: atas samādhi pariṣkāraḥ iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, it is called an accessory of concentration.

analyzed: asti ca karma āvaraṇam
translated: There is also the obscuration of karma.
The obscuration of afflictions.

analyzed: anayoḥ dvayoḥ phalam vipāka āvaraṇam
translated: The result of these two is the obscuration of ripening.

analyzed: pariśuddha śīlasya imāni trīṇi āvaraṇāni na bhavanti
translated: For one with pure morality, these three obscurations do not exist.

analyzed: anāvṛta cittasya samādhiḥ sidhyati
translated: For one with an unobstructed mind, concentration is accomplished.

original: pariśuddhaśīlo na vikṣipatītyato niyamena nirvāṇamadhigacchati gaṅgāstrotasi dāruskandhavat /
analyzed: pariśuddha śīlaḥ na vikṣipati iti atas niyamena nirvāṇam adhigacchati gaṅgā strotasi dāru skandha vat
translated: One with pure morality does not become distracted, therefore one certainly attains nirvana like a log in the Ganges stream.

analyzed: pariśuddha śīla samādānāt vyavasthām karoti
translated: One makes a determination through taking up pure morality.

analyzed: śīla samādānam kāyikam vācikam akuśalam karma pratiṣedhayati
translated: Taking up morality prohibits unwholesome bodily and verbal actions.

analyzed: dhyāna samāpattiḥ mānasam akuśalam karma pratiṣedhayati
translated: The attainment of concentration prohibits unwholesome mental actions.

analyzed: evam kleśānām pratiṣedhe pratilabdha tattva jñānasya ātyantika prahāṇam bhavati
translated: Thus, in the prohibition of afflictions, one who has attained the knowledge of reality has complete abandonment.

analyzed: mārga varge sakṛt darśitam śīlam stambha bhūtam iti
translated: Morality is shown repeatedly in the chapter on the path as being like a pillar.

original: dhyānasamādhicittanagarasya śīlaṃ parighā bhavati /🔽saṃsāraughataraṇasya śīlaṃ setuḥ /
analyzed: dhyāna samādhi citta nagarasya śīlam parighā bhavati  saṃsāra ogha taraṇasya śīlam setuḥ
translated: Morality is the moat of the city of the mind of concentration and meditation.🔽Morality is the bridge for crossing the flood of samsara.

analyzed: sat jana pariṣadi praveśasya śīlam mudrā
translated: Morality is the seal for entering the assembly of the virtuous.

analyzed: aṣṭāṅgika āryakṣetrasya śīlam pārabhūtam
translated: Morality is the shore for the field of the eight-fold path.

original: yathā pārarahite kṣetre jalaṃ na tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: yathā pāra rahite kṣetre jalam na tiṣṭhati
translated: Just as water does not remain in a field without a shore,

analyzed: evam pariśuddha śīle sati samādhi jalam na tiṣṭhati
translated: so the water of concentration does not remain in one without pure morality.

analyzed: pṛ kaḥ pariśuddha śīlaḥ
translated: Who has pure morality?

original: u yo gogī pāpakriyānabhiratādhyāśayaḥ paralokaparivādādibhyo bibhyati /
analyzed: u yaḥ go gī pāpa kriyā an abhirata adhyāśayaḥ para loka parivāda ādibhyaḥ bibhyati
translated: He who is not inclined to evil actions, who is afraid of slander in the other world and so on,

analyzed: sa pariśuddha śīlaḥ iti ucyate
translated: he is said to have pure morality.

analyzed: kiñca yogī citta viśuddhaye pariśuddha śīlaḥ bhavati
translated: Moreover, the yogi becomes one of pure morality for the purification of the mind.

analyzed: yathā uktam cittam apariśuddham iti atas śīlam api apariśuddham iti
translated: As it is said in the Saptasatpuruṣayoga-rāga-sūtra: Even when there is no offense in the body, the mind is impure, therefore morality is also impure.

analyzed: śīla bheda pratyayāḥ sarve kleśāḥ
translated: All defilements are the conditions for the breach of morality.

analyzed: teṣām pragrahe pariśuddha śīlaḥ bhavati
translated: By controlling them, one becomes one of pure morality.

analyzed: śrāvakāṇām śīlam nirvāṇa artham eva
translated: The morality of the disciples is only for the sake of nirvana.

original: tathāgatamārgārthī mahākaruṇācittena sarvasattvānāṃ kṛte na śīlalakṣaṇaṃ samādatte /
analyzed: tathāgata mārga arthī mahā karuṇā cittena sarva sattvānām kṛte na śīla lakṣaṇam samādatte
translated: One who seeks the path of the Tathāgata, out of a mind of great compassion, for the sake of all beings, does not take up the characteristics of morality.

original: śīlamidaṃ tathā karoti yathā bodhisvabhāvo bhavati /
analyzed: śīlam idam tathā karoti yathā bodhi svabhāvaḥ bhavati
translated: This morality is practiced in such a way that it becomes the nature of enlightenment.

analyzed: īdṛśam śīlam pariśuddham iti ucyate
translated: Such morality is called pure.

analyzed: abhisambodhiḥ iti
translated: Abhisambodhi.

original: uktaṃ hi sūtredvau khalvāyuṣman pratyayau samyakdṛṣṭerutpādāya parato ghoṣo yoniśo manaskāra iti /
analyzed: uktam hi sūtre dvau khalu āyuṣman pratyayau samyak dṛṣṭeḥ utpādāya paratas ghoṣaḥ yoniśas manaskāraḥ iti
translated: For it is said in the sutra: Venerable one, there are two conditions for the arising of right view: the voice of another and proper attention.

analyzed: paratas ghoṣaḥ eva abhisambodhiḥ
translated: The voice of another is itself abhisambodhi.

analyzed: ayam santuṣṭaḥ
translated: This is contentment.

analyzed: kaścid alpam gṛhītvā api ramaṇīyam kāmayate
translated: One who, having taken little, still desires more.

original: ayamalpeccho na santuṣṭaḥ /🔽yo'lpalābhena tṛpyati sa santuṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: ayam alpa icchaḥ na santuṣṭaḥ  yā ulpa lābhena tṛpyati sa santuṣṭaḥ
translated: This is having few desires, not contentment.🔽One who is satisfied with little gain is content.

analyzed: yadi apekṣita grāhī alpa icchaḥ iti
translated: If one who takes what is necessary is one who has few desires.

analyzed: sarve sattvāḥ alpa icchāḥ bhaveyuḥ
translated: All beings would be those who have few desires.

analyzed: eṣām pratyekam apekṣita tvāt
translated: Because each one takes what is necessary.

analyzed: yogī gṛhṇāti upayoga artha mātram
translated: The yogi takes only what is necessary for use, out of non-attachment.

analyzed: na bahu gṛhṇāti
translated: He does not take much.

original: na tu yathā laukikā yaśomaṇḍanavardhanāya bahu gṛhṇānti /
analyzed: na tu yathā laukikāḥ yaśaḥ maṇḍana vardhanāya bahu gṛhṇānti
translated: But not like worldly people who take much for the sake of fame, adornment, and increase.

analyzed: yogī kasmāt alpa icchayaḥ santuṣṭaḥ bhavati
translated: Why is the yogi content with few desires?

analyzed: sa hi paripālana ādau ādīnavam paśyati
translated: He sees the danger in protecting and so on.

analyzed: anupayukta dravya saṅgrahaḥ sammūḍhasya lakṣaṇam
translated: Accumulating unnecessary goods is a sign of confusion.

original: pravrajito na bahu sañcinvannavadātavasanaiḥ samo bhavet /
analyzed: pravrajitaḥ na bahu sañcinvan navadāta vasanaiḥ samaḥ bhavet
translated: One who has gone forth should not be like those who wear white robes and accumulate much.

analyzed: tādṛśa doṣa sattvāt alpa icchaḥ santuṣṭaḥ bhavati
translated: Because of having such faults, he is content with few desires.

analyzed: yogī yadi na alpa icchaḥ santuṣṭaḥ
translated: If the yogi is not content with few desires,

analyzed: tadā kāma cittam kramaśas vardheta
translated: then the mind of desire will gradually increase.

analyzed: dhana lābhi tvāt a prārthanīyam prārthayīta
translated: Because of the gain of wealth, one would seek what is not to be sought.

analyzed: dhana lābha abhilāṣaḥ ca na eva saṃśāmyati
translated: And the desire for the gain of wealth is never appeased.

analyzed: tatra adhyavasāyi tvāt
translated: Because of attachment to that.

analyzed: praviveka sukhāya pravrajitaḥ dhana kāmi tayā tat karaṇīyam vismarati
translated: One who has gone forth for the sake of the happiness of solitude forgets that duty because of the desire for wealth.

analyzed: kleśān api na prajahāti
translated: And one does not abandon the defilements.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: bāhya padārthān eva na prajahāti
translated: One does not abandon even external things.

analyzed: kaḥ punar vādaḥ ādhyātmikān dharmān prajahāti iti
translated: How much less can one abandon internal dharmas?

analyzed: lābha dṛṣṭiḥ vipatti vihiṃsā hetuḥ
translated: The view of gain is the cause of misfortune and injury.

analyzed: yathā karaka vṛṣṭiḥ sasyāni vināśayati
translated: Just as a shower of hail destroys crops.

analyzed: atas satatam alpa icchā santuṣṭa tām bhāvayet
translated: Therefore, one should always cultivate contentment with little.

original: dṛśyate ca deyasya padārthasya pratyarpaṇaṃ duṣkaram /
analyzed: dṛśyate ca deyasya padārthasya pratyarpaṇam duṣkaram
translated: And it is seen that the return of a given thing is difficult.

original: yaṭhā ṛṇī ṛṇamapratyarpayan paścāttadduḥkhaṃ vyathāmanubhavati iti /
analyzed: yaṭhāḥ ṛṇī ṛṇam a pratyarpayan paścāt tad duḥkham vyathām anubhavati iti
translated: Just as a debtor, not repaying the debt, later experiences the suffering of that.

analyzed: lābha satkāra dṛṣṭiḥ buddha ādibhiḥ sat jānaiḥ tyaktā
translated: The view of gain and honor is abandoned by the Buddhas and other noble ones.

original: yathāha bhagavānnāhaṃ lābhasatkāramanuprāpnomi mā lābhasatkāro māmanuprāpnotviti /
analyzed: yathā āha bhagavān na aham lābha satkāram anuprāpnomi mā lābha satkāraḥ mām anuprāpnotu iti
translated: As the Blessed One said, I do not attain gain and honor, let gain and honor not attain me.

analyzed: ayam ca yogī saddharma santuṣṭa tvāt lābha satkāram prajahāti
translated: And this yogi abandons gain and honor because he is content with the true Dharma.

original: yathāha bhagavāndevā na pratilabhante naiṣkramyasukhaṃ pravivekasukhamupaśamasukhaṃ yathā mayā pratilabdham /
analyzed: yathā āha bhagavān devāḥ na pratilabhante naiṣkramya sukham praviveka sukham upaśama sukham yathā mayā pratilabdham
translated: As the Blessed One said, The gods do not attain the happiness of renunciation, the happiness of solitude, the happiness of tranquility as I have attained it.

analyzed: atas lābha satkāram prajahāmi iti
translated: Therefore, I abandon gain and honor.

analyzed: yathā āha śāriputraḥ
translated: As Śāriputra said:

analyzed: animittam bhāvayitvā ca aham śūnya samādhinā
translated: Having cultivated the signless state with the emptiness concentration,

original: samīkṣe sarvavastūni kheṭapiṇḍān yathā bahiḥ // iti /
analyzed: samīkṣe sarva vastūni kheṭa piṇḍān yathā bahis iti
translated: I observe all things like lumps of spittle outside.

original: kiñca yogī paśyati na kāmopabhogena tṛptirbhavati /
analyzed: kiñca yogī paśyati na kāma upabhogena tṛptiḥ bhavati
translated: Moreover, the yogi sees that one does not become satisfied by enjoying desires.

original: yathā lavaṇodakaṃ piban na tarṣaṇamapanayati iti prajñāṃ prarthayānastṛpto bhavati /
analyzed: yathā lavaṇa udakam piban na tarṣaṇam apanayati iti prajñām prarthayānaḥ tṛptaḥ bhavati
translated: Just as drinking salty water does not quench thirst, one becomes satisfied by aspiring for wisdom.

original: mahecchaḥ sadā prārthanāmutpādayan bahu prārthayitvā'lpaṃ vindate /
analyzed: mahā icchaḥ sadā prārthanām utpādayan bahu prārthayitvā alpam vindate
translated: The one with great desire, always producing aspiration, aspires for much and obtains little.

analyzed: atas sadā khidyate
translated: Therefore, he is always troubled.

original: paśyāmaśca bhikṣārthī janairavamanyate na satkriyate yathā'lpecchaḥ /
analyzed: paśyāmaḥ ca bhikṣā arthī janaiḥ avamanyate na satkriyate yathā alpa icchaḥ
translated: And we see that one who begs for alms is despised by people and not honored, as one with little desire.

analyzed: pravrajitaḥ mahat prārthayate iti akāryam etat
translated: It is improper for one who has gone forth to aspire for much.

analyzed: janaiḥ dattasya agrahaṇam tu yukta rūpam
translated: But it is proper not to accept what is given by people.

analyzed: atas ulpa icchā santuṣṭim ācaret
translated: Therefore, one should practice contentment with little desire.

original: pravivikta iti yat gṛhasthapravrajitayoḥ kāyikapravivekasamācāraḥ kleśeṣu mānasapravivekasamācāraḥ ayaṃ pravivekaḥ /
analyzed: praviviktaḥ iti yat gṛhastha pravrajitayoḥ kāyika praviveka samācāraḥ kleśeṣu mānasa praviveka samācāraḥ ayam pravivekaḥ
translated: Isolation means the physical isolation and conduct of householders and renunciants, and the mental isolation and conduct regarding afflictions. This is isolation.

analyzed: pṛ yogī kasmāt praviviktaḥ bhavati
translated: Why does the yogi become isolated?

original: u pravrajitā apratilabdhamārgā api pravivekārāmā bhavanti /
analyzed: u pravrajitāḥ a pratilabdha mārgāḥ api praviveka ārāmāḥ bhavanti
translated: Even renunciants who have not attained the path delight in isolation.

original: avadātavasanādayaḥ tatsthānagatastrīrūpavikṣepāvakṛṣṭā na tatra kadācitsukhino bhavanti /
analyzed: avadāta vasana ādayaḥ tad sthāna gata strī rūpa vikṣepa avakṛṣṭāḥ na tatra kadācid sukhinaḥ bhavanti
translated: Those wearing white robes, etc., are distracted by the forms of women in that place and are never happy there.

analyzed: praviveke tu cittam su upaśamam bhavati
translated: But in isolation, the mind becomes very peaceful.

analyzed: yathā salilam anāvilam prakṛtitaḥ su accham
translated: Just as water, by nature clear, becomes unclouded.

analyzed: atas praviveke carati
translated: Therefore, one practices in isolation.

analyzed: praviveka dharmaḥ yam gaṅgā nadī vālukā samaiḥ buddhaiḥ abhisaṃstutaḥ
translated: This dharma of isolation is praised by Buddhas equal to the sands of the Ganges River.

analyzed: kena idam jñāyate
translated: How is this known?

original: bhagavān grāmopakaṇṭhe niṣaṇṇaṃ bhikṣuṃ dṛṣṭvā aprītamanasko bhavati /
analyzed: bhagavān grāma upakaṇṭhe niṣaṇṇam bhikṣum dṛṣṭvā a prīta manaskaḥ bhavati
translated: The Blessed One, seeing a monk sitting near a village, becomes displeased.

original: śūnyāyatane ca śayānaṃ bhikṣuṃ dṛṣṭvā bhagavān prītamanasko bhavati /
analyzed: śūnya āyatane ca śayānam bhikṣum dṛṣṭvā bhagavān prīta manaskaḥ bhavati
translated: But seeing a monk lying in an empty place, the Blessed One becomes pleased.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: What is the reason for this?

original: grāmopakaṇṭhe niṣṣaṇṇasya bhikṣorbahubhiḥ kāraṇaiḥ samāhitacittavikṣepe labdhavyaṃ na labhyate sākṣātkartavyaṃ na sākṣātkriyate /
analyzed: grāma upakaṇṭhe niṣṣaṇṇasya bhikṣoḥ bahubhiḥ kāraṇaiḥ samāhita citta vikṣepe labdhavyam na labhyate sākṣātkartavyam na sākṣātkriyate
translated: For a monk sitting near a village, due to many reasons, the concentrated mind is distracted, what is to be obtained is not obtained, what is to be realized is not realized.

original: śūnyāyatane śayānasya kiñcitkausīdye satyapi samādhyāśāsambhave cittaṃ parigṛhyate /
analyzed: śūnya āyatane śayānasya kiñcid kausīdye sati api samādhi āśā sambhave cittam parigṛhyate
translated: For one lying in an empty place, even if there is some laziness, when the possibility of concentration exists, the mind is restrained.

analyzed: parigṛhītam cittam vimucyate
translated: And the restrained mind is liberated.

analyzed: nimitta udgraham upādāya ca kāma ādayaḥ kleśāḥ samudbhavanti
translated: And the defilements such as desire arise based on grasping the sign.

original: śūnyāyatane na rūpādīni nimittāni santīti kleśāḥ suprahāṇāḥ /
analyzed: śūnya āyatane na rūpa ādīni nimittāni santi iti kleśāḥ su prahāṇāḥ
translated: In an empty place, there are no signs such as form, etc., so the defilements are easily abandoned.

analyzed: yathā agniḥ asati indhane svatas śāmyati
translated: Just as a fire, when there is no fuel, naturally goes out on its own.

original: uktañcasūtreyo bhikṣuḥ saṅgaṇikāvihārarataḥ sambhāṣyarataḥsa gaṇādavivikta ityataḥ sāmayikīmeva vimuktiṃ na pratilabhate /
analyzed: uktam ca sūtreyaḥ bhikṣuḥ saṅgaṇikā vihāra rataḥ sambhāṣya rataḥ sa gaṇāt aviviktaḥ iti atas sāmayikīm eva vimuktim na pratilabhate
translated: And it is said in the sutra: That monk who delights in dwelling in company, who delights in conversation, is not secluded from the group, therefore he does not obtain even occasional liberation.

original: kaḥ punarvādaḥ akopyāṃ vimuktiṃ pratilabhata iti /
analyzed: kaḥ punar vādaḥ a kopyām vimuktim pratilabhate iti
translated: How much less does he obtain unshakable liberation?

analyzed: pravivikta vihārī punar ubhayam sākṣātkurute
translated: But one who dwells in seclusion realizes both.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: yathā pradīpaḥ vāta viviktaḥ prakāśate
translated: Just as a lamp, when free from wind, shines brightly.

analyzed: evam yogī praviveka vihāri tayā tattva jñānam vindate
translated: Thus, the yogi, by dwelling in solitude, attains the knowledge of reality.

analyzed: ārabdha vīryaḥ iti
translated: One who has begun vigor.

original: yogī yadi samyakpradhānamācaran akuśaladharmān prajahāti kuśaladharmāṃśca sañcinoti /
analyzed: yogī yadi samyak pradhānam ācaran akuśala dharmān prajahāti kuśala dharmān ca sañcinoti
translated: If the yogi, practicing the right endeavors, abandons unwholesome dharmas and accumulates wholesome dharmas,

analyzed: tadā tatra samyak pradhānām ācarati iti ārabdha vīryaḥ iti ucyate
translated: then at that time, practicing the right endeavors there, he is said to have begun vigor.

analyzed: evam ca bhagavat śāsane hitam pratilabhate
translated: And thus he obtains benefit in the Blessed One's teaching.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: What is the reason for that?

analyzed: sa hi kuśala dharma sañcayena pratidinam abhivardhate
translated: For he increases day by day by accumulating wholesome dharmas.

analyzed: yathā utpala padma ādīni yathā salilam abhivardhante
translated: Just as lotuses and so on increase with water.

analyzed: kausīdya cārī punar kāṣṭha musala vat prathama abhinirvartanāt ārabhya pratidīnam apacīyate
translated: But one who practices laziness, like a piece of wood or a pestle, decreases day by day starting from the first performance.

analyzed: ārabdha vīryasya artha pratilābhi tayā cittam sadā pramudyate
translated: And the mind of one who has begun vigor is always delighted by the acquisition of benefit.

analyzed: kausīdya cārī tu akuśala dharma nivṛtta cittaḥ satatam duḥkha upadravam anubadhnāti
translated: But one who practices laziness, with a mind turned away from unwholesome dharmas, is always afflicted by suffering.

original: ārabdhavīryasya ca kṣaṇe kṣaṇe kuśaladharmo nityamabhivardhate /
analyzed: ārabdha vīryasya ca kṣaṇe kṣaṇe kuśala dharmaḥ nityam abhivardhate
translated: And the wholesome dharma of one who has begun vigor always increases moment by moment.

analyzed: na apacīyate
translated: It does not decrease.

original: vīryaprakṛṣṭamācarannāpnoti prakṛṣṭaṃ sthānaṃ yaduta buddhānāṃ gatim /
analyzed: vīrya prakṛṣṭam ācaran āpnoti prakṛṣṭam sthānam yat uta buddhānām gatim
translated: Practicing excellent effort, one attains an excellent state, namely the state of the Buddhas.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtre bhagavatā ānandaṃ prati prakṛṣṭaṃ vīryamabhyasan buddhagatiṃ yātīti /🔽ārabdhavīryasya cittasamādhīḥ sulabhaḥ /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre bhagavatā ānandam prati prakṛṣṭam vīryam abhyasan buddha gatim yāti iti  ārabdha vīryasya citta samādhīḥ sulabhaḥ
translated: As it is said in the sutra, the Blessed One said to Ananda, By practicing excellent effort, one goes to the state of the Buddhas.🔽And for one who has begun effort, mental concentration is easily attained.

analyzed: manda indriyaḥ ārabdha vīryaḥ saṃsārāt eva āśu mucyate
translated: One of dull faculties who has begun effort is quickly liberated from samsara.

analyzed: tīṣṇa indriyaḥ kusīdaḥ tu na vimucyate
translated: But one of sharp faculties who is lazy is not liberated.

analyzed: yat asti kiñcid aihikam āmuṣmikam laukikam lokottaram hitam
translated: Whatever there is of this-worldly or other-worldly, mundane or supramundane benefit,

analyzed: tat sarvam vīryam upādāya bhavati
translated: all that comes from effort.

analyzed: sarveṣām lokānām yat asti alābha vyasanam
translated: Whatever there is of misfortune and calamity for all people,

analyzed: tat sarvam kausīdyam upādāya bhavati
translated: all that comes from laziness.

original: evaṃ kusīdasya doṣamārabdhavīryasya guṇaṃ dṛṣṭvā vīryamanusmarati /
analyzed: evam kusīdasya doṣam ārabdha vīryasya guṇam dṛṣṭvā vīryam anusmarati
translated: Seeing thus the fault of laziness and the virtue of begun effort, one recollects effort.

analyzed: upasthita smṛtikaḥ iti
translated: One who has established mindfulness.

analyzed: kāya vedanā citta dharmeṣu sadā smṛtim samupasthāpayati
translated: One always establishes mindfulness in body, feeling, mind, and dharmas.

original: pṛ eṣāṃ caturṇāṃ dharmāṇāṃ smṛtyā kīdṛśaṃ hitaṃ vindate /
analyzed: eṣām caturṇām dharmāṇām smṛtyā kīdṛśam hitam vindate
translated: And what kind of benefit does one find through mindfulness of these four dharmas?

original: u pāpakā akuśalā dharmā na cittamāgacchanti /
analyzed: u pāpakāḥ akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ na cittam āgacchanti
translated: Unwholesome, unskillful dharmas do not come to the mind.

analyzed: yathā su rakṣite na pāpakaḥ puruṣaḥ avatarati
translated: Just as a well-guarded city is not entered by a wicked person.

original: yathā ca ghaṭaḥ pūrṇo na punarudakamādatte /
analyzed: yathā ca ghaṭaḥ pūrṇaḥ na punar udakam ādatte
translated: And just as a full pot does not take water again.

original: evamasya puruṣasya kuśaladharmasampūrṇasya na pāpakāni prasajyante /
analyzed: evam asya puruṣasya kuśala dharma sampūrṇasya na pāpakāni prasajyante
translated: In the same way, for this person whose wholesome dharmas are full, wicked things do not occur.

original: yo bhāvitasamyaksmṛtikaḥ sa vimuktibhāgīyān sarvān kuśaladharmān saṅgṛhṇāti /
analyzed: yaḥ bhāvita samyaksmṛtikaḥ sa vimukti bhāgīyān sarvān kuśala dharmān saṅgṛhṇāti
translated: He who has developed right mindfulness includes all the wholesome dharmas that are conducive to liberation.

original: yathā samudrāmbupāyinaḥ sarvāṇi strotāṃsi pītāni bhavanti /
analyzed: yathā samudra ambu pāyinaḥ sarvāṇi strotāṃsi pītāni bhavanti
translated: Just as for one who drinks the water of the ocean, all the streams are drunk,

analyzed: sarveṣām udakānām samudra varti tvāt
translated: because all the waters flow into the ocean.

analyzed: asyāḥ smṛteḥ bhāvayitā svatantra caryā sthāne viharati iti ucyate
translated: The one who cultivates this mindfulness is said to dwell in the stage of independent conduct.

analyzed: kleśa māraḥ na kiñcid ākopayati kāka ulūka dṛṣṭānta vat
translated: The demon of afflictions does not disturb him in any way, like the example of the crow and the owl.

original: asya ca cittaṃ supratiṣṭhitaṃ duṣkampanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: asya ca cittam su pratiṣṭhitam duṣkampanam bhavati
translated: And his mind is well-established and unshakable,

analyzed: yathā vṛttaḥ ghaṭaḥ śikyam adhiniviśyate
translated: just as a full pot is placed on a sling.

analyzed: sa ca aciram eva artham lapsyate
translated: And he will soon attain his goal.

original: yathoktaṃ bhikṣuṇīsūtrebhikṣuṇya ānandametadavocaniha bhadanta ānanda vayaṃ catṛṣu smṛtyupasthāneṣu supratiṣṭhitacittā viharantya udāraṃ pūrveṇāparaṃ viśeṣaṃ samprajānāma iti /
analyzed: yathā uktam bhikṣuṇīsūtre bhikṣuṇyaḥ ānandam etat avocan iha bhadantaḥ ānanda vayam catṛṣu smṛti upasthāneṣu su pratiṣṭhita cittāḥ viharantyaḥ udāram pūrveṇa aparam viśeṣam samprajānāmaḥ iti
translated: As it is said in the Bhikṣuṇī Sūtra: The bhikṣuṇīs said this to Ānanda: Venerable Ānanda, we dwell here with our minds well-established in the four establishments of mindfulness, and we clearly recognize a superior distinction compared to before.

analyzed: ānandā uvocata evam etat bhaginyaḥ evam etat bhaginyaḥ iti
translated: Ānanda said: So it is, sisters! So it is, sisters!

analyzed: samāhitaḥ iti
translated: Concentrated means:

analyzed: citta samādhim bhāvayataḥ pravaraḥ ūrthaḥ bhavati
translated: For one who cultivates concentration of the mind, the supreme meaning is attained.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtre samāhito yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti iti /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam prajānāti iti
translated: As it is said in the sūtra: One who is concentrated knows as it really is.

original: anena manuṣyakāyenātimānuṣadharmo bhavati yaduta kāyenodakarmamagniñcāvagāhya nirgacchati /
analyzed: anena manuṣya kāyena ati mānuṣa dharmaḥ bhavati yat uta kāyena uda karmam agnin ca avagāhya nirgacchati
translated: By this human body, a superhuman dharma is attained, namely: by entering into water and fire with the body and emerging.

analyzed: vihāyasā gamane ca svatantraḥ ityādi
translated: And being independent in flying through the air, and so on.

original: kiñcāsya sukhaṃ bhavati yat yāvaddevāḥ sahāṃpatibrahmādayo'pi nāpnuvanti /
analyzed: kiñca asya sukham bhavati yat yāvat devāḥ sahāṃpati brahma ādayaḥ api na āpnuvanti
translated: Moreover, he has such happiness that even the gods, the lords of the Sahā world, Brahmā, and so on, do not attain.

analyzed: ayam yat kartavyam tat karoti iti ucyate
translated: This one is said to do what should be done.

analyzed: yat akartavyam na tat karoti
translated: What should not be done, he does not do.

original: samāhitasya saddharmaḥ sadā vardhate samāhitasya cittaṃ nānutapyate /
analyzed: samāhitasya saddharmaḥ sadā vardhate samāhitasya cittam na anutapyate
translated: For one who is concentrated, the true Dharma always increases. And the mind of one who is concentrated does not burn with regret.

analyzed: ayam pravrajyā phala bhāj bhavati tathāgata śāsana anuyāyī ca
translated: He partakes of the fruit of renunciation and follows the teaching of the Tathāgata.

analyzed: na anya puruṣa vat vṛthā satkāram svīkaroti
translated: He does not accept honor in vain like other men.

analyzed: ayam eva dāna puṇyam vipācayati na anye
translated: He alone ripens the merit of generosity, not others.

analyzed: ayam ca samāhita dharmaḥ buddhaiḥ āryaiḥ ca niṣevitaḥ
translated: And this concentrated Dharma is practiced by the Buddhas and the noble ones.

analyzed: sarveṣām kuśala dharmāṇām samārjanāya yogyaḥ ca bhavati
translated: He becomes fit for the cultivation of all wholesome dharmas.

original: yadi samāhitasya siddhirbhavati tadā āryamārgasya pratilābho bhavati /
analyzed: yadi samāhitasya siddhiḥ bhavati tadā ārya mārgasya pratilābhaḥ bhavati
translated: If success is attained in concentration, then the noble path is obtained.

analyzed: yadi na siddhiḥ
translated: If there is no success,

analyzed: tadā śubha deveṣu upapadyate yat uta rūpa ārūpya dhātau
translated: then he is reborn among the good gods, namely in the form and formless realms.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

original: na hi dānādinā īdṛśaṃ kāryaṃ pratilabhate yadekāntataḥ pāpakānāmakaraṇam /
analyzed: na hi dāna ādinā īdṛśam kāryam pratilabhate yat ekāntataḥ pāpakānām akaraṇam
translated: For one does not attain such an effect through generosity etc. as the complete non-doing of evil.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtreyo daharo yuvā ājanma maitrīṃ bhāvayati /🔽sa kiṃ pāpakaṃ cittamutpādayet /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtreyaḥ daharaḥ yuvā ājanma maitrīm bhāvayati  sa kim pāpakam cittam utpādayet
translated: As it is said in the sūtra: One who, being young and youthful, cultivates loving-kindness from birth,🔽would he generate an evil thought?

analyzed: pāpakam vā cintayet
translated: Or think evil?

analyzed: no hi idam bhagavan
translated: No, Blessed One.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ tad samādhi prabhāvaḥ eṣaḥ
translated: Why is that? It is the power of that concentration.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: citta samādhiḥ ca tattva jñānasya pratyayaḥ
translated: And mental concentration is a condition for the knowledge of reality.

analyzed: tattva prajñā sarvān saṃskārān kṣapayati
translated: The wisdom of reality destroys all formations.

analyzed: saṃskārāṇām kṣayāt sarve duḥkha upāyāsāḥ śāmyanti
translated: By the destruction of formations, all sufferings and troubles cease.

original: yogī sarvāṇi laukikāni lokottarāṇi smaranneva kuryāt na klamathena kāryaṃ prayojayan /
analyzed: yogī sarvāṇi laukikāni lokottarāṇi smaran eva kuryāt na klamathena kāryam prayojayan
translated: The yogi, remembering all worldly and transcendental [dharmas], should perform [his duties] without weariness.

original: anye pudgalāstena labdhaṃ pramātuṃ cittameva notpādayanti /
analyzed: anye pudgalāḥ tena labdham pramātum cittam eva na utpādayanti
translated: Other persons do not even generate the mind to attain [enlightenment].

analyzed: atas āha samāhita ṛtham āpnoti iti
translated: Therefore it is said: One who is concentrated attains the goal.

analyzed: prajñāvān iti
translated: The wise one.

analyzed: prajñāvataḥ citte kleśāḥ na sambhavanti
translated: For the wise one, defilements do not arise in the mind.

analyzed: yadi sambhavanti
translated: If they do arise,

original: tadaiva nirudhyante yathā taptāyaḥpātre patitā jalakaṇikā /
analyzed: tadā eva nirudhyante yathā tapta ayaḥ pātre patitā jala kaṇikā
translated: they are immediately extinguished, like a drop of water falling on an iron plate heated to redness.

analyzed: prajñāvataḥ citte saṃjñāḥ na āvirbhavanti
translated: For the wise one, conceptual thoughts do not appear in the mind.

analyzed: yadi āvirbhavanti
translated: If they do appear,

original: tadaiva nirudhyante yathā tṛṇāgre'vaśyāyabinduḥ sūrya uditamātre śuṣyati /
analyzed: tadā eva nirudhyante yathā tṛṇa agra iva śyāya binduḥ sūryaḥ udita mātre śuṣyati
translated: they are immediately extinguished, like a drop of dew on a blade of grass that dries up as soon as the sun rises.

analyzed: yaḥ prajñā cakṣuṣkaḥ sa buddha dharmam paśyati
translated: One who has the eye of wisdom sees the Buddha's Dharma.

analyzed: yathā cakṣuṣmataḥ sūryaḥ upayogāya kalpate
translated: And just as the sun is useful for one who has eyes,

analyzed: prajñāvān buddhasya dharma dāya bhāj iti ucyate
translated: the wise one is called the heir of the Buddha's Dharma.

analyzed: yathā jātaḥ putraḥ pitroḥ dhana bhāj bhavati
translated: Just as a son who is born becomes a sharer of his parents' wealth.

analyzed: prajñāvān eva sa jīvaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Only the wise one is said to be alive.

analyzed: anye mṛtāḥ iti
translated: Others are dead.
The wise one is a seeker of the truth.

analyzed: mārgasya parijñānāt
translated: Because of the complete knowledge of the path.

analyzed: prajñāvān eva bhagavataḥ śāsana amṛta rasam vetti
translated: Only the wise one tastes the nectar of the Blessed One's teaching.

analyzed: yathā avipariṇata jihvā indriyaḥ pañca rasān vivecayati
translated: Just as one with an unimpaired tongue sense faculty distinguishes the five tastes.

original: prajñāvān bhagavacchāsane samāhito na kampate tadyathā śailo na vāyunā kampyate /
analyzed: prajñāvān bhagavat śāsane samāhitaḥ na kampate tat yathā śailaḥ na vāyunā kampyate
translated: The wise one, concentrated in the Blessed One's teaching, does not waver, just as a mountain is not shaken by the wind.

analyzed: prajñāvān śrāddhaḥ iti ucyate
translated: The wise one is called faithful.

analyzed: catuḥ śraddhā lābhi tayā para an anuyāyi ta tvāt
translated: Because of attaining the four kinds of faith, he does not follow others.

analyzed: ārya prajñā indriya pratilābhī jinaurasaḥ bhavati
translated: The one who attains the noble faculty of wisdom becomes a son of the Victor.

analyzed: anye bāhyāḥ pṛthagjanāḥ
translated: Others are outsiders, ordinary people.

analyzed: atas ucyate prajñāvān artham vindate iti
translated: Therefore it is said that the wise one finds wealth.

analyzed: niṣprapañca ārāmaḥ iti
translated: Delighting in the absence of conceptual proliferation.

analyzed: yat eka aneka tva vādaḥ sa prapañcaḥ
translated: The doctrine of one and many is conceptual proliferation.

original: yathā ānandaḥ śāriputraṃ pṛcchatiṣaṇṇām āyuṣman sparśāyatanānāmaśeṣavirāganirodhādasti anyatkiñcit /
analyzed: yathā ānandaḥ śāriputram pṛcchati ṣaṇṇām āyuṣman sparśa āyatanānām aśeṣa virāga nirodhāt asti anyat kiñcid
translated: Just as Ānanda asks Śāriputra: Venerable one, when there is complete dispassion and cessation of the six sense bases, is there anything else?

analyzed: śāriputraḥ hi evam āyuṣman
translated: Śāriputra replies: No, venerable one.

original: ṣaṇṇāmāyuṣman sparśāyatanānā maśeṣavirāganirodhādastyanyatkiñciditi vadan aprapañcaṃ prapañcayasi /🔽nāsti kiñciditi /🔽asti ca nāsti cānyaditi /
analyzed: ṣaṇṇām āyuṣman sparśa āyatanānām aśeṣa virāga nirodhāt asti anyat kiñcid iti vadan aprapañcam prapañcayasi  na asti kiñcid iti  asti ca na asti ca anyat iti
translated: Venerable one, by saying There is something else when asked if there is anything else apart from the complete dispassion and cessation of the six sense bases, you are elaborating on what is non-elaborate.

original: naivāsti no ca naivāstyanyaditi ca praśne prativacanamapi tathā syāt /
analyzed: na eva asti no ca na eva asti anyat iti ca praśne prativacanam api tathā syāt
translated: If you say there is nothing, there is something else, there is both something and nothing else, or there is neither something nor nothing else, the answer would be the same.

analyzed: pṛ kasmāt idam aprapañcam
translated: Why is this non-elaborate?

original: u ayaṃ vastuta ātmadharmapraśnaḥ yadyekaḥ yadi vāneka iti /
analyzed: u ayam vastutas ātma dharma praśnaḥ yadi ekaḥ yadi vā anekaḥ iti
translated: This question is really about the self and its attributes, whether it is one or many.

analyzed: atas na pratyuvāca
translated: Therefore, he did not answer.

analyzed: ātmā ca na niyataḥ
translated: The self is not definite.

analyzed: pañca skandheṣu kevalam prajñaptyā abhidhīyate  yadi asti kiñcid iti
translated: It is merely designated in the five aggregates.🔽If one were to say there is something

analyzed: yadi vā na asti kiñcid iti pratibrūyāt
translated: or there is nothing,

analyzed: tadā śāśvata uccheda pātaḥ syāt
translated: then one would fall into the extremes of eternalism and nihilism.

analyzed: yat sa niṣprapañcaḥ
translated: The self that is conventionally designated in dependence on the five aggregates is non-elaborate.

original: yadi paśyati sattvaṃ śūnyaṃ dharmāśca śūnyā iti sa niṣprapañcārāmaḥ /
analyzed: yadi paśyati sattvam śūnyam dharmāḥ ca śūnyāḥ iti sa niṣprapañca ārāmaḥ
translated: If one sees beings as empty and phenomena as empty, one delights in the non-elaborate.

analyzed: atas niṣprapañca ārāmāḥ bhagavat śāsana īrtham vindante
translated: Therefore, those who delight in the non-elaborate find meaning in the Blessed One's teachings.

analyzed: iyam kuśala vitarka sampadā
translated: This is the excellence of skillful investigation.

analyzed: kuśala vitarka vargaḥ tri aśīti uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: Chapter 83: Good Contemplation
Chapter on the Five Requisites for the Final Three Concentrations

analyzed: kalyāṇa adhimukti sampad iti
translated: The abundance of good faith.

analyzed: yogī yat saṃsāram vidveṣayati
translated: The yogi who delights in nirvana and hates samsara.

analyzed: iyam kalyāṇa adhimuktiḥ
translated: This is good faith.

analyzed: evam adhimuktaḥ kṣipram vimukti bhāj bhavati
translated: Being thus faithful, one quickly becomes a partaker of liberation.

analyzed: nirvāṇa abhiratasya cittam na kutracid abhiniviśate
translated: For one who delights in nirvana, the mind does not cling to anything.

analyzed: nirvāṇa abhiratasya na asti bhayam
translated: One who delights in nirvana has no fear.

analyzed: yadi pṛthagjanasya cittam nirvāṇam anusmarati
translated: If the mind of an ordinary person remembers nirvana,

analyzed: tadā eva santrāsaḥ bhavati aham atyantam nakṣyāmi iti
translated: then fear arises: I will be utterly destroyed.

analyzed: pṛ kena pratyayena nirvāṇa idhim ucyate
translated: By what condition does one have faith in nirvana?

original: u yogī lokamanityaṃ duḥkhaṃ śūnyamanātmakaṃ dṛṣṭvā nirvāṇe upaśamasaṃjñāmutpādayati /
analyzed: yogī lokam anityam duḥkham śūnyam anātmakam dṛṣṭvā nirvāṇe upaśama saṃjñām utpādayati
translated: The yogi, seeing the world as impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self, gives rise to the notion of peace in nirvana.

analyzed: svābhāvika kleśa pratanu bhūtaḥ nirvāṇa bhāṇakam śṛṇoti
translated: This person, with naturally thin afflictions, hears the one who speaks of nirvana.

analyzed: tadā tasya cittam tatra adhimucyate
translated: Then his mind has faith in that.

original: yadi vā kalyāṇamitrāt yadi vā sūtrādhyayanāt saṃsāra ādīnavaṃ śṛṇoti /
analyzed: yadi vā kalyāṇa mitrāt yadi vā sūtra adhyayanāt saṃsāraḥ ādīnavam śṛṇoti
translated: If from a good friend or from studying the sutras, one hears the danger of samsara,

analyzed: yathā an avara agra sūtre pañca deva dūta sūtre ca uktam
translated: As it is said in the Sutra on the Beginningless Cycle of Existence and in the Sutra on the Five Messengers of the Gods.

analyzed: tadā saṃsārāt nirviṇṇaḥ nirvāṇa idhim ucyate
translated: Then, being disgusted with samsara, one becomes devoted to nirvana.

analyzed: pradhānīyā aṅga sampad iti
translated: The abundance of the principal factors.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre pañca pradhānīya aṅgāni
translated: As it is said in the sutra, there are five principal factors.

analyzed: katamāni pañca
translated: What are the five?

original: iha bhikṣavo bhikṣuḥ śrāddho bhavati /🔽aśaṭho bhavati /
analyzed: iha bhikṣavaḥ bhikṣuḥ śrāddhaḥ bhavati  a śaṭhaḥ bhavati
translated: Here, monks, a monk is faithful.🔽He is not deceitful.

analyzed: alpa ābādhaḥ bhavati
translated: He has little illness.

analyzed: ārabdha vīryaḥ bhavati
translated: He is one who has begun effort.

analyzed: prajñāvān bhavati iti
translated: He is wise.

original: śraddhāvān nāmayaḥ triṣu ratneṣu caturṣu satyeṣu ca vigatavicikitso bhavati /
analyzed: śraddhāvān nāmayaḥ triṣu ratneṣu caturṣu satyeṣu ca vigata vicikitsaḥ bhavati
translated: One who is faithful is one who is free from doubt regarding the Three Jewels and the Four Noble Truths.

analyzed: vigata vicikitsā tvāt kṣipram samādhiḥ sidhyati
translated: Because of being free from doubt, samadhi is quickly accomplished.

analyzed: śraddhāvataḥ prīti bahula tvāt ca kṣipram samādhiḥ sidhyati
translated: And because one who is faithful is full of joy, samadhi is quickly accomplished.

analyzed: śraddhāvān su samāhitaḥ dāntaḥ ca bhavati
translated: One who is faithful becomes well-concentrated and disciplined.

analyzed: atas api sahasā samādhim vindate
translated: Therefore, he also quickly attains samadhi.

analyzed: yadi samādhinā prajñā utpadyate
translated: If wisdom arises from samadhi,

analyzed: atha vicikitsām prajahāti
translated: then how does one abandon doubt?

analyzed: katham idānīm samādheḥ pūrvam eva ucyate vigata vicikitsaḥ iti
translated: How is it that one is said to be free from doubt even before samadhi?

analyzed: u bahu śruta tvāt kiñcid vicikitsām prajahāti
translated: And by being very learned, one abandons some doubts.

analyzed: na samādhi lābhāt
translated: Not by attaining concentration.

original: adhimuktakulotpannaḥ śrāddhena sahavṛttikaḥ sadādhimukticittaṃ bhāvayan apratilabdhasamādhirapi vicikitsāṃ na karoti / evamādi /
analyzed: adhimukta kula utpannaḥ śrāddhena saha vṛttikaḥ sadā adhimukti cittam bhāvayan a pratilabdha samādhiḥ api vicikitsām na karoti evamādi
translated: One born in a family of faithful ones, with a livelihood together with the faithful, always cultivating the mind of faith, even without attaining concentration, does not doubt, and so on.

analyzed: aśaṭhaḥ iti ṛju cittasya na asti kiñcid gopanīyam
translated: Honest means one with a straightforward mind has nothing to hide.

analyzed: sat api su tīrṇam bhavati
translated: Even if one has a fault, it is easily cured.

analyzed: yathā kaścid bhiṣajam upetya vyādhi svarūpam uktvā sucikitsaḥ bhavati
translated: For example, someone who goes to a doctor, tells the nature of the illness, becomes easily curable.

analyzed: alpa ābādhaḥ iti
translated: Having few afflictions means

analyzed: sa pūrvarātre pararātre ca vyavasyati
translated: one is intent on the first and last watches of the night.

analyzed: na viramati
translated: One does not rest.

analyzed: yadi ābādha a bahulaḥ
translated: If one has many afflictions,

analyzed: tad mārga caryāyāḥ antarāyaḥ bhavati
translated: it becomes an obstacle to the practice of the path.

analyzed: ārabdha vīryaḥ iti
translated: One who has begun effort means

analyzed: mārga arthi tvāt sadā viryam ārabhate
translated: because one seeks the path, one always begins effort.

original: ato'gniṃ manthāno na viramamāṇo sahasāgniṃ vindate /
analyzed: atas agnim manthānaḥ na viramamāṇaḥ sahasā agnim vindate
translated: Therefore, one who is not resting while churning fire suddenly finds fire.

analyzed: prajñāvān iti
translated: Wise means

original: prajñāvattvena caturṇāmaṅgānāṃ phalaṃ bhavati yaduta mārgaphalam /
analyzed: prajñāvat tvena caturṇām aṅgānām phalam bhavati yat uta mārga phalam
translated: by being wise, one attains the fruit of the four limbs, namely the fruit of the path.

analyzed: smṛti upasthāna dharmāḥ api pradhānīya aṅgāni
translated: The foundations of mindfulness are also the principal limbs of the path.

analyzed: kasmāt kevalam ete pañca dharmāḥ uktāḥ
translated: Why are only these five dharmas mentioned?

analyzed: u yadi api sakalam aṅgam
translated: Even though all are limbs,

analyzed: tathā api ime dharmāḥ mukhyatamāḥ yogibhiḥ api apekṣyante
translated: nevertheless, these dharmas are the most important and are considered by yogis.

analyzed: atas ime kevala muktāḥ
translated: Therefore, only these are mentioned.

original: sarveṣāṃ pāpakānāṃ parivarjanaṃ sarveṣāṃ kuśalānāṃ sañcayaśca yogino'ṅgam /
analyzed: sarveṣām pāpakānām parivarjanam sarveṣām kuśalānām sañcayaḥ ca yoginaḥ uṅgam
translated: Abandoning all evil and accumulating all good are the limbs of yogis.

analyzed: yathā sūtre varṇitam
translated: As it is described in the sutra.

analyzed: vimukti āyatana sampad iti yat pañca vimukti āyatanāni
translated: The abundance of the bases of liberation means the five bases of liberation.

original: ihaśāstā anyataro vā gurusthānīyaḥ sa brahmacārī bhikṣūnāṃ dharmaṃ deśayati /
analyzed: ihaśāstā anyataraḥ vā guru sthānīyaḥ sa brahmacārī bhikṣūnām dharmam deśayati
translated: Here, either the Teacher or another venerable person teaches the Dharma to the monks.

original: yathā yathā dharmaṃ deśayati /🔽tathā tathā tasmin dharme arthapratisaṃvedī ca dharmapratisaṃvedī ca bhavati /
analyzed: yathā yathā dharmam deśayati  tathā tathā tasmin dharme artha pratisaṃvedī ca dharma pratisaṃvedī ca bhavati
translated: As he teaches the Dharma,🔽he becomes one who experiences the meaning and the Dharma in that teaching.🔽Joy arises for him who experiences the meaning and the Dharma.

analyzed: tasya artha pratisaṃvedinaḥ dharma pratisaṃvedinaḥ prītiḥ jāyate
translated: The mind of one who is joyful becomes serene.

analyzed: prīta manasaḥ kāyaḥ praśrabhyate
translated: The body of one whose mind is serene becomes tranquil.

analyzed: praśrabdha kāyaḥ sukham vedayate
translated: One who has a tranquil body experiences pleasure.

analyzed: sukhinaḥ cittam samādhīyate
translated: The mind of one who is pleased becomes concentrated.

analyzed: idam prathamam vimukti āyatanam
translated: This is the first basis of liberation.

original: yatra bhikṣo rapramattasyātāpinaḥ prahitātmano viharato'vimuktaṃ cittaṃ vimucyate /
analyzed: yatra bhikṣoḥ ra pramattasya atāpinaḥ prahitātmanaḥ viharataḥ vimuktam cittam vimucyate
translated: Where, for a monk who is heedful, ardent, and resolute, the mind is liberated,

analyzed: a parikṣīṇāḥ vai āsravāḥ parikṣayam gacchanti
translated: or the defilements that have not yet been exhausted are exhausted,

analyzed: an anuprāptam vā anuttaram yogakṣemam anuprāpnoti
translated: or he attains the unsurpassed security from bondage that has not yet been attained.

analyzed: dvitīyam vimukti āyatanam vistareṇa sūtra adhyayanam
translated: The second abode of liberation is extensive study of the sutras.

analyzed: tṛtīyam pareṣām dharma deśanā
translated: The third is teaching the Dharma to others.

analyzed: caturtham vimukte sthāne dharmāṇām anuvitarkaḥ anuvicāraḥ
translated: The fourth is thorough investigation and consideration of the dharmas in the place of liberation.

original: pañcamaṃ samādhinimittasya sugrahaṇaṃ yaduta navanimittādīni yathāpūrvamuktāni /
analyzed: pañcamam samādhi nimittasya su grahaṇam yat uta nava nimitta ādīni yathāpūrvam uktāni
translated: The fifth is proper grasping of the sign of concentration, namely the nine signs and so on as previously mentioned.

original: pṛ śāstā anyataro vā gurusthānīyaḥ sabrahmacārī kasmāt bhikṣūṇāṃ dharmaṃ deśayati /
analyzed: pṛ śāstā anyataraḥ vā guru sthānīyaḥ sabrahmacārī kasmāt bhikṣūṇām dharmam deśayati
translated: Why does the teacher or another senior co-religious person teach the Dharma to the monks?

analyzed: dharma sama apādānena mahāntam artham āpnoti
translated: Because by attaining the Dharma, one attains great benefit.

analyzed: iti atas deśanām karoti
translated: Therefore, he teaches.

analyzed: sa brahmacārī ayaḥ śāstāram upādāya pravrajitaḥ
translated: A co-religious person is one who has gone forth taking the teacher as the basis.

analyzed: indriyāṇām paripācanāya dharmam deśayati
translated: He teaches the Dharma for the ripening of the faculties.

analyzed: guru sthānīyaḥ sabrahmacārī samāna karma tvāt ca dharma deśanām karoti
translated: A fellow student who is like a teacher teaches the Dharma because of having the same duties.

analyzed: bhikṣavaḥ vaśyam dharmam śṛṇvanti iti atas ca dharma deśanām karoti
translated: Monks necessarily listen to the Dharma, therefore he teaches the Dharma.

original: ime pudgalā viśuddhaśīlādiguṇasampannāḥ tadyathā subhājanaṃ samṛddhiṃ samādātuṃ bhavyam ityato dharmadeśanāṃ karoti /
analyzed: ime pudgalāḥ viśuddha śīla ādi guṇa sampannāḥ tat yathā su bhājanam samṛddhim samādātum bhavyam iti atas dharma deśanām karoti
translated: These persons are endowed with pure morality and other qualities, just as a good vessel is fit to receive abundance, therefore he teaches the Dharma.

analyzed: imāḥ tisraḥ prajñāḥ dharma pratisaṃvedaḥ bahu śruta mayī prajñā

analyzed: vimocayan cittam praśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate  anitya anudarśī āśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate
translated: He trains like this: “I will breathe in liberating the mind.”🔽He trains like this: “I will breathe out contemplating impermanence.”

analyzed: anitya anudarśī praśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate  virāga anudarśī āśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate
translated: He trains like this: “I will breathe in contemplating impermanence.”🔽He trains like this: “I will breathe out contemplating dispassion.”

analyzed: virāga anudarśī praśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate  nirodha anudarśī āśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate
translated: He trains like this: “I will breathe in contemplating dispassion.”🔽He trains like this: “I will breathe out contemplating cessation.”

analyzed: nirodha anudarśī praśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate  pratinissarga anudarśī āśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate
translated: He trains like this: “I will breathe in contemplating cessation.”🔽He trains like this: “I will breathe out contemplating letting go.”

analyzed: pratinissarga anudarśī praśvasiṣyāmi iti śikṣate
translated: He trains like this: “I will breathe in contemplating letting go.”

original: pṛ kathamānāpānasya dīrghaṃ hrasvaṃ vā bhavati /
analyzed: pṛ katham āna apānasya dīrgham hrasvam vā bhavati
translated: How is the mindfulness of breathing long or short?

analyzed: u yathā kaścid parvatam ārohati
translated: Just as someone climbing a mountain,

analyzed: yadi vā vā bhāram vahati
translated: or carrying a heavy load,

analyzed: tadā klāntaḥ hrasvam śvasati
translated: when tired, breathes short.

original: tathā yogyapi audārike citte pravṛtte hrasvaṃ śvasati /
analyzed: tathā yogī api audārike citte pravṛtte hrasvam śvasati
translated: Similarly, when the yogi's gross mind is active, he breathes short.

analyzed: audārika cittam iti capalam roga vikṣiptam cittam
translated: A gross mind is a fickle mind, a distracted mind.

original: dīrghaṃ śvasatīti yadi yogī sūkṣmacitte sthitaḥ /
analyzed: dīrgham śvasati iti yadi yogī sūkṣma citte sthitaḥ
translated: He breathes long if the yogi is established in a subtle mind.

analyzed: tadā tasya āśvāsa praśvāsāḥ dīrghāḥ bhavanti
translated: Then his inhalation and exhalation become long.

analyzed: kasmāt  sūkṣma citta anuvartinaḥ āśvāsa praśvāsāḥ api sūkṣmāḥ anupatanti
translated: Why?🔽Because the inhalations and exhalations, following the subtle mind, become subtle.

original: yathā tasyaiva klāntasya viśrāntasya āśrāsapraśvāsā sūkṣmā anupatanti /
analyzed: yathā tasya eva klāntasya viśrāntasya āśrāsa praśvāsā sūkṣmāḥ anupatanti
translated: Just as for that very tired person, when rested, the inhalations and exhalations become subtle.

original: tasmin samaye dīrghā aśvāsa praśvāsā bhavanti /
analyzed: tasmin samaye dīrghāḥ aśvāsa praśvāsāḥ bhavanti
translated: At that time, the inhalations and exhalations become long.

analyzed: sarva kāya pratisaṃvedi iti
translated: Experiencing the whole body.

original: yogī kāye tucchādhimuktaḥ sarvaromakūpeṣu vāyumantarbahiścāriṇaṃ paśyati /
analyzed: yogī kāye tuccha adhimuktaḥ sarva romakūpeṣu vāyum antar bahis cāriṇam paśyati
translated: The yogi, with faith in the emptiness of the body, sees air moving in and out of all the pores.

analyzed: praśrambhayan kāya saṃskāram iti
translated: Relaxing the bodily formation.

original: dhātubalalābhino vyupaśāntacittasya yogina audārikā āśvāsapraśvāsā vyupaśāntā bhavanti /
analyzed: dhātu bala lābhinaḥ vyupaśānta cittasya yoginaḥ audārikāḥ āśvāsa praśvāsāḥ vyupaśāntāḥ bhavanti
translated: For the yogi who has attained the strength of the elements and has a tranquil mind, the gross inhalations and exhalations become tranquil.

analyzed: tadā yogī kāya mmṛti upasthāna samanvitaḥ bhavati
translated: Then the yogi is endowed with the mindfulness of body death.

analyzed: prīti pratisaṃvedi iti
translated: Experiencing joy.

analyzed: asmāt samādhi dharmāt asya citte mahatī prītiḥ bhavati
translated: From this concentration dharma, great joy arises in his mind.

original: prakṛtito vidyamānā'pi naivaṃ bhavati /🔽asmin samaye prītipratisaṃvedītyākhyāyate /
analyzed: prakṛtitaḥ vidyamānā api na evam bhavati  asmin samaye prīti pratisaṃvedī iti ākhyāyate
translated: Even though it exists by nature, it is not like this.🔽At this time, he is called experiencing joy.

analyzed: sukha pratisaṃvedi iti
translated: Experiencing happiness.

analyzed: prīteḥ sukham jāyate
translated: Happiness arises from joy.

analyzed: kasmāt  prīta manasaḥ kāyaḥ praśrabhyate
translated: Why is it so?🔽The mind of one who is joyful becomes serene.

analyzed: praśrabdha kāyaḥ sukham vindate
translated: One whose body is serene experiences happiness.

analyzed: yathā uktam sūtre prīta manasaḥ kāyaḥ praśramyate
translated: As it is said in the sutra, the body of one whose mind is joyful becomes serene.

analyzed: praśrabdha kāyaḥ sukham vedayate iti
translated: One whose body is serene experiences happiness.

analyzed: citta saṃskāra pratisaṃvedi iti
translated: Experiencing the mental formations.

analyzed: yogī prītau ādīnavam paśyati
translated: The yogi sees the danger in joy.

analyzed: rāga janaka tvāt
translated: Because it gives rise to attachment.

analyzed: rāgaḥ yam citta saṃskāraḥ cittāt utpanna tvāt
translated: This attachment is a mental formation, because it arises from the mind.

original: vedanāyāṃ rāgo jāyata ityato vedanāṃ cittasaṃskāraṃ paśyati /
analyzed: vedanāyām rāgaḥ jāyate iti atas vedanām citta saṃskāram paśyati
translated: Attachment arises from feeling, therefore he sees feeling as a mental formation.

analyzed: praśrambhayan citta saṃskāram iti
translated: Calming the mental formations.

analyzed: yogī paśyati vedanātaḥ rāgaḥ jāyate
translated: The yogi sees that attachment arises from feeling.

analyzed: tat praśrambhayataḥ cittam upaśāmyati
translated: By calming that, the mind becomes tranquil.

analyzed: audārika vedanām api praśrambhayati iti praśrambhayan citta saṃskāram iti ucyate
translated: It is said to pacify mental formations because it also pacifies gross feelings.

analyzed: citta pratisaṃvedi iti
translated: Experiencing the mind.

original: yogī praśrambhayan vedanāsvādaṃ paśyati cittaṃ śāntaṃ na līnaṃ noddhatam /
analyzed: yogī praśrambhayan vedanā āsvādam paśyati cittam śāntam na līnam na uddhatam
translated: The yogi, pacifying the taste of feelings, sees the mind as peaceful, neither sunken nor agitated.

analyzed: cittam idam kasmiṃścid samaye punar līnam bhavati
translated: At what time is this mind sunken?

analyzed: tasmin
translated: At that time, he should uplift it.

analyzed: yadi punar uddhatam
translated: If it is agitated again,

analyzed: tasmin samaye samādadhāti
translated: at that time, he should concentrate it.

analyzed: yadi ubhaya dharma vinirmuktam
translated: If it is free from both qualities,

analyzed: tasmin samaye samutsṛjet
translated: at that time, he should release it.

analyzed: atas ucyate vimocayan cittam iti
translated: Therefore, it is said to liberate the mind.

analyzed: evam yogī samāhitaḥ nitya ākāram utpādayati
translated: Thus, the yogi, being concentrated, produces the aspect of impermanence.

analyzed: anitya ākāreṇa kleśān prajahāti
translated: By the aspect of impermanence, he abandons the defilements.

analyzed: ayam nirodha ākaraḥ
translated: This is the aspect of cessation.

analyzed: kleśānām prahāṇāt cittam nirvidyate
translated: Due to the abandonment of defilements, the mind becomes disgusted.

analyzed: ayam virāga ākāraḥ
translated: This is the aspect of dispassion.

analyzed: virakta citta tayā sarveṣām pratinissargam anuprāpnoti
translated: Due to the mind being detached, he attains the complete abandonment of all.

analyzed: ayam prati nissarga ākāraḥ
translated: This is the aspect of complete abandonment.

analyzed: evam anupūrvam vimuktim anuprāpnoti iti ṣoḍaśa ākārāḥ āna apāna smṛteḥ bhavanti
translated: Thus, he attains liberation in sequence. Thus, there are sixteen aspects of mindfulness of breathing.

original: pṛ kasmādānāpānasmṛtirāryavihāra iti divyavihāra iti brahmavihāra iti śaikṣavihāra iti aśaikṣavihāra iti cocyate /
analyzed: kasmāt āna apāna smṛtiḥ ārya vihāraḥ iti divya vihāraḥ iti brahma vihāraḥ iti śaikṣa vihāraḥ iti aśaikṣa vihāraḥ iti ca ucyate
translated: Why is mindfulness of breathing called the noble abode, the divine abode, the brahmin abode, the abode of the trainee, and the abode of the non-trainee?

analyzed: u vāyuḥ ākāśe viharati
translated: Air moves in space.

analyzed: ākāśa lakṣaṇam rūpa lakṣaṇam prakaṭayati
translated: The characteristic of space manifests the characteristic of form.

analyzed: rūpa lakṣaṇam idam śūnyam eva
translated: This characteristic of form is empty itself.

analyzed: śūnyatā eva ārya vihāraḥ iti ārya vihāraḥ bhavati
translated: Emptiness itself is the noble abode, so it becomes the noble abode.

analyzed: śubha deveṣu utpati artha tvāt divya vihāraḥ
translated: Because it leads to rebirth among the auspicious gods, it is the divine abode.

analyzed: upaśama prāpaṇa artha tvāt brahmavihāraḥ
translated: Because it leads to the attainment of tranquility, it is the brahmin abode.

analyzed: śaikṣa dharma pratilābha artha tvāt śaikṣa vihāraḥ
translated: Because it leads to the attainment of the dharmas of the trainee, it is the abode of the trainee.

analyzed: aśaikṣa artha tvāt aśaikṣa vihāraḥ
translated: Because it leads to the non-trainee state, it is the abode of the non-trainee.

analyzed: yadi aśubha bhāvanayā kāyāt viraktaḥ vimuktim anuprāpnoti
translated: If one becomes detached from the body through the cultivation of foulness and attains liberation,

analyzed: kaḥ upayogaḥ ebhiḥ ṣoḍaśabhiḥ ākāraiḥ
translated: what is the use of these sixteen aspects?

original: u aśubhabhāvanayā alabdhavairāgyasya ātmadurviṇṇasya kāyacitte vyāmohite syātām /
analyzed: u aśubha bhāvanayā alabdha vairāgyasya ātma durviṇṇasya kāya citte vyāmohite syātām
translated: For one who has not attained detachment through the cultivation of foulness, who is despondent about the self, the body and mind would become confused.

analyzed: yathā duṣṭam auṣadham sevamānasya vyādhiḥ punar bhavati
translated: Just as when one uses a bad medicine, the disease returns.

analyzed: evam aśubha bhāvanayā durnivedaḥ bhavati
translated: In the same way, the cultivation of foulness becomes difficult to digest.

original: yathā valgumuttitīrṣayā bhikṣavo'śubhabhāvanayā atīva nirviṇṇā viṣapānabhṛgupatanādibhirvividhairātmānaṃ dhnanti sma /
analyzed: yathā valgu muttitīrṣayā bhikṣavaḥ śubha bhāvanayā atīva nirviṇṇāḥ viṣa pāna bhṛgu patana ādibhiḥ vividhaiḥ ātmānam dhnanti sma
translated: As the monks, desiring to attain the pleasant state, became extremely disgusted with their bodies through the meditation on foulness, they destroyed themselves in various ways, by drinking poison, falling off cliffs, and so on.

original: na tathā ime ṣoḍaśākārā vairāgyaprāpakā api na durnivedajanakā bhavantītyato viśiṣyante /
analyzed: na tathā ime ṣoḍaśa ākārāḥ vairāgya prāpakāḥ api na durniveda janakāḥ bhavanti iti atas viśiṣyante
translated: These sixteen aspects, though leading to detachment, do not cause such difficulty, so they are superior.

analyzed: kiñca ayam ākāraḥ sulabhaḥ sva kāya avalambi tvāt
translated: Moreover, this aspect is easy to attain because it relies on one's own body.

analyzed: aśubha ākāraḥ tu su vināśaḥ
translated: But the aspect of foulness is easily destroyed.

analyzed: ayam ākāraḥ sūkṣmaḥ sva kāya vipariṇāmaka tvāt
translated: This aspect is subtle because it transforms one's own body.

analyzed: aśubha ākāraḥ audārikaḥ
translated: But the aspect of foulness is gross.

analyzed: asthi kaṅkāla vipariṇāma duṣṭaḥ
translated: It is defiled by the transformation into bones and skeletons.

analyzed: ayam ākāraḥ sarveṣām kleśānām bhedakaḥ
translated: This aspect is the differentiator of all defilements.

analyzed: aśubha ākāraḥ tu maithuna rāga mātrasya kasmāt
translated: But the aspect of foulness is only of sexual desire. Why is it so?

original: sarve hi kleśā vitarkaṃ pratītya jāyante /
analyzed: sarve hi kleśāḥ vitarkam pratītya jāyante
translated: Because all defilements arise in dependence on discursive thought.

analyzed: āna apāna smṛteḥ ca sarva vitarka upaccheda ārtha tvāt
translated: And because mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation serves to cut off all discursive thoughts.

original: pṛ anāpānaṃ kiṃ kāyānubandhi kiṃ cittānubandhi /
analyzed: an āpānam kim kāya anubandhi kim citta anubandhi
translated: Is inhalation and exhalation related to the body or to the mind?

analyzed: u kāya anubandhi citta anubandhi ca
translated: It is related to both the body and the mind.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: garbhāśaya gatasya abhāvāt jñāyate kāya adhīnam iti
translated: Because it is known to be dependent on the body, since it does not exist for one in the womb.

analyzed: caturtha dhyāna ādikasya acittakasya ca abhāvāt jñāyate citta anubandhi iti
translated: Because it does not exist in the fourth dhyāna and above, and in the mindless state, it is known to be associated with the mind.

analyzed: āśvāsa praśvāsaḥ bhūtvā utpannaḥ citta adhīnaḥ na syāt
translated: In-and-out breathing, which did not exist before but arises, would not be dependent on the mind.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: sa na manasaḥ vaśāt utpadyate
translated: It does not arise by the power of the mind.

original: yathā anyadvastu smarati citte sadā āśvāsapraśvāsā bhavanti /
analyzed: yathā anyat vastu smarati citte sadā āśvāsa praśvāsāḥ bhavanti
translated: Just as one remembers another thing, in-and-out breathing always occurs in the mind.

analyzed: yathā bhuktaḥ āhāraḥ svayam paripacyate
translated: Just as food eaten is digested by itself.

original: yathā ca pratibimbaṃ svayaṃ pravartate na puruṣaḥ karoti /
analyzed: yathā ca pratibimbam svayam pravartate na puruṣaḥ karoti
translated: And just as a reflection occurs by itself, a person does not make it.

analyzed: āśvāsa praśvāsaḥ bhūtvā utpadyate na smṛti vaśāt
translated: In-and-out breathing arises without having existed, not by the power of memory.

analyzed: kintu pratyaya sāmagryā utpadyate
translated: But it arises from the totality of conditions.

analyzed: sa cittasya asti acittakasya punar na asti
translated: It exists for one with mind, but not for one without mind.

analyzed: atas jñāyate citta adhīnaḥ iti
translated: Therefore it is known to be dependent on the mind.

analyzed: yathācittañca bhidyate  audārika cittasya hrasvaḥ
translated: And it is differentiated according to the mind.🔽For one with a gross mind, it is short.

analyzed: sūkṣmacittasya dīrghaḥ
translated: For one with a subtle mind, it is long.

analyzed: āna apānam bhūmi adhīnam citta adhīnam  āna apāna bhūmi
translated: In-and-out breathing is dependent on the stage and the mind.🔽The stage of in-and-out breathing

analyzed: gatasya āna apāna bhūmiḥ api asti
translated: For one who has attained the stage of in-and-out breathing, there is also the stage of in-and-out breathing.

analyzed: tasya tasmin samaye cittam api asti
translated: At that time, he also has a mind.

analyzed: āna apāna bhūmiḥ nāma kāmadhātu strīṇi dhyānāni ca
translated: The stage of in-and-out breathing is named the desire realm and the three dhyānas.

original: ya ānāpānabhūmigataḥ tasya asti tu ānāpānabhūmicittam /
analyzed: yaḥ āna apāna bhūmi gataḥ tasya asti tu āna apāna bhūmi cittam
translated: For one who has attained the stage of inhalation and exhalation, there is the mind of the stage of inhalation and exhalation.

original: acittakasya tasmin samaye tadbhūmi cittamapi nāsti /
analyzed: acittakasya tasmin samaye tat bhūmi cittam api na asti
translated: For one without mind, at that time there is no mind of that stage either.

original: ānāpānavihīnabhūmigatasya tasmin samaye tadbhūmi ścitta mapi nāsti /🔽pṛ śvāsa utpadyamāna kiṃ pūrvamāśvasati /
analyzed: āna apāna vihīna bhūmi gatasya tasmin samaye tad bhūmi ścittam api na asti  pṛ śvāsaḥ utpadyamāna kim pūrvam āśvasati
translated: For one who has attained a stage devoid of inhalation and exhalation, at that time there is no mind of that stage either.🔽When inhalation arises, does one first inhale or first exhale?

analyzed: kim vā pūrvam praśvasati
translated: What is it?

analyzed: u upapatti kāle pūrvam āśvasati
translated: At the time of rebirth, one first inhales.

analyzed: maraṇa kāla inte praśvasati
translated: At the time of death, one last exhales.

analyzed: evam caturtha dhyāne nirgamana praveśau api
translated: And so also for leaving and entering the fourth dhyana.

analyzed: āna apāna smṛtiḥ iyam katham paripūrṇā bhavati
translated: How is this mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation fulfilled?

analyzed: u yogī yadi ṣoḍaśa ākārān pratilabhate
translated: The yogi, if he obtains the sixteen aspects,

analyzed: tasmin samaye paripūrṇā bhavati
translated: at that time it is fulfilled.

analyzed: kecid śāsta ācāryāḥ vadanti ṣaṣ ibhaḥ pratyayaiḥ paripūrṇā iti
translated: Some teachers of the Master say it is fulfilled by six conditions.

original: ṣaṭ pratyayā yaduta gaṇanā anubandhanā śamatho vipaśyanā vivartanaṃ pariśuddhiḥ /
analyzed: ṣaṭ pratyayāḥ yat uta gaṇanā anubandhanā śamathaḥ vipaśyanā vivartanam pariśuddhiḥ
translated: The six conditions are counting, following, tranquility, insight, reversal, and purification.

analyzed: gaṇanā āna apāna gaṇanā ekatas ārabhya yāvat daśa
translated: Counting is counting the inhalations and exhalations from one to ten.

original: triprakārā gaṇanā samā vā atiriktā vā nyūnā vā /
analyzed: tri prakārā gaṇanā samā vā atiriktā vā nyūnā vā
translated: Counting is of three kinds: equal, excessive, or deficient.

original: samā nāma daśasu satsu daśeti gaṇayati /🔽atiriktā nāma ekādaśasu daśeti gaṇayati /
analyzed: samāḥ nāma daśasu satsu daśā iti gaṇayati  atiriktāḥ nāma ekādaśasu daśa iti gaṇayati
translated: The equal is when one counts ten in ten that are present.🔽The excess is when one counts ten in eleven.

analyzed: nyūnāḥ nāma navasu daśa iti gaṇayati
translated: The deficiency is when one counts ten in nine.

analyzed: anubandhanam nāma yoginaḥ citta māna apānam anubadhnāti
translated: The continuity is when the yogin's mind is connected to inhalation and exhalation.

original: vipaśyanā nāma yogī āśvāsapraśvāsān kāyānubaddhān maṇiṣu sūtravatpaśyati /
analyzed: vipaśyanāḥ nāma yogī āśvāsa praśvāsān kāya anubaddhān maṇiṣu sūtra vat paśyati
translated: Insight is when the yogin sees the in-breaths and out-breaths connected to the body like a thread in a jewel.

analyzed: śamathaḥ nāma cittasya an āpāne pratiṣṭhāpanam
translated: Tranquility is the establishment of the mind in inhalation and exhalation.

original: vivartanaṃ nāma cittaṃ pratītya kāyasya pravṛttiḥ /
analyzed: vivartanam nāma cittam pratītya kāyasya pravṛttiḥ
translated: Reversal is the activity of the body in dependence on the mind.

analyzed: cittam pratītya ca vedanāyāḥ
translated: And the activity of feeling is in dependence on the mind.

analyzed: pratyutpanna citta dharmaḥ upi evam
translated: The present mind-dharma is also like this.

original: pariśuddhirnāma yogini sarvakleśaiḥ sarvākṣaṇaiśca vimukte cittaṃ pariśudhyati /
analyzed: pariśuddhiḥ nāma yogini sarva kleśaiḥ sarva akṣaṇaiḥ ca vimukte cittam pariśudhyati
translated: Purification is when the yogin's mind is purified, being liberated from all defilements and all unfavorable factors.

analyzed: nemevaśyaniyatāḥ
translated: These are not necessarily fixed.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: ākāreṣu gaṇa anubandhana rūpayoḥ dvayoḥ dharmayoḥ na avaśyam upayogaḥ bhavati
translated: Because in the aspects, the two dharmas of counting and continuity are not necessarily used.

original: yato yogī kevalamānāpāne cittaṃ pratiṣṭhāpayan sarvān vitarkānupacchedayati /
analyzed: yatas yogī kevala māna apāne cittam pratiṣṭhāpayan sarvān vitarkān upacchedayati
translated: Because the yogin, establishing the mind only in inhalation and exhalation, cuts off all discursive thoughts.

original: yaḥ ṣoḍaśavidhamācarituṃ samarthaḥ sa paripūrṇa ityucyate /
analyzed: yaḥ ṣoḍaśavidham ācaritum samarthaḥ sa paripūrṇaḥ iti ucyate
translated: One who is able to practice the sixteen aspects is said to be complete.

analyzed: idam paripūrṇa lakṣaṇam ca aniyatam
translated: This characteristic of completeness is indeterminate.

analyzed: mṛdu indriya ācaritam tīkṣṇa indriyasya a paripūrṇam
translated: What is practiced by one of dull faculties is incomplete for one of sharp faculties.

analyzed: āna apāna sūtre ismin kasmāt uktam āhārāya bhavati iti
translated: In this Ānāpānasūtra, why is it said to be for nourishment?

analyzed: u āna apāna stimitasya kāyaḥ sukhī bhavati
translated: When one is still in Ānāpāna, the body becomes happy.

analyzed: yathā madhura anna bhujaḥ kāyaḥ prahlādyate
translated: Just as the body is refreshed by eating sweet food.

analyzed: atas āhārāya bhavati iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, it is said to be for nourishment.

analyzed: eṣu ṣoḍaśa ākāreṣu kim āna apānam saṃsmarati
translated: Among these sixteen aspects, what does one recollect in Ānāpāna?

analyzed: idam eva kāya anusmṛtiḥ iti ucyate

analyzed: caturdhā kāyam anusmarati iti kāya anusmṛtiḥ

analyzed: smṛtiḥ atīta ālambanā

analyzed: āśvāsa praśvāsāḥ pratyutpannāḥ
translated: Inhalation and exhalation are present.

analyzed: kasmāt tat smṛtiḥ bhavati

analyzed: idam prajñapti bhedakam jñānam anusmṛti nāmnā ucyate
translated: This knowledge that distinguishes designations is called mindfulness.

analyzed: caitasika dharmāṇām anyonyam nāma bhavati

analyzed: yathā daśa saṃjñā ādayaḥ smṛti pūrvam kriyamāṇa tvāt anusmṛtiḥ iti ucyate
translated: For example, the ten perceptions and so on are called anusmrti because they are performed with memory as the antecedent.

analyzed: dīrgha hrasva ādīnām nārya vihāraḥ iti abhidhānam
translated: The dwelling of men and women is called dīrgha and hrasva.

analyzed: katham smṛti upasthānam iti ākhyāyate

original: uktañca sūtre yogī ānāpānaṃ śikṣamāṇaḥ dīrghamāśvasan vā śikṣate hrasvaṃ vā sarvakāyapratisaṃvedī vā praśrambhayan kāyasaṃskāraṃ vā śikṣate
analyzed: uktam ca sūtre yogī āna apānam śikṣamāṇaḥ dīrgham āśvasan vā śikṣate hrasvam vā sarva kāya pratisaṃvedī vā praśrambhayan kāya saṃskāram vā śikṣate
translated: It is said in the sutra: The yogi, while training in inhalation and exhalation, trains in breathing long or short, or in experiencing the entire body, or in calming the bodily formations.

analyzed: tasmin samaye kāya smṛti upasthānam bhavati
translated: At that time, there is the foundation of mindfulness of the body.

analyzed: ayam ādyaḥ upāya mārgaḥ
translated: This is the first path of means.

analyzed: viśuddhaye prahāṇa mārrgaḥ iti ucyate
translated: It is called the path of abandonment at the end because it leads to purification.

analyzed: atra anitya ādi ākāraḥ asti
translated: Here, there is the aspect of impermanence and so on.

analyzed: asmin sūtre param na uktam
translated: This is not stated in this sutra.

original: anyasmin sūtretūktamyogī ānāpāne sthitaḥ kāye samudayadharmānudarśī vyayadharmānudarśī /
analyzed: anyasmin sūtre tu uktam yogī āna apāne sthitaḥ kāye samudaya dharma anudarśī vyaya dharma anudarśī
translated: But it is stated in another sutra: The yogi, dwelling in inhalation and exhalation, observes the arising nature of the body, observes the passing away nature,

analyzed: samudaya vyaya dharma anudarśī viharati iti
translated: and dwells observing the arising and passing away nature.

analyzed: āha kāyam anityam paśyati ityādi
translated: It is said: He sees the body as impermanent, and so on.

analyzed: caturthe parama nitya ādi ākāraḥ paripūrṇa tvāt uktaḥ
translated: In the fourth, the aspect of supreme permanence, etc. is said to be complete.

analyzed: āna apāna vargaḥ pañcāśīti uttara śatatamaḥ
translated: This is the eighty-fifth chapter on the section on inhalation and exhalation.

analyzed: samādhi apakṣāla vargaḥ
translated: Chapter on the Hindrances to Samadhi

analyzed: samādhiḥ ayam tad pratibandhibhiḥ apakṣālaiḥ vinirmuktaḥ san mahat hitam sādhayati
translated: This samadhi, when free from the hindrances that obstruct it, accomplishes great benefit.

analyzed: yat uta audārikī prītiḥ
translated: The hindrances to samadhi are as follows: coarse joy.

original: yathoktaṃ sūtremamaudārikaṃ prītiprāmodyaṃ cittasya dūṣaṇamabhūt iti /
analyzed: yathā uktam sūtra imam audārikam prīti prāmodyam cittasya dūṣaṇam abhūt iti
